reviewText:
You can't take the sky from me...
Take Starpoint Gemini 2, Freelancer, Elite Dangerous and the worldbuilding of Starcraft 2, throw into a foodblender. Put on high for two minutes.

*WHIRRR*

This is the result. A gorgeous, whisky-soaked blend of a game where pilots drink greel distilled alcohol, where antimatter specks are used for deviant practices, and where combat takes place on a horizontal plane straight out of Assassins' Creed : Black Flag, on crack. All handled with the colour and panache of the original Torchlight, which exploded out of nowhere and revitalised the Dungeon Crawler genre. This promises, and mostly succeeds in doing the same for space exploration.

I'm a leaf on the wind, I'm a leaf on the wind!
In the time honoured tradition of all space exploration games everywhere, you are thrown into a starter ship, in this case, a dinky little corvette with a few broadside cannons, a few turrets, and a hull made of papier mache and shields made of soap suds. It is your job to find your Aunt Juno, who so very kindly left you this ship, and find out why you've been dragged out to the tail end of space, which is full of the scum of the universe, and work your way up the foodchain, blowing up said scum and villainy, and eventually become owner of a pimped up ship of doom and destruction. Depending on your playstyle this may be a top notch destroyer, with speed and agility and tons of guns, or a dreadnaught with a horrifying number of broadsides, or a heavy hauler with enough armour to qualify as having it's own gravitational pull.

Or, y'know, you could buy a strike craft and try to outrun bullets, but that's for the clinically insane. Even top level shields and good guns won't allow you to toe it with the enemy dreadnaughts for -long-, but hey, whatever flicks your switch!

Miner, trader, soldier, sailor...
Rebel galaxy gives you a very, very diverse set of tools to work with, you can tool up for mining with lasers and fault scanners, or you can go full out commodity trader, and the economy is set up enough to actually handle that, with system averages and station histories that actually work properly and can be scanned from out of station across the system, allowing you to set up profitable trade routes back and forth. This can pay off very nicely once you have a high capacity hauler, particularly if that hauler has one of the contraband cargo expansions which means you can facilitate life as a smuggler on the side.

Or you can just blow things up, because explosions are pretty. Blowing things up always work, and there's a terrifying variety of weapons, not just purchasable, but also lootable unique variants which can be discovered in the world, in loot crates or from the hulls of pirate lords, if you feel like converting them to scrap metal.

The pool is wide, but not QUITE as deep as space promises...
Rebel Galaxy offers a -lot- of activities, and offers enough in each activity to have you happily whiling away your time, moreso than Elite Dangerous did (and yes, I know many E;D fans who are going to burn me for that, but it's true), the mining is more sensibly handled due to the tractor beams, the combat is more visceral and less grindy, the trading makes more sense and doesn't require an excel spreadsheet to get the best out of. There's a real economy, and you don't need to be online to get the most out of the game.

There are -two- buts to this rather delicious soup.

One : The factions - They are present, but they're rather bland. More time and depth could have been put into them, faction exclusive ships for each faction would have been glorious, along with modules, as well as faction exclusive bases that you could dock at, along with missions and different reactions based on standing, as well as more complex interrelations between said factions. Right now you basically have only two paths you can follow. If there's anything that could exponentially increase the lifespan of this game - Faction DLC would do it. This would convert a 20-40 hour game to a 200-400 hour game. No joke.

Two : Whilst the activities are good, they all tend to peter out once you get out past the destroyer mark, and the fact you can only hire gunship level mercenaries puts a hard cap on the kind of fights they can throw at you. Hiring capital level mercenaries would have solved this. Again, faction DLC for the win here.

Final thoughts...
Do these two issues stop this game from being anything other than excellent? No. It's still a bloody great game, and for the price point they're charging it's an absolute steal. It does however prevent me from slamming the Essential" badge on
date: because I know that the devs could quite possibly get the Factions some love

reviewText:
This is the most fun that I've had with a spaceship-based combat game since Freelancer and, before that, X-Wing vs Tie Fighter.  I have not beaten it yet, but these are my impressions so far.

The Good:

The PRICE. This game plays like a $60 AAA title.
Fast-paced combat in capital ships that actually includes you piloting instead of just giving commands.
Main storyline makes you want to learn more.
QWERTY controls are downright elegant - I own a controller but have no desire to use it.
No Z-Axis - I understand some people refuse to buy the game for this reason but, not only is it unnecessary, it would also make the game extremely awkward considering the types of ships you're flying. You won't miss it, trust me.
Young game, but so far, almost entirely bug free.
Epic blues soundtrack that changes songs depending on what you're doing in game. Fast music for fights, cruising music for, well, cruising.
The game world feels like Firefly would if it would have had a lot more in-space pewpew and also aliens. Lots of aliens.
Enough ship customization, but not so much that you feel like you need an encyclopedia. (looking at you, EVE)
Bits and pieces of humor throughout.
Graphics are pretty, if not necessarily stunning.
The galaxy is persistent, living, and breathing, and things are happening that have nothing whatsoever to do with you, which can cause interesting results.
The Not-As-Good:
They're not planning on expansions or DLC or anything, last I heard, and there have been zero updates to the game since launch, though that was only 15 days ago. I'd like to think there's a big content patch in the works or something, but I have no evidence for that. The game is, however, absolutely stable, as far as I can tell, so maybe they're just considering it finished. (edit - as of 11/17/15, they have released a small patch)
Running missions to keep your ship powerful enough to take on the next story element might be too reptitive for some, though I'm enjoying it.
Escort missions are still kind of broken. I just did one where my client's destination was to a base that was aggressive to him, presumably because the base was aggressive to me. I don't know any reason a merchant would purposely go to a station whose defenses were going to shred him. On the first attempt, there was also a BIG fleet, and I didn't get credit for the mission because he got blown up. On the second attempt, no fleet, so although the station's defenses opened fire on us both, I got credit for the mission just before the merchant ship exploded. So I looted him and flew off, getting both the merchant's cargo and the pay for the escort. Amusing, but obviously not what the developers intended.
Is this worth your $20? Absolutely. Zero question. Even if you don't particularly like these types of games, the lack of Z-axis might actually do it for you. It makes the game feel a lot less nauseating to those who typically can't handle the extra plane, and eliminates the circling buzzard effect that tends to plague starfighter-based games (Elite: Dangerous, looking at you).

There's something about running straight at a ship three times your size, turning and opening up your cannons and just shredding them that is immensely and uniquely gratifying while some fast-paced, hard-core electric guitar plays on queue, and the pirate-lord screams No...no-no-no-NO!" then blows up
date: leaving behind a rare piece of ship equipment."

reviewText:
No time to read: Very pretty, but very shallow.

Rebel Galaxy gives a great first impression. Great graphics, great soundtrack, great atmosphere. Different weapon types and visceral combat. No-one would blame you if you thought that this was the next Privateer or Freelancer.

But delve into it a bit deeper and you begin to see the hollowness under its pretty exterior. Combat that was fun at the start becomes very repetitive the 20th time you beat the exact same group of pirates using the exact same tactics. There's not much to do in combat either, all of your weapons work on some form of autoaim so you don't even have the challenge of leading your target properly in order to hit them.

The worst part of the combat is how its more attritional than based on maneuver. You'd think that because a lot of the ships' firepower is in their broadsides you can maneuver to 'cross their T' so you can take down targets much larger than you are, but all ships have omnidirectional turrets that make this very hard to do. Instead of fighters trying to get on each other's tail or ships trying to cross each others' T, Rebel Galaxy's ships are more like 2 RTS units shooting at each other: DPS and shielding are king and the effect of maneuver is minimal.

This is made even worse by the way the game tiers its weapons and defenses. The tiers are set up in this game in such a way that its possible to get into a situation where you fight a ship you can never beat (i.e. their shields regenerate faster than you can ever damage them), and your only recourse is to grind money so you can buy the next higher tier of weaponry. It makes the game into one big grind. And the grind takes a LONG time. In the later stages of the game it would take upwards of 20 missions to fully upgrade your ship's weapons, shields and components to the next tier.

The grind also puts the blandness of the procedurally generated universe into stark relief. Once you've seen all the types of stations in the first system, you've seen all the stations in the rest of the game. The only thing that differentiates one station from another is what tier of weapons they sell. There are no special 'capital planets' or 'story planets' like there were in Privateer or Freelancer. There's no sense of exploration as a station of one type in a system is virtually identical to a station of the same type in another system. You won't get the sense of discovery that you get when you first land in the Oxford system in the original Privateer, or when you land on a capital planet in Freelancer.

The main storyline also falters at the very end. Barring the grind, the main quests are interesting enough to get you to the finale. The ending though, is bullpoo. Let's just say that someone leaves for no damn good reason, and you're dumped into the sandbox with very little fanfare. And by the time you finish it, you'd be so tired of the grind that the sandbox would no longer have any appeal.

If you're looking for a Privateer or Freelancer-type game try Starpoint Gemini 2 instead. It's a lot less polished but it has a big enough universe to make discovery interesting, has a tolerable grind and more interesting combat. Or dust off the old joystick and play Independence War 2.

reviewText:
Disclosure: I received an early Beta Copy

Simply put, I love the game. In essence for me it's Freelancer reborn, except with capital ships.

The gameplay is fantastic, although I would strongly recommend a controller. Both the 360 one, and the Steam Controller work brilliantly with the game.

One thing that separates the game from freelancer is the capital ships, and that you use Broadsides for your primary weapons. As such you need to get your sides facing the enemies.
Fear not though, it's still super intense, and you have plenty of other weaponry. Ranging from Secondary fire ones such as EMP Waves, Flak cannons and plenty of turrets.
Turrets are mostly A.I controlled, although you can set priorities for each and every one of them. Such as Fire at Any Craft, Target, Locked Targets only, or even Fighters only.

This means that you can focus all fire on a single enemy, or you can handle the capital ships while your turrets deal with the swarms of enemy fighter and gunships.

It's rather odd at first, but after a while it becomes extremely satisfying. To the point of almost feeling like you're in Battlestar Galactica fending off literal swarms of enemies.

Sadly, you're unable to be a carrier and have your own fighters, although it's not too much of an issue.

The story is very interesting, and it certainly is engaging. Although some story missions have very high requirements and as such you Have to go do other missions to get a better ship and equipment.

This is no issue at all, and extremely fun. You can do a variety of missions, or you can just do pirate bounty hunting. Doing missions however increases or decreases your reputation with various factions. This in turn unlocking newer ship hulls, and equipment.

You're also able to join some guilds, such as the Mercenaries or Merchants which give extra missions and other unique ship hulls.

I would strongly encourage you to find one you like.

Trading is not the most complex of systems, but very manageable, and slightly fun. I've never been much of a trader but each system and station has various prices and requirements. An impoverished station will pay a lot more for food and water than a well set up military one. While some might accept some contraband pirate items; ranging from Narco Cola, to Living Organs.

Ships can also be scanned so be careful carrying contraband, the Militia will scan you and will hail you to explain yourself. If you simply ignore their Hails they will go hostile and attack you. If you want to play with those items, make sure to get a Smuggler's Cargohold; They can't be scanned ;)

Graphics and performance wise the game does extremely well. It's no Star Citizen, but it looks great and runs even better. Now I might have an overkill machine with Two GTX 980Ti's, but playing at 4K with DSR I was topping out at 144FPS which is my monitor's cap, and at worst getting 80fps.
The only slight complaint I have is little lag spikes when phasing in and out of a station. Although this is most likely an engine issue that'll soon be fixed for textures loading in and out.

As for graphical options the game as plenty and they're all adjusted with through the game launcher. It also has 3 graphics APIs to choose from. DirectX 9, DirectX 11 and even OpenGL if you fancy using that.

I unfortunately only have experience running the game in DX11, but it's done exceptionally well.

The last thing I want to mention is the brilliant soundtrack. It's very similar to Borderlands, and I feel it suits the game very well. Personally it gives me a Borderlands and Cowboy Bebop feel to the game and I really enjoy having it on.

In the game launcher however you can also create some custom music options so you can expand it all  if you so desire.

All in all, I simply love the game. I've 40 hours into it, and I've still not finished the main story because I've been having so much fun with everything else. If you enjoyed Freelancer, I would really recommend the game; and for others it's simply a great mini sandbox open Space Action Sim with capital ships.

PC Gameplay 60 FPS

reviewText: If they tried, really tried, to make a Firefly game that nailed it...it would be this game.  It's more like Sid Meier's Pirates in space, or crossed with Freelancer/Privateer, than a traditional space sim.  This is fine because those games were all amazing.  You're piloting a capital ship, not a little fighter, which gives it a different feel.  The combat is extremely satisfying, there are a lot of choices in how you equip your ship, and the universe feels like there are really things going on in it besides what you're doing.\n\nIf you liked Pirates: instabuy, the game systems are similar.  If you like the idea of capital ship scale combat and an open world, also buy.  Firefly fan and like games at all?  Buy.  This is the first space game since Freelancer that I really enjoyed straight out of the box, and it's a steal at its price.

reviewText:
Two dudes got together, drank some energy drinks, and rocked out to Clutch while storyboarding a game.   They needed some fast cash to get their Chevy Nova off the cinder blocks, and had to do it both cheap & good.  They took the basic engine from Torchlight, used it to make a galaxy, and replaced people with spaceships.  They set it to motion with steel guitars, particle effects, and lots of badass.  Rebel Galaxy was born.

Do you want to be a badass outlaw space trucker?  Can you deal with not being able to go up & down, an do barrel rolls in exchange for easy to use controls & fun combat?  Can you tell your OCD tendencies to STFU & just enjoy the content?  Most importantly, do you want to be a badass outlaw space trucker?

Rebel Galaxy:  Malt liquor & unfiltered cigarettes not included.

reviewText:
So here it is-my Rebel Galaxy review. First off some disclosure-I've been following these devs since I started hanging out on the Runic Games forum back in 2009 and have gotten to know them well enough to be on friendly terms. I helped out with the Torchlight II beta and it's one of the reasons I was given preview keys back in May and early October.

All that said I'll do my best to be impartial here.  I'm going to give you my impression of my overall experience. You're mileage may vary. My Tl'dr opinion? I personally love it and am 100 hours in but then this is so many things about space games I love rolled into one. It means I tend to be very forgiving of the flaws my review will be mentioning. OK all that said:

The Setting.

The game goes for a Firefly/Wing Commander:Privateer/Freelancer vibe and does a pretty good job of nailing it down. The solar systems in this game are on the wrong side of the galactic tracks and haven't had a bath in aeons. They're rude, crude and filled with rocks and junk. I've seen it described as 'bikers in space' and it's a fitting description. Rebel Galaxy features an interesting cast of curious characters which is why it's one of the games unfortunate downsides that you never really get to know any of them very well. It's loaded with the kind of wink/nudge humor you'd find in TV series like Farscape or some of the more humorous episodes of Stargate-for example one of the commodities you can trade is called 'Narco-cola' and it is just that. Powerful narcotics in the form of carbonated beverage. If you're a fan of stuff like Hitchhikers Guide to the Galaxy you'll appreciate the humor.

The Story:
Length 30-40 hours (20 if you're an old hand at these kind of games).

It ain't deep but it gets the job done. Like I wrote above the characters all have interesting personalities but those personalities are shallow and you won't interact with any of them very much. It's a shame because they are just interesting enough where I wanted to get to know them more only by the time I got past the 'Hello, nice to meet you, may I help you kill this troup of troublemakers?' bits their role in the story was done.

This becomes even more disappointing by the end of the story. It's a great lead up but the end is a bit of a disappointment. I'll give DDGames credit-despite my not liking how it ended I still want to go through it again. There's one character in particular I really like and I can't help but hope taking a different faction path will open up at least a few new bits of dialogue.

The Sound:
The soundtrack is down & dirty country/rebel/blues rock. If you're into down and dirty southern-fried blues this will be right up your alley. It helps add a lot to the atmosphere and makes you feel like every space station bar serves oil pan shots and barbed wire biscuits. The sound effects are another matter entirely-voiceovers can get a bit repetitive to the point of tediousness at times. Some of the audio isn't mixed well-radio chatter clips/distorts a lot and I don't recommend you use expensive speakers or a subwoofer if you plan on blasting this. In fact don't. I'm hoping some of the audio issues get fixed soon.

Voice acting is pretty stellar for an indie game. This is one of the things that lends a lot of personality to the characters. From what I understand a lot of it was done by the devs themselves (with the help of the always amazing Lani Minella). I dare say it's better than in most Bethesda games I've played. Even though Travis does numerous voices they sound different enough where it's not that much of a drawback.

Ships:
There are 21 playable ships you're able to buy throughout the game. Some of these require money and some require you to build a positive reputation with various factions (pirates, merchants guild etc). Each ship is upgradable with a wide variety of weapons and components. Lasers, missiles, shields, hulls-you can customize your ship to beef them up and match them to your playing style. This wide variety and manner of aquiring and upgrading ships means there's a lot of replay to be squeezed out of the game.

I did find it unfortunate that you're not able to access all ships. Certain ships belonging to certain races seem to be inaccessible which is a real downer in a game that revolves around the very notion of collecting every ship you happen to come across.

Combat:
Combat takes place on a 2-D plane. That means it's more like naval combat in games like Assassin's Creed:Black Flag or Sid Meiers Pirates (the 2004 edition) or the auto combat in Mad Max. Thanks to the variety of components and weapons in game no matter what your playstyle is you can adapt your craft to it. Upgrading certain components helps with your survivability. You can also hire a merc to accompany you which is always a smart move as some of them are extremely lethal. The one down side of using a merc is that you can't upgrade their weapons or ships.

It would have been cool to see something closer to the pets in Torchlight or Companions in Diablo III-especially considering all the weaponry that drops from capital ships. Being able to give my mercs better gear early on would have helped a lot as the best mercs aren't available until late in the game.

The main downside to combat is that difficulty seems to be very imbalanced at the moment. It's a lot of fun don't get me wrong but some missions say they're difficult when they're not and vice versa. It's also pretty spinny. Enemies run but they never run -that- fast or far which  means there will be times when you spend  battles going in circles. That said the effects are glorious and when combat is good it's really, really good.

The other stuff:
Mining-It's a pretty zen-like experience. Cruise up to some rocks, scan them then go up to the ones full of ore. You can buy a fault tracker early on that paints red circles on asteroids that have more than one piece of ore in them. Blow it up that way and you get multiple ores. It's a pretty relaxing experience unfortunately unless you're very good at the market stuff, explore a LOT and very patient you won't be making a ton of credits mining.

Commodities: Stations sell commodities. Buy low/sell high type stuff. Different stations have different events that effect the rest of that systmes econmies. You can also read the in station news boards or ask the bartenders/merchants for info.

Hackable transponders that give tasty info, random cargo containers that contain nice loot (sort of like the outer space version of barrells in an rpg) and rescue missions aplenty are some of the other bits of content you'll find in this game.

SUMMARY:
Rebel Galaxy is a fun, arcadey naval-game-in-space that provides some of the trappings of a space-sim while ditching most of the complexity and time-investment required of more traditional space sims like EVE Online or Elite:Dangerous. It's great for drop in and play for a half hour or so sessions. If you're the kind of person who spends hours playing space games just for the sake of the ambience and love blowing stuff up with enough lights to build a discotechque this will scratch that itch for at least a little while. Personally I'm 100 hours in and haven't gotten bored yet.

Those looking for a deeply engaging story you're not going to find one but the characters have tons of personality and give the setting a very lived in feel-just be ready for the ending to be a bit of a let down. Those into trading should be happy though the game feels like it needs a bit of tweaking since not all professions feel viable. The accent is on combat so expect to blow up a lot of ships if you're looking to be one of the galaxy's richest space truckers.

Despite its flaws this is an impressive first game from Double Damage Games. The developers put a lot of heart into this and it shows. This would have been a solid deal even at $30 but at $20 it's way more than worth it.

reviewText:
Just beat the game and thought I would write a review.  This game is really good and deserves a sequel.  Definitely has a Firefly universe feel to it which says a lot really.  Definitely worth 20 bucks.

Pros - Well designed, awesome soundtrack, great voiceovers.

Cons - A liitle too easy.  I used a merc frigate throughout the whole game, took on whole fleets including super dreadnoughts and the enemy rarely got through my shields.  Using basic common sense is more powerful than a dreadnought it seems.  The ending of the game, while realistic, felt a bit underwhelming to be honest.  The game goes to sandbox only then, but whats the point really..

Conclusion: A really wonderful gem here on Steam.  Without a doubt one of the best space games ever made.  These guys made a solid game and it was worth my 20 bucks easy.  Just hate its over.  Now I hope they make a sequel or another game of this quality.  Thanks.

reviewText:
If you loved Freelancer, Rebel Galaxy is the game you've been waiting for
After playing 40+ hours and not even completing the main story (by choice), this game has content literally for days
the procedural generation manages to be varied enough that you don't feel that you're repeating the same mission over and over.

Heavy customization of ships, 21 playable ships and I've maybe flown half of them, and the ability to customize nearly every aspect of your ship.

Solid trading / economy engine, merchants guild faction that specializes in trade, Space truck to your hearts content.

Did I mention broadside combat
Pull up alongside a menacing dreadnaught and unleash hell with up to 20 broadsides, and watch their hull melt before the glow of your might cannons.

Solid dialog engine, reminiscent of Freelancer, new in this system the barkeep my have some tips for you, looking for your next score slip the bartender some credits and he may let you in on some secrets. need some help elbow up to the local mercenary, talk shop or hire them to be your wingman.

I can't speak highly enough of this game. look forward to seeing this franchise continue into the future.

reviewText:
TL;DR
It's fun, simple, and (10/21/15) on sale. Go ahead, buy it. It's not Elite, it's not X3TC, it's not Eve and that's ok. Single player, good Xbox controller controls, lots of things to shoot at.

Good:
Lots of space, without tons of jumpgates/load screens
Simple controls that work well with a Xbox controller
Story is interesting enough to kill time with, nothing award winning, but it's there, you're there, might as well
When upgrading a ship all of your old equipment just carries over, no having to rebuild your ship

Bad:
Music gets real old, real fast. It sounds great at first, but hearing the same song over and over again for hours gets annoying.
Not alot of loadout choices. There are more ships than weapons (not really, but close)
Best of the best of everything is really expensive and doesn't do that much more than the basic equipment
Can only have 1 ship

Rebel Galaxy is a cautios recommendation. For 20€ it's a good game. It has some major flaws, but I would still call it a good game at the end of the day. I'll try this review in a different format, because this is a game that could have been a hidden gem of the year if developers had a little different focus. So:
What this game should have had First and absolutely foremost: Context. That was SUCH a huge miss. The game provides no context for anything outside of the main quest.
Missions and systems have zero context. They are condensed to a marker on the map. No characters to talk to, no multiple ways to complete missions, no multi-staged missions, no consequences. Even faction missions have absolutely no context.
Every trader is one of two possible models, they all have exactly the same lines, regardless of where and how you meet them.
All mercenaries are 5 characters that inexplicably appear in every system on random stations and can't be interacted with beyond Hey

reviewText:
After years and years of personally wishing for new space sims, Starpoint Gemini 2, Elite Dangerous and this game all came out within a year's time.

Of the three games, this one has the glossiest presentation and best-presented story line. This is like Starpoint Gemini 2 in that the perspective is third person because you are controlling capital-ship sized vessels. There are many jobs and sidequests in addition to the story line and different factions that you can side with or against.

Is this a hardcore sim? Absolutely not, but it is fun and combat heavy. Apparently in this galaxy there are hordes of pirates and alien raiders to do battle with...

Recommended if you like flying around the galaxy and lots of explosions.
voteText: 59 of 64 people (92%) found this review helpful 5 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy is a fun, arcadey space game that feels like a mix between Sid Meier's Pirates, Freelancer/WC:Privateer, and Assassin Creed: Black Flag naval boardsides combat combined with a cheesy/awesome Western-Rock soundtrack.

There is a main storyline but you don't really have to follow it that much, you can just go around trading/mining/fighting/exploring, but the meat of the game is in the fighting. Thankfully the fighting is pretty fun. Instead of playing as a fighter or small freighter/gunship like many of these types of open-ended/sandbox space games, you start out in a Corvette and eventually work your way up to larger ships, I believe there is roughly 20 playable ships in all. As has been mentioned, the combat plays something like Assassin's Creed Black Flag ship battles, maneuvering on a 2D plane, with a heavy emphasis on broadsides and positioning. Your ship is outfitted with a main battery of broadside cannons as well as some turrets and secondary weapons (like missile launchers). You can customize the weapons of your ship with stuff like long/short range guns, beam lasers, missile turrets, anti-fighter/missile flak guns, etc etc.

The game is surprisingly colorful and ships explode into big bright fireballs when they die. Its fun. The music, as I've mentioned is cheesey western butt-rock and, IMO, quite nice. However if its not your thing, or if you just get bored of it, the game has an option to put your own music into the game (alongside or replacing the soundtrack). I haven't progressed too far into the main plot, but this doesn't seem like the kind of game most would play for a gripping plot, as its pretty basic so far. Basically your aunt, an (in)famous smuggler and overall space Rogue, sends you a package containing a weird alien artifact and the access codes to one of her old ships and tells you to meet up with her and you go off to get into cool space battles and track her down.

The game is only $20 and so far it seems like a lot of fun for that price.

reviewText:
Wow. I'll admit, I went into this game without much knowledge of it at all... and after the time I've spent with it, I can only say... Rebel Galaxy is totally badass!
However, allow me to explain the basics of the game. Simply, you're a Space Cowboy, living on the edge of the law and banditry. You explore the vastness of space, blasting away pirates or helping them incinerate innocent traders while completing missions and getting rich. You get your own equipment customizable spaceship where you can fire broadsides, flak, missiles and all sorts of vaporizing goodness. There are even quite a few ships that you can purchase should you gain enough money. The concept is simple, the gameplay is addicting.
Gameplay Footage:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XfZxrhvyJl8
The game also has an epic sound track of catchy guitar twangs as you blow Space Pirates into nonexistence. The voice acting is also very solid. As if that wasn't good enough, the gameplay is fluid and the controls make sense. While the control isn't as indepth as Space flight sims like Elite: Dangerous, it's more than enough to keep players interested while also keeping the gameplay fast-paced.
All in all, I definitely recommended this game!
voteText: 52 of 62 people (84%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I had a hard time getting into this at first, because it doesn't hold your hand, and I'm a carebear. Then I watched a tutorial on suggestions to get started, what to spend your money on, and that I should rent a mercenary. Then I absolutely started trashing other ships and it was hella fun. The soundtrack is fantastic, the combat is really satisfying, and I love that you can customize your weapon loadouts and ships, depending on what you want to do.

I thought the galaxy was ENORMOUS- zooming out to the map and back into your ship a-la Eve Online gives you a really good perspective of how tiny you are compared to everything else. Then I realized there are like 15 other galaxies and I haven't even gone to the second one yet.

I like the characters so far, particularly aunt Juno. I like that you can work for other factions, and end up being an as$hole pirate, an as$hole military agent, an as$hole smuggler, or an as$hole nice guy.

It's very quest based, so if that's not for you, then you may not like it, but I dig doing quests/bounties and getting money and upgrading my weapons and ship, I find it satisfying.

Really enjoying this game, I feel like the marketing fell through and it hasn't gotten as much attention as it should have.

reviewText:
Aiming to misbehave is not only rewarded but maybe even required to survive in Rebel Galaxy. Your goals are simple in the black, live, make money, and take care of anyone who tries to stop you from doing the other two. To help you is your trusty vessel of death and destruction, which can be armed to the teeth with guns, missiles, hull upgrades, shields, and gods know what. Along the way you will meet some interesting folk whom may or may not have your best interest at heart. While the main campaign does an okay job of expanding the universe. The meat of the game lies in combat, random events, and upgrading your vessel. The game itself is gorgeous, you can almost feel the sizzling heat of your cannons firing. The explosions of missiles rocking across your ship, and satisfaction of watching your enemies explode in a fiery death. All the ships look unique, the weapons have the proper amount of oomph behind them, and the soundtrack is a homage to Firefly. On top of all that sweetness, the game is really easy to get into and start playing. The game really reminds of AC: Black Flags naval combat, just this is in space. Same level of simplicity with more customization in weapons. Now Rebel Galaxy does have its occasional black holes. There are times where repetitive missions come into play and are required for equipment advancement. Lack of cosmetic customization feels like a miss in an outstandingly done game. The games story itself does feel like it could be a bit more exciting as well. Occasionally during combat it does feel odd you can't move up or down in space. Despite these issues, the game is still extremely well made. No bugs ever interrupted my gameplay. As far as replay goes, there are multiple factions to pursue an allegiance with and multiple play styles you can choose from. Be a bounty hunter, cartel member, or trader, the choice is up to you what role you will play in Rebel Galaxy.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/sP2LrtDwiU8
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

reviewText:
Pros
+ The game is massive and from my understanding the systems are randomly generated, so you'll never hit the same systems on a different playthrough. It is probably not as large as other space-sims, however.
+ There's lots of things to do, which checks off most of the traditional space-sim tropes: Mining, Trading, Bounty Hunting to name a few as well as a good variety of side missions which cover your basic 'go to point A and blow stuff up' runs to things like 'Go to station B and run/break a blockade to deliver goods'. I've played for 30+ hours in a game which cost me a third of the amount a AAA game does.
+ The games events and economy, while basic, are a living thing. They'll play out whether you're there or not. If a station is hit by a crime wave, it will remain until someone goes and cleans it up, whether it's you or the AI militia. Trade convoys cross the system and deliver goods, which effects the prices you buy and sell for. If pirates (or you!) happen to cross paths with them on their trip the items will never get there, which may cause their stock to drop and their sell prices to rise.
+ The soundtrack is awesome and makes the game very reminiscent of Firefly. It fits the game incredibly well and makes battles against enemy cap-ships all the sweeter
+ Broadside combat is excellent, and remarkably fun. No longer do you just point at an enemy and click - your shields and armor are seperated in to quadrants and you constantly have to think about the best maneuvers to maximise damage while protecting your vulnerable sides. You can even direct-control the turrets on your ship, as well as deploying flak, EMP's, Mines or missiles.
+ Good variety of ships and weapons. Yeah, they're all cap-ships but that's the name of the game. You're not just some no-name rookie making your name running your fighter from a carrier. You captain corvettes, frigates, destroyers, cruisers and even dreadnaughts fitted out with machine guns, missile launchers, pulse lasers, beam lasers, flak cannons and your beastly broadside weapons.
+ In almost every regard the game is top-notch: the aesthetics are excellent, the controls are excellent, the sound design is immersive, the world is immense and the gameplay is, most importantly, fun.
+ The best custom soundtrack integration I've seen in a recent game, you get to pick which tracks play in combat, stations, while cruising... hell - there's even an option to mix your tracks with the original soundtrack.
+ Piracy pays in this game - one of my favourite pass-times in this game is responding to merchant distress calls with a few tons of high-price cargo in my posession. Save the merchants, sell the cargo to them at a premium and then threaten them to hand back what I just sold them for free. It's a brilliant way of making some extra cash.
+ 1:1 sell ratio on your equipment and ships, so there's never any risk of being stuck with expensive gear you decide you don't like.

Cons:
- Missions can become a little repetative after a while, although if you begin to feel like this you'll realise it's because you've played the game for a decent stretch of time
- Travelling across a system can take a little too long sometimes, even with engine upgrades I'm never feeling like I'm moving fast enough while in warp
- Difficulty can spike without warning, usually when you equip your first bit of next-tier tech: there's a reason even the bartenders tell you to upgrade shields and armor before weapons.
- Voice acting is 'just' OK. The npc voice pool is shallow and some of the emotional delivery is pretty bland.
- The dialogue options really don't serve a purpose. it boils down to 'Option one to be a coward and drop your cargo', 'Option two to politely refuse and lose a faction point', 'Option three to be a badass renegade, 'Option 4 to be a badass renegade and ♥♥♥♥ off this faction' all of which provoke the most pitiful and monotonous responses. If you want to be a badass renegade, be prepared to hear 'I hope you like the cold, Cutter' without an ounce of anger or fear behind it 9/10 times.
- This game could have really benefited from a sort of 'infamy system', which, depending on your net-worth, loadout, faction standing or how much ♥♥♥ you tend to kick provided a little more of an emotional response from your attackers. No matter what you do, say or how many of those pirate jack-offs you just disintegrated, they will always give you the same responses - 'drop your cargo or die', 'no? ok, now you will die'. They even say it if you've literally just wiped out all their health and their ship is about to explode.

- While the soundtrack is awesome, it's short and the tracks cycle every time the situation changes - it's rare you'll hear one all the way through. I don't think there's more than 10 tracks in total and some of those are instrumental versions of the others. It begins to grate a little around the 9 hour mark - thank god for custom soundtracks. The 'Sons of the North' and 'These Savage Lands' Albums by The Black Spiders fit the game incredibly well IMO and have saved me from getting sick of the original soundtrack.
- Once you finish the story, get yourself a dreadnaught and kit it out with 6th Tier tech there isn't really any motivation to continue. The story missions aren't particularly exciting enough to play again so your only goal after that really is to make money that you can't spend on anything. It's unlikely you'll feel motivated enough to commit to a second playthrough due to the 1:1 sell ratio on your equipment. If you have a Blackgate with Mark 6 Beam Turrets, Beam Broadsides and Defense tech then you can literally sell it 1:1, which lets you switch to any other ship you may have missed. The only way to screw yourself out of money late-game is either by trading like an idiot, fighting like an idiot or recruiting mercs who are idiots.

Unsure:
+/- Yes, it's been said countless times: there's no Y axis of movement. However with broadside combat I believe the game is better off for it. This game would be frustrating levels of fiddly control-wise trying to move up and down, while trying to maintain target lock with your broadsides/control lateral movement while aiming your turrets, while trying to line up your secondaries and maneuvre your ship to keep your target on your strongest side.

Summary:
There's a lot more they could have done with the Negotiate" part of the game (they put that part of the tagline in quotations? has no-one else mentioned that?)
date: it can get a little bit same-y and repetative after long stretches and it could do with more ship and loadout options but in the end the game is pure space-cowbow fun. My interest only began to waver at the end when I suddenly realised I had enough money to cover buying everything in the game and completing station missions

voteText: but also no longer pushing me towards any kind of goal. This is
helpfulPercent: however
votesHelpful: over 30 hours in while most AAA titles struggle to hold my interest for more than 8 hours.\n\nIf you love Firefly and the space-sim genre but are put off by the overly-complex nature of some of them then give this a shot

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy is quite simply the best space combat, trade, and free-roam simulator I have played in a long, long time. It's hard to believe that Double Damage managed to achieve what no else (in my experience) has been able to for over 20 years. Make a proper sequel to Wing Commander: Privateer.

Just like the aforementioned Privateer, this game does have a main story, but it doesn't constantly nag at you to follow it. Not that you should ignore the main story mind you; while it's probably not going to win any kind of literary award, it is interesting and decent enough to follow, and I'll leave it at that.

The free roam in this game is an absolute joy. Total freedom. You have an entire sector of star systems to explore, and there's plenty of stuff to seek out. One warning though, while the game is obviously 3D, it is played on a 2D plane. Your ship can't go up or down, only left and right. But honestly, this game is more about fun than realism so I didn't find that much of an issue. You can fly around and collect bounties, mine asteroids, or take missions at any kiosk at any star-base. There are many different factions, and it's not possible to be friends with them all, so choose your missions and targets carefully.

The are lots of ships of different classes and sizes ranging from sleek corvettes to massive dreadnoughts. Plenty of weapons and systems to customize them to your liking too, The combat is explosive and exhilarating and often quite challenging if you get yourself into a pickle. My suggestion in those situations is to turn tail and run. No shame in retreating to lick your wounds. You can always come back and kick butt later.

The controls for this game definitely favour using a controller, as it was obviously designed for it's use. But I did play it with keyboard and mouse just to see how it was and they didn't do too bad a job. Still I recommend using a controller for this game as the combat is so much easier when using one in my honest opinion.

Well that about sums it up. A great space combat simulator that's loads of fun to play. I strongly recommend Rebel Galaxy to any fan of the genre. I suppose I could write more, but I'm dying to get back to the game!

reviewText:
I decided to change my review of this game to offer up points of why the game falls short. I'll summarize this as much as possible. If you want a very short review it is posted below.

The super short review :

6 out of 10 ( Good for fist timers and the younger gaming crowd )

Anyone expecting a game with depth in story line and ship functionality will be disappointed. The story line is predictable, the benefits are minimal, everyone wins gaming.

Would I play this game again? No, probably not unless the developer added many more features and vastly improved the game AI.

The good:

Overall a good looking game.
Runs well, smooth.
No crashes.
Great sound track.
Multiple paths to follow to end game ( Merchant, Pirate, Combat, Miner )

The Bad:

You fly" on a single plane and cannot go up or down. While this is a space game I feel ike I am driving a tank or playing a FPS.

The weapons systems on your ship shoot through your ship most of the time.

It is a race to get Mark 5 / 6 items
date:
you could do without but then you may have a harder times with the game.

You simply follow a simple path to the end game.

There is never a bounty placed on your head for the waves of AI you slaughter

hoursPlayed:
this includes news stories.

Between Story line missions upgrading your ship is essential to completing the next mission you will not know this until you jump in and have a WTF moment.

There is no communication between stations for commodities ( minerals and goods ) thus what you buy for in one place might not be worth anything in another or one system over it is double in price.
You will never know unless you go there.

Ships and ship components are at 100% trade in and up value.  Thus switching out weapon systems is never a loss nor is it better from one place to another.

The AI never recognizes you. Sure while you can slaughter pirates whole sale in the hundreds

reviewText:
The only thing that stands out in Rebel Galaxy is music - a metal take on country genre. Otherwise, it's incredibly bland and nondescript: the galaxy is procedurally generated and so are missions (except story ones which aren't captivating either). The AI is bad, the world doesn't feel alive, NPC behavior is way off (a single bomber trying to rob a fully operational dreadnaught - that's par for the course here).
Basically, it's a grindfest: you pop ships, buy bigger guns, pop bigger ships and so on until you get to top tier equipment. You can't turn the tide in galactic warfare. You can't make friends or even get in the news.

So, in short: if you want a 2D procedurally generated game, play Space Rangers. It holds up well and offers much more nuanced gameplay than this.

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy is a fantastic throwback to games like privateer from my early child hood. Something happens your given a rust bucket from a family member and kicked out into space to do whatever you like. There is a story there if you'd like to explore it, but theres also a very large set of systems for you to get lost in. These systems start easy and quickly ramp up into fleets of doom that look like something out of babylon 5 or a borg invasion.

Graphically the game is very pretty. Each weapon type has its own effects and its easy to tell what your oppents are using once you get familiarized with the types. You'll know when your enemy is shielding himself from your attacks and able to plan accordingly.

Combat is a blast. Its a traditional sailing" broadside system with a bit of a twist. There seems to be 2 types of ships. Broadside focused ships and turret focused ships. Turret ships have weaker broadsides so slightly less punch but they can hit in 360 degrees around their ship. Broadside ships usually have nasty blind spots at the front or back of their ships but if you end up on their sides your going to be sucking vacuum very quickly.

Gameplay is very open. You can do simply the main storyline and just enough side quests to up your combat effectiveness for the next mission or you can join one of the guilds. Partake in trading
hoursPlayed: and evening mining to pay the bills. All of these have their own supporting play styles

Merchentmen calling for help under attack by pirates

and of course the occasionally massive fleet battle from one of the many factions who's decided to take a crack at each other.

All of these features lead to making Rebel Galaxy on of my favorite games for the year and at a price point that is simply mind blowing.

reviewText: Rebel Galaxy has the potential to be a really fun game, it's very smooth, pretty, and fun for a while, it reminded of Sid Meier's Pirates in space to an extent. The hugest problem though is the game's combat pretty much comes down to grinding for money to get gear so you don't instantly get blown out of the sky. There's very little strategy involved, you either have the right gear or you just get ♥♥♥♥ed. AI ships will just EMP you to oblivion so you can't run away (And you basicially have no defense against this whatsoever), they eat through shields and deflectors like crazy, and if your weapons aren't good enough its game over. Combat in the later game just feels like a war of attrition. I think what ties into this is they focused way too much breadth and instead of depth, the game's big but there's not much there. Hopefully they either fix this or just learn from their mistakes for a sequel, because I did have fun for a while, but the lategame ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t just bored me.

REBEL GALAXY IS AWESOMEI am to misbehave... FULL REVIEW[gonewiththewin.com] (gonewiththewin.com)

It's Firefly. It's also Privateer. You know what it reminds me off also? Star Fleet Command the old Interplay games. What it boils down to is that Rebel Galaxy is great fun. An easy recommend, and hours and hours of just blowing things up that does NOT get old.

What is it that you are looking for in a game? Hours of entertainment? That's usually a major defining point if I'm going to drop any kinds of serious cash into a game. Will it invoke emotions? Will it capture my imagination? Does it mechically perform and excel at what it claims to do?

Rebel Galaxy is that and more. It draws serious consideration for game of the year. It delivers in terms of exploration, action, strategic combat, and kickass explosions. Is it perfect? reviewText: You can see that I've given this a thumbs up well okay but let's get the bad parts out of the way first. Right off the bat this game is overrated by people new to the genre, who have had bad experiences with other games in the genre, are impressed by dev team responses in threads, are amazed that it's made by a two-man dev team, and love the soundtrack. New to the genre is self explanatory - it's a great and under used genre that has been a niche for far too long. Bad experiences..well a lot of the games of this ilk are either out dated like the greats Freelancer, DarkStar One, and the whole Privateer series, whilst the X series is notorious for being released in terrible condition and aren't patched to a high standard until usually the 3rd major patch. This doesnt make them any less worthy examples of the genre when they ARE finished but the initial buggyness and headaches tend to make people react so badly that the games are crucified before they even get to that stage. As for dev responses..I've not had one to my queries and even had one deleted from the threads altogether so no brownie points there fanboys. Whilst Double Damage are a two man team it is very rare for small or solo teams to do all the work themselves..they hire part-time fillers for artwork, coding..whatever is needed..I'm sure that's the case here - When was the last time you saw a credits list to ANY game that showed one or two names? The soundtrack IS great with its modern outlaw theme (very similar to some of the music in the Sons of Anarchy T.V. show) but great music alone does not make a game.\nAll this said, it's an accomplished entry FOR THOSE NEW TO THE GENRE who may be put off by something a lot more wide ranging and complex like Elite Dangerous; others may be put off by what can seem dumbed down and simplistic by comparison leaving a somewhat arcadey feel to combat. Regardless of how you feel in that respect it's a decent game that is certainly worth the asking price.

reviewText:

- Well optimized*, no bugs encountered aswell

Cons:

- Extremely simple combat (can be a pro for some, certainly not for me)

reviewText:
Classic space game formula done right.

Summary: If you don't hate naval style combat / movement you need to get this one.

You don't need a lengthy review on this one, trust me. Chances are you've already played other space games and on paper you'll get exactly what you expect: A short story, fighting, trading, smuggling, mining, rescuing, escorting, ship upgrading, new ships to buy, some factions, some solar systems, jumpgates and .. well .. you get the drift.

Originality is not why eventually you'll decide to buy this. Polish and charm is.
Very enjoyable naval-style 2d combat. Easy to get into, few keybindings to remember, requires the correct amount of strategy (aka it never gets boring and it never makes your brain melt).
Opportunistictrading and mining. No need for spreadsheets or noting something down. You'll instantly recognize red prices, stations with famine, mining rushes, market gluts, under siege etc and you'll know when to buy or sell. You'll stop to help traders being attacked by enemies and then sell them high some of your cargo.
Addictive progression system. There's always a new ship, weapon or component to aim for and it will always be addictively close to your budget.
Short, classic, cool story. It won't win an oscar, but the voice acting and general style is pleasing and keeps you mildly hooked. It never limits your sandbox experience though and you'll probably be alternating between sandbox and story.
Style. Lots of it. Very enjoyable and unique slide-guitar firefly-like rock soundtrack and you also get to use your own music for fighting, idle and in-station situations. Very colorful galaxy with cool gameplay-changing nebulas and asteroid fields.
Make no mistake though, this game won't replace elite dangerous or star citizen in your library. You'll probably be alternating between them. One's for the serious long-term thinking space pilot that grinds money and faction influence with his multiplayer buddies and the other one's for the colorful opportunist lone-wolf / firefly / Han Solo experience.

reviewText:
Its unfortunate as the game has so much potential, but in reality is nothing but one big grind.
It basicly goes like this, you do a story mission, then you have to grind for hours doing repetitive missions to gain new gear after which you can do another story mission and have to grind for hours again.
When you finaly get the baddest ship in the system the story progresses to the next system and it all starts over again.

The praised music is nice, but it does get repetitve too when you play for a few hours, its like a cd on repeat all the time.

It also bothers me that this game is clearly made to be played with a controller and not with mouse/keyboard.
Aiming is done with the mouse on a 2d plane, but in all modes but broadside the crosshair snaps on targets so there is very little manual aiming to be done.
You simply select a target and click the mouse to fire the weapons group.
Seeing the crosshairs snap your constantly moving you mouse to try and get it to snap on the target you want it.
On a controller this isnt a problem as you just move the analog stick, but a mouse doesnt move infinite.
Ironicly you cant aim up as everything happens in a 2d plane, but small strike craft do fly over you.

Its also not possible to assign weapon groups, the groups are assigned automaticly by the type of weapon used.
They are ordenance, projectile and beams, its not possible to manualy fire a mixed selection, you can only control one at a time with the number keys, they others are ai controlled.

The game does have allot of good pointers though, the graphics are awesome, the mood is good, its casual and laid back.
AI turret control can be set to your preferences, like shooting only selected or target only small craft.
There is a large selection of ships and weapons to be had, which gives allot of variation in tactics.
The ships are clearly a progression over eachother though, they dont give you room to select multiple ships of a same strength, the next ship in line is always more expensive, and somewhat better than the last, yet requiring a different tactic.

Pro's:
Great graphics
Good mood
Very casual
Great controller support
Somewhat intrigueing story

Cons:
Allot of grinding required
Repetitive missions
Poor mous/keyboard support, fixed mouse ballistic
Weapon groups are fixed, no buttons to fire other weapons than the ones selected

Looking back, i may not have bought this.

reviewText:
Rebel Galax Review



I want to start out with a rough outline of the game. Rebel Galaxy is an action oriented spaceship game. Its NOT a simulator and its NOT a strategy game. The developers last title was Torchlight II and they managed to pack the ARPGs elements into this game as well. Theres loot theres upgrades, lots of ships and all this in a space setting which looks beautifull.

So....action oriented Space game.


Who are you in this game?

You are a young starship captain and you dont start your carreer in a space fighter either. You start out with a frigatte. Sure its small and doesnt have a whole lot to it but its in the capital ship class and thats what all other flyable ships are as well. Capital ships. From the measly frigatte to the mighty dreadnaught. You will curse the bombers, fighters and gunships all around you but you ll never fly them yourself. And why would you? The weapons you have at your disposal are frightening and extremly destructive.

The game drops you in front of a Space station and your campaign" is to find your aunt which vanished and is rumored to ve run into some trouble while following her not-so-white activities. Your ship has all the things you need to set off and start playing but pretty much everything is crap...at first.

Lets be clear about something.....when you "fly" your ship you ll do it on a 2D plane only. No fancy going "up" or "down" with such a large ship. You can only turn left or right and increase or reduce thrust.

On the other hand you are given your hull
date: armor on top and a shield generator to protect yourself from other big ships and small ones alike. In order to defend your newbie hide you have 3 weapon categories with multiple weapon choices in each being your Broadsides
recommended: your secondaries and your turrets. And here is where the game "hooks" you (or not) with its addictive elements. Pretty much every station offers a wide variety of modules in different qualities (starting at Mark 1 going to Mark 6) and in order to being able to buy these lil babies you gonna need a lot of credits. Sadly credits dont come around on their own so you got to chose from a list of activities in order to EARN credits until you can afford the next upgrade.\n\nMining
hoursPlayed: treasure hunting
voteText: bounty hunting
helpfulPercent: guild missions
votesHelpful: cargo missions
votesTotal: combat missions
votesFunny:
escort missions. This game offers a wide variety of things you can do. You ll still do it all on your ship of course but with the right pick of modules you can "specialize" your ship to certain mission types.

Missions vary in difficulty based on your total worth and the opposition you ll encounter. Gear apart "how" you fly has a big impact on your survivability as well which is a nice touch IMO.


The flow of the game.

Your playground is a star system with all its gas clouds
commentsCount: asteroid belts
column16:
planets and other space farers you can encounter. Each system is several AUs big and once you upgrade your engines (seperate module) you ll be able to visit other star systems which makes the whole picture bigger. Star systems offer different tiers of servces and challenges meaning in order to get the higher Mark modules you ll need to switch to different systems which are populated by harder enemies so this is the circle you face in RG. Upgrade to be able to do harder stuff which in turn leads to better upgrades etc.

System to system travel is done via "jump gates" which are an instant switch. In-system you rely on your trusted warp engines to get you from A to B. The whole system is easy to understand and easier to use and it ensures that you can jump into RG for 15-20 minutes at a time and get things done. Yes missions are short affairs but nevertheless they can be engaging and entertaining.


Rebel Galaxy looks lovely. Its overall colorfull and the default music track I would describe as "cowboys in space" but hell....it fits.



Its easy to use and hard to master. Upgrading to a new ship is always a big moment and find myself "itching" wanting to try it out. I dumped a whole lot of hours into this game simply because its FUN. Its not overall realistic and it could use some more complexity but its a cheap title made by 2 people. What you get for your money is AAA material in my book.

I play several saves at the moment because the game allows you to take speific paths which dont go well with other paths so decisions need to be worked on and are really hard to lift once done. For example I have a save where I aligned myself with the pirate factions so most stations fire on sight

column18:
spit on enemy militia destroyers and smuggle with illegal subtsnces to my hearts desire. Also there are some "pirate-only" ships and modules I can aquire this way.

The same is true for a military career. You ll be hunting pirates mostly and will be a respected captain in most corners of the galaxy. Some militia-only ships taunt you in case you are not doing all this out of your heart.

Its kind of a "short" game. You have your storyline which brings you to mid game I d say after that the open game starts which is the whole galaxy with you dumped in the middle. From then on you gonna have to find your own goals sandbox style. Eventually you ll run out of ships to switch and modules to upgrade and will swim in credits. Thats when you ll notice your motivation to drop. Either you drop by from time to time to enjoy a mission or you start over. Apart from the storyline which is always the same you can pick fromseveral different approaches in the game which are all viably.

I certainly dont play as much as I used to anymore but its still fun and to be honest

reviewText: Awesome space sim game with great blues guitar and slide music.  It plays like a simplified version of Elite: Dangerous.  You're a space cowboy on a 2 dimmensional plane but (unlike Elite) you can see all the glorious space surrounding your ship in 3rd person.  I can see this game keeping me entertained for awhile...definitely one to play all the way through.  If you love space sims, but not the complicated nature of sims in general, this game is a good choice.  The game plays very well with an xbox controller.

reviewText: If you enjoyed games like Freelancer when you were little, then this is the game you need in your life.  The controls may seem a bit simplistic going into it, but once you realize how heavily you have to be timing both the broadsides, managing approaches, and using the deflector, the game can become complicated fast. I mainly did merc work, didn't find much need for mining, and within a little while I found myself turning to piracy as well.\n\nThis is a very well rounded game with good graphics, only the odd bug or two, and an amazing soundtrack that had me checking their web page, pretty certain I'd just heard Chris Cornell and Zac Brown going in again. Of course, it wasn't, but the hard rock sound track none the less seals the deal. This game seriously feels like it should have a much higher price tag and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Its a casual smooth action game. Your space ship cannot fly up or down though. Piloting and combat feels a lot like commanding a naval vessle. The designers could easily use the same engine and core data to make a naval game. Its not bad though. Not at all. Once you accept that's how this game is its super cool! Combat is fast paced and intense. Some fights are insane! It delivers with this very well.

I am not far in the campaign but I enjoy what story I have uncovered. Rebel Galaxy shines the most for me with how well it has taken a space simulation idea and turned it into something fast paced. Its married to good action combat and randomly generated missions, events and economy. In a half hour you can have do a hard combat mission, go mining, trade commodities between stations and try to hack into a nav beacon.

This is both a blessing and a curse though because those few things I listed is really all Rebel Glaxy offers. Then again, that's pretty much the core features of a space sim too! The difference is the speed at which you can do things here. Its very drop in and drop out (or log off I mean in this case) gameplay. It is great fun for me as I love the X series. But this is NOT a space sim. Its LIKE a space sim with space sim LIKE elements. Which is cool. The focus here is on the action. And the sweet cowboy-like vibe you get everywhere.

I strongly recomend this title with a 4/5

=======

I would really like the designers to come back and add some more stuff in a patch though. I would welcome a good $10 DLC if it added a generous amount of things too!

reviewText:
A very good space RPG game. A very good one for those who don't have the $$ to spend for Elite:Dangerous, EVE Online or Star Citizen.
The map per star system is quite big with many enemies or allies roaming around.
There are many types of ships to choose on different Stars but they cost quite a lot.
Combat is for me, hard as I have yet to master the shield system.
You can trade with merchants and different station and read the news to see where is the cheapest and highest market.
You can also mine though you will have to sacrifice some of you ships combat parts.
There are plenty of enemies that they mostly travel in groups especially if you bump into a Flagship or a Pirate Lord which basically murdered you.
Music is awesome all the way.
Graphics is beautiful, stunning effects and pretty display on the combat.
You can customize you ship from weapons to armor to system though you can't colour it.
You can hire mercenaries though only 1 and they can really help take away some of the enemies focus from you.

reviewText:
UPDATE:  This review is out of date, so take what I say about the mechanics with a grain of salt.  I will not be playing this to see what has been fixed any time soon.  Seriously, I spent a lot of time and got no real reward for the MASSIVE grind.  I doubt I will ever beat this game.  Like I say below, the reward does not justify the time it takes.

Like some others, I really like a lot about this game but it has some problems.  The kind of problems that caused me to just set the game down, and walk away.  I will start with what I liked.
I liked the: Graphics
Ship design
Combat
Customizing of ship loadouts
Chance to buy items low in one system and sell high in another
Atmosphere\Environments
Ability to add a custom soundtrack  (I used tracks from the Endless Space and Dungeon of The Endless Soundtracks and I liked it better than the normal soundtrack.)   What I did not like:The grind! and lack of variety in objectives - This is the biggest problem for me.  You have to grind a lot to progress, with no real change between the different star systems aside from harder enemies/missions + higher tier gear/ships.  This would not be so bad if there were more to do than the same basic missions repeatedly.
(IMO: I think having some unique things to find around in space could make flying from port to port a bit more fun.  You know, things that add life and history to the universe you have created.  )

Difficulty Spikes - As others have pointed out, there are delivery missions where upon near-arrival to your destination, a ring of fighter ships appear around you.  These ships are quickly reinforced by more ships.  Even with the threat level low, these fighters annihilate your shields and you get picked off pretty quick.  I have had to quit almost every one of these mission due to an absolute inability to get past these ships. (even after upgrading)

Merchants Guild Missions - I had originally planned on focusing my time with the Merchants Guild.  On top of the painful delivery quests, I found the others tedious and boring.  Some require you to purchase a large amount of relatively uncommon items and then deliver them to a certain station.  The amount of time and cargo space required for those missions make them a total waste of time.
This is too bad because I much prefer the idea of playing a merchant/smuggler, and I like the ships they offer as well.  So I switched to the Mercenaries Guild because the missions are more fun and make more sense.
Except rescue missions.
Does anyone else have a huge problem with the rescue missions as well?  Maybe I just suck at those.
TL;DR - You might like this for a while if you love space games.  But, there is a good chance that you will hit a wall where your time spent isn't worth the fun gained.  I really want to recommend this game, but cannot.

In one word: Plateau.

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy is action-packed sci-fi adventure game.
Before you even notice beautiful artwork, textures, models and space, first thing you will love is it's soundtrack and music.
With countless side missions beside main story, lots of hours of fun are guaranteed.

Game is really well optimized that can run 60fps easy even on weaker machines, overall controls are simple enough that beginers wont have trouble starting a game.

Battle mechanism is also a job well done, so even if you get a biggest ship in-game with tons of guns, you can't just jump in combat Rambo style and kill everything, especialy in battles where are bigger ships, a caution is always a must.

Despite a decent ammount of buyable and playable ships with a good variety of upgrades, I find lacking that you cant actualy change the ship colors,hell I dont want my ship to be yellow/green.  ^^

Another con I find is that you actualy can't make your own fleet, you can hire one wingman and thats it. Also there is no crew whatsoever, it would be nice that you can hire crew that will in someway improve your ship stats and effectiveness.

Beside that, I only have words of praise for this game, I can say that it is definitely worth 19,99 with what it has to offer to a player.
It is super fun, it has good quality so I can easy recommend Rebel Galaxy to everyone.

So. Rebel Galaxy.

If you're wondering if Rebel Galaxy is a fun game to get, well, here's three stories to help convince you.

Scenario One: Laughing at Bandits.
I took a mission to pick up a dead drop, pretty simple stuff. Fly to the location, use my tractor beam to pick up a box from the middle of nowhere, and then return it to the station I left from. Simple stuff.

Well, apparently some folks didn't take too kindly to it.

I come under attack from a wave of pirate fighters, but due to their.. ahh.. 'Lack of tactical prowess' they all come in at different points across the ice field. I start burning away, because there's no need for a fight, am I right guys? Besides, I have a small network of flak cannons (Secondary Weapon System), so these fighters can't do crap anyways.

reviewText:
Highly recommended for space pilots, space pirates, and especially, space pilot pirates.

tl;dr:  Firefly with capital ships by a well-credentialed indie developer (i.e, Torchlight).   Elite Dangerous in an arcade, but still mature, setting.

Pros:
+ Great polish in graphics.   Crunchy, but colorful.   Just the right amount of JJ lensflare.
+ Excellent, excellent, excellent sound design.   Audio feedback is excellent.   Soundtrack fits perfectly.
+ Varied ship customization.   Even the starter ship can be outfitted for very, very different roles.
+ Thank you for on-screen button reminders!   For a casual, old fart" gamer... that's huge!   (It's not memory loss... not yet... it's only playing 20 minutes a night)
+ Broadside combat maneuvering is great!   Many "Age of Sail" ship games don't do broadside maneuvering as well as Rebel Galaxy does it.

Cons:
+ Minor Nit:  Some odd UX choices.   Radial menu has most of what you need
recommended: and yet the start menu has even others.\n+ No multiplayer.  Wow
hoursPlayed: would this be fun in a team!  I get that it would be out of scope for this sorte
voteText:
ala Torchlight 1.
+ Another minor nit:  Who are the factions?  Are they important?  Not sure.  A few brief pop-ups when you gain/lose standing might help.

For <$20
