reviewText:
Introduction

Rebel Galaxy is the space swashbuckling brainchild of Double Damage, reminiscing of arcade space games like Freelancer, and is supported by an excellent Firefly-like soundtrack. Unlike most space arcade shooters, the game has no pitch movement, instead opting for travel along a single plane. The main game is set inside a galaxy, although it does feature multiple maps, relatively large in size. Despite its similarities, it does a whole lot of thing in a slightly different manner, from combat style all the way down to the way you travel. What you see is basically a new breed of space arcade gameplay, and very much feels like its own brand of shiny new original IP. Prepare yourself for broadside battles and inter-faction negotiations, along with a whole lot of lighting effects to blind you mid-mining.

Storyline

This game actually has a rather interesting story line, which is something I didn’t expect. Basically I was expecting it to be like Freelancer in most ways, but be lacking in some department or other. Despite my previous disposition, Rebel Galaxy follows a decent storyline. Basically you’ve been sent a message from your old crazy Aunt, who actually turns out to be a swashbuckling badass space-pirate at the age of late 50’s early 60’s. You’re trying to find out where she is, and make some sense of this weird AI you’ve gotten a hold of. Needless to say you get backstabbed and used like no tomorrow, and very often end up murdering the people you started out helping. It’s all a bit up and down, but heavily broken up by side quests and random world events. It’s similar to Freelancer in that you really need to do side quests and random events in order to upgrade your ship between main missions.

Gameplay

Learning Rebel Galaxy initially can be a bit odd. I went in expecting one thing, and discovered it was something different. The key problem is I was expecting something akin to most space arcade titles. I wasn’t far off, but I was enough for the game’s management to throw me a bit. From scanning areas to turrets with AI, that and the fact that despite manual aim there’s still an aim assist – don’t walk into this expecting Freelancer/Freespace/X-Wing. Take portions of a number of space arcade games, and you’ll eventually have a recipe for Rebel Galaxy. The mystification lasted only a short while in fairness, it’s just something new you have to get used to, but once you do it becomes second nature. To clarify, this is a good thing. What we have in Rebel Galaxy is something that feels at least a little bit unique, unique enough for us to be learning something new, while enjoying ourselves at the same time.

I’d like to go on about how much I love this game, so let’s first get the crap out of the way. Two things disappointed me most. First and foremost is the aiming system. AI turrets are awesome, configurable, and there’s a whole bunch of them and they do their job. Manual aim however, felt consistently interrupted. When engaging in broadside battles the game is constantly doing what it thinks is best. I aim the broadsides at a ship, but there’s another smaller ship closer which the game’s AI thinks is a more important target. The catch is my broadside weapons are slow velocity projectiles, and quite frankly I don’t give a damn about that tiny piece of crap. My lasers will take care of it. Instead of simply aiming at the ship I want to kill (which is usually fine in most cases I might add), the auto-aim kicks in and starts shooting broadsides in a direction that is not where you’re pointing. I hate it when a game thinks it knows better than me, and is flat out causing issues for me in intense combat situations. This doesn’t happen all that often, but it’s enough to annoy me a bit. Freelancer had it right. Allow full manual aim, but add aim assist circles to shoot for to shoot ahead of an enemy’s flight path. Auto-aim is just plain interference, because if you want to adjust the game’s target, you have to go into scan mode and switch targets.

This auto-assist comes in a second form, with the game’s speed and travel system. I cannot abide it. I’m sorry, but throttling my sublight speeds and dropping me out of warp at the hint of a sparrow’s fart gets extremely irritating throughout the game. Basically warp can only be engaged when the game says so. Sublight can only be sped up to cruise speeds when the game says so. Give me control of my damn ship’s navigation, and stop farting about like my mother. Nothing has been more infuriating so far than travelling 6000 game-lengths and getting stopped three times between A and B because you skirted around an asteroid field. Freelancer solved it, but adding AI auto-avoidance around objects. You’d occasionally hit stuff and lose some shield, but no problem. Slowing me down, and then further slowing me down to the lowest sublight speeds, forcing me to turn ninety degrees and boost out of an asteroid field is immersion breaking.

Rant over. The rest of the game rocks. This game is not Freelancer. Stop right there. Take all those predispositions out of your head, and prepare to play an all new type of game. Movement is entirely on one plane, but that’s cool. It means you can focus more on your tactical (or woefully haphazard) combat with those big-♥♥♥ broadsides. Turrets have varying types of AI that can be programmed to fire at certain types of targets, and there’s so much variation in weapons it tickles me in all the right places. Combat feels punchy, it looks pretty, and quite frankly simulating space-pirates is an excellent idea. The easiest way to make money is to pick a mission and then do all the randomised events that happen on the way there. There’s tonnes to do, and an enormous solar system to do it in. You might think to yourself that after the first solar system you’re halfway done, but you’re wrong, there’s a tonne more, and each map is as big as the next. Quite simply put there’s an awful lot of content and a lot of sights to see.

Unfortunately I can't fit my entire review in this section.
To read the full review, go to: http://www.nextpowerup.com/articles/rebel-galaxy-review/
To read the performance analysis, go to: http://www.nextpowerup.com/articles/rebel-galaxy-performance-analysis/

reviewText:
( Als je Nederlands bent is hier een review van het spel: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XNmSR6KPTLc )

Double Damage was kind enough to sent us a review copy of this game. We're very impressed with it. It's old school fun in a modern setting. The ships designs remind me very much of the Terran Trade Authority Handbook SPACECRAFT 2000 to 2100AD By Stewart Cowley.

The game is an open world sandbox with 14 galaxies. You fly around in big capital ships, which you can upgrade or trade in for a better/larger one. The ships can mine, collect, transport and fight. Mining is done in astroid fields scattered all over the galaxies. Each galaxy is full of spacestations, belonging to one of the 4 or 5 factions (sorry don't know for sure if it's 4 or 5). At the spacestations you can sell your mined items, but also buy and sell a lot of other commodeties. You can also upgrade and buy ships there, hire mercenaries to support you and select missions you want to play. Factions offer missions there and by doing them you will grow in popularity with them, while loosing popularity with others. The less popular you are with a faction, the more likely they will attack you when you encounter them in space. When you are really unpopular with a faction, they will not allow you to dock at their spacestations. Throughout the game you can gain or loose popularity however you see fit. Missions can be focussed on trading, mining, defending or helping others, smuggling and battling.

The ships are quite cool, all of them have a bit of an 70's - 80's scifi game to them. You can upgrade their strength, equipment, cargo space, weapons and much more. Quite some options available. To make things easy, the ships more one a 2D plane, in a 3D world. This works very well for this game. The act more like a ship then a plain. They have a main engine, sub warp enigne (booster), warp engine and a interstellar warp engine. Weapons consist of turrets and broadside cannons. You can let them fire pretty much automatic, or take control of indivual turrets. Fighting is done like sail ships do, facing sideways and firing away :D

You can fly around anywhere you like and while doing so you will encounter loot, pirates, astroid fields, others in need of assistance and more. This is all aside from the missions you can do. There are also guilds in the game, joining one or more will give you access to special equipment and ships. The ships you can fly in the game range from firefly size ships to battlestart galactica capital ships and beyond.

On top of all this, there's a full story with all kinds of missions and mystery going on. You can focus on the story, do it once in a while or even neglect it completely. Besides the main story, there are a few smaller subplots as well.

The best thing about all of this is the freedom you have. Go anywhere you like, play the way you like. Be a pirate, trader, merchant and so on. Follow a story, neglects, do side mission, explore and so on. Mix it all together. The game is really easy to get into, easy to play and offers all kinds of levels of mission, with a very low risk to a high risk. The further you fly into the universe to more hostile it gets and the more advanced upgrades and ships you discover. Easy to play and to pick, yet offering a good challenge as well. Flying is easy, just like driving a car. Battling is really done awesome, you get the whole star trek, battlestar galactica, star wars feel when doing so. No puny little fighter..... no massive firepower :D

I guess that pretty much covers it, sure I forgot a thing or two. Is it worth it? Yes, without a doubt. The whole concept is done innovative and very well. Everything blends in and just works well together. It's a very welcome break from all the massive space mmo's and all the small spaceship focussed game.

reviewText:
Buy red, sell green. “Economic prosperity and quality education for our children are inexorably linked.” - Jon Huntsman

Rebel Galaxy is a indie developed game best summarized by calling it a space trucking simulator. Think of Elite Dangerous in the ocean. The games combat takes place on more of or less of a two dimensional plane. In the the way that Assassins Creed IV Black Flag naval combat has become a bit of a standard. However fighter ships can go a bit above or below the playing field. Of course there are contingencies that allow you to deal with these inconveniences such as automated scatter turrets that can have a tactical assignments selected while you are trying to focus aiming your broadside hardpoints.

The game has faction warfare that evokes a feeling of Mercenaries. Some factions are needlessly hostile to you to begin with while others can be swayed through favors or pushed away by other actions.

There is no ship customization other than changing hardpoints, shields and deflectors. Or strait up buying a new ship. The game, despite its open nature, has a very linear progression. I see only 2 ways to go. You either become better at killing other ships or pick a frigate that is better at not dying whilst transporting cargo. Essentially be a bounty hunter bent on protecting the citizenry of the known universe. Be a space trucker and keep your nose clean at least in areas controlled by the militia or become space pirate. This is not necessarily a bad thing but in all honesty it feels very shallow and has a feeling (the entire experience) of being a tutorial to Elite Dangerous. Which again is fine, so long as you expect that going in.

There are commodities at each station. In essence you could just play the market to progress and get ahead. There are often events going on like a tech boom or famine where buying low and selling high should be a strait forward affair.

The game features a custom soundtrack option. And no, I don't mean like putting on a playlist from spotify. You actually set up custom pathing. As in, choose from list A for battles, List B for Exploration etc etc.. However the game features an OST that I consider quite superb. Its consists of some amalgam of slide guitar space cowboy jams and 90's grunge. Which feels not to far to removed from the serious/satire ratio that Borderlands possesses.

THE GIST
The game is basically a more friendly version of Elite Dangerous and that's not a bad thing. So long as your expectations are not higher than that it is a very enjoyable game indeed.

reviewText:
This is a review discussing specific points about the game as a comparison for veterans of the genre.
An excellent free roaming space game. Very much a Freelancer for the new generation, featuring Capital class vessels!

THIS GAME IS JUST FINE WITH A KEYBOARD AND MOUSE, DONT LET OTHER REVIEWERS TURN YOU OFF OF IT BECAUSE YOU DONT HAVE A GAMEPAD!

So, in Rebel Galaxy, the value of ALL of the parts you buy for your ship is fully refundable. Including ship chassis. You're free to experiment with new types of loadout at will. No charge for resale at all.

There's a stat in the pause menu that shows your Net Worth, including your ship and all of the parts you have on it, what's in your cargo hold, etc. It's a great way to do a single-player space exploration game.

People complain a LOT about warping taking too long, but I don't find it a problem at all. You can get upgrades to your warp drive that increase the speed dramatically. As for hitting asteroid belts during a warp, you can and SHOULD watch for oncoming nebulae and asteroid fields. You can literally see them coming from a million miles away, and just steer out of the way. Snake around space for a better paralax view, so you can tell whether you're coming up on something big.

Combat is on a 2d plane for capital class vessels, and a 3d plane for fighters and bombers. So, your turrets can hit stuff above and below you depending on their placement, and your side-guns are primarily for hitting the bigger stuff.

There is a surprisingly large number of ships in the game, I'd put my currently seen number at about 20. Each faction has their own set of ships on offer. I particularly like the trade faction's GIGANTIC verticall wall of shipping containers, bristling with turrets and cannons.

When considering your loadout, you spend a lot of time trying to strike a good balance between equipping anti-fighter, anti-cap, anti-shield, or anti-armor. Each turret and cannon has it's own set of attributes, and the jack-of-all-trades stuff is lacking a little in the numbers department. Over all, weapons feel good and balanced between types, with a slight leaning toward Mining Lasers at the start. I found them good for the first system, and switched out to specialized guns later.

The cowboy music aesthetic is nice, very firefly. I ended up turning it off after a few hours of hearing the same four or five tracks, and loaded up a playlist with all the Star Wars music from the original trilogy. Definitely a good choice.

Bounties are very easy to get in to. You can find them at random when flying about by using your PULSE scanner, and waiting for the Bounty Detected!" notice
date: then flying to the nearest enemy group. You can get map icons and waypoints to them by paying a small fee to bartenders at any station.\n\nWhile flying about
recommended: you'll come across lots of other stuff too. Message terminals that you can hack with a simple timed button-puzzle put waypoints on your map marking weapons caches and asteroid belts uncommonly rich in minerals. You can find distress beacons
hoursPlayed: traders or military who are fighting a losing battle and pay you VERY well to save them! You can also find "Pirate Lords" floating around out there. They are elusive and unusually powerful enemies with huge bounties on them.\n\nMissions are the same old cookie cutter

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J5876V8Cq_0

Rebel Galaxy is a story driven space exploration and battle game with a unque style and a firefly-esque feel. Above is a short video of me running through th first half hour or so of the game, below are my thoughts on Rebel Galaxy.

TheHiddenLevels.com was provided a review copy by Double Damage Games and for that we thank them.

The opening soundtrack and just the music in general really gave that space junker, firefly, out in the verse where there is little law and less integrity vibe.. The following gameplay did not let this notion slip away. This is a fantastic western style space traveler and battle game. I was hooked pretty quickly by amazing music and voice acting, the graphics are impressive as well.

I engaged my first enemy and honestly thought I was about to lose my ship when I shot them down just in time, the battles feel tense and while manuvering isn't the focus, you've still got to be crafty. The only thing that was a slight turn off was that other ships I was fighting were able to move on a 3D axis, but of course our ship is not capable of 3D flight. It is a game mechanic so that is the last I'll mention it, becuase the game is supremely fun even without that facet involved.

The ship building and upgrade possibilities are relatively deep, and offer a real variance in experience and gameplay. I really enjoyed the feeling of landing on new planets, talking to folks in smoky dive bars, and running errand / bounties for unsavory space characters. It's a great adventure game and I'll likely be coming back to it often to see what's next in the story.I'd reccomend this one to any fans of space games, especially those where players can outfit ships and fly around a massive galaxy.

Thanks for wathcing and reading, check out www.thehiddenlevels.com for news and reviews!

reviewText:
This game is fun, but don't expect it to be a game you will play for 100+ hours.  It'll last the hardcore main story mission runners about 15-20 hours.  The main storyline seems short.  Most side missions are faction based, but pay well for the time involvement.  Side missions have some variety and are easy to find the location of and execute.  If you like doing side missions and answering every distress call, you can expect 50+ hours of gameplay.

There is a variety of ships each with their own specific stats, but you are more defined by your ship's equipment.  Multiple options for defenses, weapons, and components.  Once you get the largest ship with almost all of the best weapons, the enemies don't really pose a threat and the large dreadnoughts can be melted in under 10 seconds.  Looting is easy and your cargo capacity is upgradable, to a limit.

Controls are easy to use and doesn't require you to learn and use 100 different keys.

The soundtrack is great and is a mix of Rock, country, and blues.  It includes music primarily from guitarist Blues Saraceno (Poison, albeit briefly) and others.

Achievements are easily attainable.  I finished them in 60 hours(all but one at 56), but I probably could have done it much faster if I wasn't meandering.

Graphics are good and have plenty of good effects.  You have many options you can turn off.

Minimum HW requirements are low, so it'll be playable on most people's gaming computers.

There are some things that could be improved if you analyze every aspect of the game.  This is not a sim, expect it to be somewhat arcade like.  The game appears to be aimed at combat and having a good time.  Don't get hung up on the trade system because it needs an overhaul.

Overall, it is a well polished game with good graphics and a good soundtrack.  Buy it for $19.99 and enjoy it.

reviewText:
Think Elite Dangerous, but with naval combat and a good story.
The naval-style combat deters a lot of people, but it actually works quite nicely with the single-plane orbit everything has in every solar system.  That means you can't fly up or down, only left or right.  However, smaller fighter planes and asteroids can fly beneath or above you, requiring your ship's turret placements to be more strategic.
You can trade, mine, steal, join factions, make factions hate you, help people in distress, escort ships, fight every time, flee every time (depending on ship speed).  You can play as good, neutral, or evil, or jump around and do whatever pays the most.

The game allows you to easily put your own music into it.
You can resell every ship or item for 100% retail value.  This means you can test out ships, weapons, defenses, etc. without fear of wasting money.  This is a nice way of getting around the fact that you can only own one ship at a time.

I think this game is definitely worth the price.  As of writing this I have played 32 hours.  I'm not done with the main story line, and I don't think I will be for a while.  There is too much money to be made, and too many ships and ship upgrades to buy.

reviewText:
Its a cool lightweight space sim. Its got good graphics, and the alien voices are pretty cool, especially when they say words you recognize in the subtitles. The music isnt your typical space game ambient or electronica, its a kind of bluesy rock that reminds me of Pandora (Borderlands). Its great.

The weird thing about this game is it looks 3d, but its actually on a 2d plane (no Y-axis). Think a top down space sim like Escape Velocity, Ring Runner, Trancendence or any of those, where you are moving on a 2d plane. But imagine the game has a similar POV as the X series. Its really weird and disorienting to be in front of a station and not be able to dive under it.

Again, let me state that the game is *lightweight*. Not casual, just not as deep as a game like X3. If you love incredibly in-depth games like X3, Eve, or any of those, you will probably find this a bit too shallow.

People just breaking into the space sim genre, or those of you who prefer lighter weight or 2d space sims will probably like this one. For what it is, its done very well.

That lack of a y-axis  is hard to get over though, especially if you've come from a full 3d space sim.

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy, a game developed by two guys in an apartment somewhere.  It has you, the protagonist/antogonist, piloting a myriad of ships on a 2D plane while searing holes through smaller ships buzzing around you.  It's a simple game with beautiful visuals and a non-complex playstyle.  It takes a few minutes to get the controls down, but once that's done, it becomes second nature.

It's the choose your own adventure book of the space World.  Want to be a militia-supporting pilot that tries to do the right thing?  Ok.  Prefer to be a pirate that melts the armor of miners and traders?  Ok.  Want to be a miner or trader?  Ok.  Bounty hunter?  Done.

It has capital ships to fight/pilot, an array of modules/weapons to upgrade and many missions to accept and complete.  There is a propensity for the missions to get shallow, but the combat is fun enough to continue.  The desire for me to have the biggest, baddest ship in the Galaxy continues to drive me.  If I find myself getting a little weary from the missions, I go mine, or trade.  I find myself thinking about how I want to build my next ship.  Do I want an array of beam lasers?  Or do I want to build a missile boat?

The game does have a storyline arc, but I'm not fully through it yet, so it's difficult for me to comment on it.  I am intrigued though, because I want to see where it goes.  Since that's the case, it has sufficiently pulled me in enough for me to continue.

The music is terrific, and the game offers the ability to point toward your own local set of music based on triggers.  Want your collection of dubstep to play during a battle, but have a desire to have your atmospheric collection to drone on when you're just flying around?  Totally doable.

For the price, even at full cost, it's my opinion that the game is worth it.  It's a fun time sink that allows me to drop the why so serious?" facade and just play a fun game involving lasers and explosions while making my own choices."

reviewText:
Early impression is very good. It's a casual game which is a good thing for me considering how time consuming many space based games are. Rebel Galaxy just lets you jump straight in and start having fun.

The attention to detail is one of the most impressive things, most noticably the sound effects and music. Firefly was clearly an inspiration here. Full voice acting is a refreshing change from walls of text in many new space games have used.

If I had any complaints it would be that being 2D does feel a little restrictive, but I get why they did it. This could have been something really special if they made it with PC's in mind instead of consoles (but thats just me still hoping for the utimate PC space game to arrive). Dont let that put you off, it's good fun and well worth the price.

Something to add - I've noticed people complain about being dropped out of warp due to asteroids and debris. That happened to me the first time I played, but then I realized you can steer around them while in warp. It's very easy to see objects coming up in the distance and it hasn't happened since.

reviewText:
So... Rebel Galaxy...
Rebel Galaxy is a game with a space setting that locks you in a 2D plane. You can steer right, you can steer left and that's it. No up, no down, in a game with a space setting, one of the only settings in which you expect full freedom of movement and you're stuck in a 2D plane. This just doesn't make sense to me, why would you make a space game but then handle it as if the player was a ship in the ocean.This was such a disappointment.

I bought this game after I watched the trailers, had a loock at the screenshots, which do look good, and read some of the user reviews. These reviews described this game as a mix of Freelance and Sid Meier's Pirates, games I absolutely love and I go back to play them regularly.

What else can i say about this game?
The graphics are okay, the music is... well I am not a fan of country music, so it's not for me, but that's something you need to decide yourself.
I can't say much about the quests you get or the universe itself, as I only played about 20 minutes and then shut the game down in disappointment.

So in conclusion if you want a very good space game with lots of freedom get Freelancer and if you want a game with naval combat on a 2D plane get Sid Meier's Prates (it's on Steam).
I will refund this game and I hope that if you buy it you will have a better time with it than I did.

reviewText:
I have always been leery of space sims, hearing of the 'horror' stories of EVE online and the sorts. That is, until my friend introduced me to this.

It literally took me five minutes of listening to the soundtrack and watching him play the game for me to get hooked. It was one of the few games on Steam I purchased at full price, and I was not disappointed.

Despite its Indie tag, it doesn't feel like an indie game. The visuals are spectacular, the campaign is entirely voice-acted (even the alien species), and the combat is great.

I don't think I need to explain the plot or setting in detail. You're in space. You're finding ancient ♥♥♥♥. Uhh... Untrustworthy aliens/Australians. That's all you need to know.

This game does the RPG-style building-up of your equipment very well. You start with a dinky little ship with a laser. After you've completed a few missions and/or saved/looted some traders, you can buy better lasers. But wait! Your ship's too small for any more lasers, and you're finding it difficult to deal with pirates/police! Well, now you've got to get a bigger ship that can withstand more damage and wield more lasers. You complete a few missions and save/loot some more traders...

The game gets progressively difficult in a way that takes you out of your comfort zone. You can continue to do missions in your current system where enemies aren't hard to beat, but the reward is significantly smaller than that in more difficult systems. Additionally, you can only get better upgrades to your ship in harder systems. Frequently, you'll find yourself battling against a superior opponent, only to either destroy them or escape at the skin of your teeth.

The difficulty does peak at some point though. Enemies don't seem to get much harder or meatier just as you're able to get MK6 weaponry (last tier), while you can still acquire better ships and better equipment. Once you've got the money to afford a Blackgate ship, the game is practically over.

The trading system is not as powerful as simply completing missions, but I overheard that the trading system used to be busted, allowing players to make millions within an hour by only trading. Either way, you can still make a hefty sum from researching how each 'event' changes commodity prices (such as when a planet/station's at 'War', the price of Ammunition goes up).

If you're looking for a great singleplayer game that'll most likely last your 10-20 hours, this is the perfect game, ESPECIALLY for an Indie game. It's not confusing, combat's satisfying, the soundtrack is rockin', and... just, everything is there.

reviewText: I bought Rebel Galaxy on a whim, and thus far it has been the best impulse buy I've ever made on Steam.  You control a space cruiser flying around the galaxy trading and fighting.  Make money from trading at space stations buying low, selling high, and use the money to upgrade your ship with new weaons, armor, and equipment.  This will allow you to take on pirates (or become a pirate) and loot your fallen enemies.  Trade, fight, loot, upgrade, repeat until you have enough for a bigger ship and repeat the process.  This is much what I imagine Han Solo and Chewbacca did before running into Luke and Ben in Mos Eisley.  Do you want a Han Solo simulator or a Firefly simulator?  This is pretty much it.  I also enjoy the amount of choices the devs chose to throw at the player.  For almost every mission you have multiple options of how to proceed, be it violently or non-violently.  I have yet to see how many of these choices play out, but Rebel Galaxy has made a very good impression in my first few hours of gameplay.

reviewText:
Great space action RPG. As a low priced space game I didn't expect much, but have found this game fun and satisfying.

The world is full with a great variety of things to do. Everywhere you go are distress beacons, asteroid fields, ships to fight. Even while on a mission you constantly run into things to distract and entertain you. There are a huge variety of quests to suit any play style.

The combat is interesting and challenging. The world is 2d and the ships feature big broadside guns, naval combat style.

There are a variety of upgrades that will change the way you play. Broadsides cannons, turrets, missiles, different shield and engine styles.

If I have a single complaint it's the difficulty curve of the main quest. The missions ramp up very steeply and require doing tons of side missions to earn cash for upgrades. While I'm still enjoying myself, it does get a bit grindy.

reviewText:
I've only gotten a few hours into this game, but I'm already loving it. It appears to have the full range of activities in the Freelancer tradition: exploration, trading, mining, and loads of combat. You have faction relations that can go up or down depending on who you do missions for, and there seem to be space ports all over the place to dock at for missions and equipment. I've only barely scratched the surface of the main story, but it's intriguing so far.

Combat seems to be the focal point of the game, and it's really well done. I'm not sure how much more layered it can get, but it's nicely varied so far. You control a capital ship rather than just a fighter, and you seem to have two primary classes of weapons: broadsides and turrets. Broadsides do massive damage, but are slow and can't track fast moving ships. They're great against other capital ships though. Turrets can lock onto targets and tear up small fighters, but they can overheat if you don't give them a break from firing. And the cool thing is, they will automatically fire while you're controlling the broadsides. In addition, you have a thruster boost mechanism that can increase you speed, but which can also be depleted from over use, such that it needs a rest to recharge. On top of that, you can get a deflector add-on which is something like an extra shield that absorbs essentially all incoming damage. When it's up, you can't fire your weapons, and it has limited energy which drains over time or rapidly when it's taking hits.

What all this means in practice is that you've got a lot of systems and energy bars to keep track of, which keeps combat really engaging. It was a tiny bit overwhelming or frustrating initially, but I felt like I got the hang of the essentials within maybe half an hour. At that point, combat was a blast.

I can't say much about the main story, since I've only gotten a couple missions into it, but it seems to revolve around some form of advanced technology and finding a lost relative. Interesting enough that I want to see where it goes. The world feels large and full of activity. Visually, the game is gorgeous, with great effects for all the weaponry, and the music is awesome, a dustry, countrified rock soundtrack that really adds a lot of character to the experience. I love me some electronic music, but this is a nice change of pace that gives the game a distinct personality.

In summary, if you ever played the old Wing Commander games, or Freelancer, or anything similar, you will love this game. It even more closely resembles another game call Nexus: The Jupiter Incident that came out about a decade ago, which had an equally interesting story. I'd say the primary difference with that game is that combat is much more refined and well done here. If you're like me and aren't sure, but crave space adventures, get this game.

reviewText:
This game is great! You'll be able to find a lot of reviews listing its general qualities, so I'll just talk about my experiences with its combat.

Note: This is not a 3D movement dogfight space combat sim,  combat in this game is closer to what you might find in old naval battles

Combat against a mixed enemy fleet is truly a multitasking excercise. You'll be using your boosters to keep yourself alongside larger enemy ships so you can use your broadside cannons, timing your deflector shield uses to block their incoming broadsides/missles, and spamming X button to fire EMP flak at the smaller ships so you can focus on the big target.

I find myself having to think about positioning alot, and having to boost away from larger ships or swarms of small craft while i swing my own ship around because the big hole in my leftside hull cant take it anymore, so i reorient and come in from a new angle.

So far about 50% of my combat has been outside of mission running. You'll often find distress beacons, get tips from bartenders on bounty locations, or just plain run smack into an enemy fleet while warping somewhere else.

Certain missions seem really unbalanced at first, but after refitting to the right weapons or adopting new tactics, suddenly theyre totally manageable.

reviewText:
I love space games. I mean I really LOVE them, alright! I've played so many and been very disappointed. I though the pinacle was HOMEWORLD from back in the day and then they re-released it with better bells and whistles and I never thought there could be a better title. Then my sister sent me this game for a present...and it BLEW MY DAMN MIND!

I slobbered over my keyboard at the sheer epicness of this game. Hours and hours of gameplay and I haven't even scratched the surface!

BEST SOUNDTRACK TO A GAME EVER! And they even let you use your own music plugged directly into the game with their own OST...WHO DOES THAT!?

There is a litteral trade/consumables market that fluctuates like the stock exchange and I've never felt more satisfied from an in game payday than this!

Seriously, if you love space sims (without all the dizzying directional BS)

If you love some broadside pirate-style combat,

If you love going in balls to the wall against impossible odds,

If you want the choice of forging your living as a pirate, privateer, mercenary, or smuggler,

THEN THIS GAME IS FOR YOU!!!

reviewText: I'd call this a light recommendation. There's a great deal of repetitive game play, but I found that for the price it met exactly what I wanted: a space game with some space fights that made me feel like a space ace. The story-line is intriguing, but there are some stoppages as you have to upgrade your ship as you progress or it will not be powerful enough for the missions. Despite the somewhat repetitive nature, there was a certain appeal to finally getting that new ship and whipping the ♥♥♥ of those pirates that took you into hull so many times. Treat this game like it's Gran Turismo, Space Edition, and you'll probably solidly like it as I did. Game is 8/10. EDITED because I forgot to mention, the MUSIC is AWESOME. Totally makes you feel like you're in Firefly. There's only a few different songs, but they are masterfully done and very immersive. Music is 10/10.

Remember Wing Commander Privateer? This is that game taken to the next level.

Arcade style controls that can be played best with a controller? CHECK

Bad-♥♥♥ music while traveling and fighting? CHECK

Bottom Line: This game is what you've been waiting for if you have yearned for a return to Freelancer or Privateer-style games. My social life & marriage has suffered a bit because I can't stop playing. Now that's a good game that keeps you hooked.

9.5/10

reviewText:
I had been looking for a single player space based game that included missions, mining, exploration and ship to ship combat for a long time before I came across Rebel Galaxy. I picked this game up on sale hoping it would provide me with what I had been looking for and was happily satisfied.

You start Rebel Galaxy off in a tiny ship and are quickly thrown into this massive galaxy head first with no real direction and plentiful choices on what to do first, an amazing first impression. After a few hours I found that some of the missions were kind of repetitive so I moved on to a different sector to try a new guild. While the missions did vary there are a lot of fetch quest style side missions that unfortunately did not change as the game progressed.

Rebel Galaxy shows you straight from the start these giant dreadnaught class ships worth $15m+ while you are making a measly $10k a mission. This while great, also lead to a desire to acquire better ships and gear as quickly as possible. The problem with this choice is due to the games difficulty system, which  is never explained. Rebel Galaxy seems to use four mechanics to set difficulty; system rating, mission difficulty and the last two are based on what hull class and gear type you are using. The game only considers your highest individual type of gear to set the difficulty which can lead to some annoying situations where you are severely outclassed by the enemy ships .

These two points should not dissuade you from this game, however. Almost every other aspect was fantastic. The music, while I found not suited to space exploration, was great and has been well received by the community . The ship types and styles all were unique and looked great while offering a variety of build possibilities and attack styles. The weight and feel of the ships during combat and the combat itself.

The battles at the core of the game can be amazingly chaotic, the large varieties of ships / builds with different amounts of each in a fleet can lead to some of the biggest fights you have ever been in. I went into a great number of battles ridiculously outnumbered and when surviving in the final moments after a tense and carefully executed fight,  let out a profanity or cheer due to the satisfaction of these sometimes epic encounters.

Overall this game scratched an itch that I've had for years that nothing has come close to. For the price and the amount of time you can get out of this game I couldn't recommend it enough.

reviewText: The soundtrack makes this probably the best Firefly game we'll ever get, but if - after a dozen hours have you memorized every note of the included tracks - you throw in the right custom soundtrack it pretty much covers Cowboy Bebop as well. Mechanics-wise this is basically Freelancer 2, except with far better 2D naval combat, randomized systems and sectors, far less loadscreen" traveling (instead you free-form warp and dodge obstacles and it usually takes 40-60 seconds) and the endgame is you piloting gigantic behemoths with dozens of automated turrets in gigantic battles with up to a hundred ships.\n\nThe variety of mission types for the generated missions is reasonable but limited
date: so it's up to yourself to pick the type you enjoy (pro-tip: escort missions usually pay that much for a reason) and to get the insane(ly expensive) gear you'll need need to either batch a few dozen missions or - much more exciting - pick the contracts that the game deems far too hard for you and play smart (and hope for the best). So that's both difficulty selection and clever risk-reward choice to let you pick the pace you enjoy.\n\nThere are definitely a number of systems that feel functional yet rudimentary that i'd like to see expanded for a sequel
recommended: but this delivered everything i always thought i wanted from the larger space games like Elite or EVE (ha) or that other sad joke in a much more condensed and enjoyable package.\n"

reviewText:
This game has the understanding that many of the more recent space sims do not, namely that a living world creates immersion and that the major component for creating a living world consists of real voices, simulating communication with the player, and a vibrant AI system. Add to it some hearty music and Rebel Galaxy feels warm and alive, unlike its much more expensive predecessors.

The main gameplay feature that sets this space sim apart from all others is that the battle happens with Black Flag type naval combat, where the ship stays on a flat plain and fires cannons from the sides.


Pro's:

Good flow: you complete missions, scavenge ships, buy upgrades, move to more dangerous areas, buy better ships, help out allies, do more missions, etc. It gets addicting.

Dynamic unbalanced world: I once came across an enemy capital ship in a low-difficulty space that annihilated two militia capital ships and was clearly overpowered for the area. Another time, I came across a giant pirate armada next to a planet. Yet another time, the mission was labeled hard but turns out to be super easy if you are fast enough. Maybe these are all bugs, but they make the game feel more dynamic and realistic.

Music: slide guitar rock is great. I bought the songs before the game even came out.

Combat is fun. Lots of ships flying all over in the colourful chaos of battle.

Customizable fighting styles: Buy a fast ship or a slow mammoth; long range torpedo boat or point-blank cannon. You decide.

Good value for your money.


Cons:

Saving behavior. At the time of this review, the game saves whenever you quit the game or at a station and there is only one save. This means: 1. you cannot load a previous game if you mess up and 2. if anything happens to your save, you are screwed. This means you have less freedom to experiment. I have yet to find a game where the checkpoint system did not annoy me.

Flat space: While the naval combat system does work, part of what I love about space sims so much is the freedom to fly anywhere and by restricting the movement to a plain you are cutting at the core of what is interesting about space sims.

Trading system is mediocre: You can buy low by paying attention to the news and then sell high but it is nowhere near as profitable as doing even the easiest of the combat missions and just does not work very well.

In time, a few annoying bugs did reveal themselves, though nothing gamebreaking.

reviewText:
This game brings to mind a delicious combination of Battlestar Galactica, Star Trek, Spaghetti Westerns, Wild West Novels, the Imperial Navy from Warhammer 40,000, and Battlefleet Gothic. But I'll be sure to be more cohesive at this point.

Firstly, the music is great. As in, bloody fantastic, perfect, chill-inducingly delectable. It makes me so happy to hear a westernized form of country again, even if it is more modern. It practically makes me weep with joy and happiness. The music guides you along a beautiful path of twisted flaming wreckage and bloody gorepiles in space of the helpless rended limb from limb by a cascade from your turret networks. Truly, it makes me nearly froth with inarticulate rage and glory, my blood flowing in great cascades from my eyelids to hear this music. I would rate it a 7/10 or even 8/10 if I am particularly in the moment.

Next we have the gameplay, an enormous bulky monster that growls across the scarred membranes of your cerebral cortex. First of all, it is weighty. I feel as if I am a space marine interred in a mighty dreadnaught of the God Emperor of the Mandkind whenever I go into warp, barreling on to my inevitable destination and perhaps description. Secondly, the combat makes my eyes burn with the dancing hatred of a thousand devils, shewn from the eternal Blood War by a great swathe of undead demons lead by Orcus himself. I revel in the heinous and most deliciously extensive.  The pound of my ordnance and turretry as I combat the vile hordes of heretics and pirate scum makes me giggle as a mentally deranged serial killer escaped from Alcatraz. Truly, this game excels in its gameplay.

Finally, as I must say, the westernized feel bleeds over heavily into the characters, making for interesting dialogue and contact with either unknown xeno scum or unwashed and mangy of hide baffoons. As the clink of aged coin, illicit goods, or untold amounts of credits flow from my scabrous hands as we exchange evil pleasantries and oafish camaraderie. I can do nothing but appreciate this.

I recommend this game highly my battle brothers, my dark souled companions, my vicious murderers and my fellow hiver scum.  You will do no better on this day if you seek endless battle, horrific suffering, and countless bouts of larcency, lies, and lack of litigious action.

“The past shall consume the future, the dead shall consume the living, and chaos shall reign supreme!”
--- Unicron

reviewText:
Main storyline (with a few side missions) took about 40 hours. It's more arcade than sim, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.

This game is greater than the sum of its' parts. Graphics are nice to look at but not the best I've seen. Combat is satisfying despite occasional glitchiness. Storyline is a little predicable but the characters are interesting and the voice acting (for the most part) is pretty good.

Despite these minor annoyances, this game is, hands down, the most fun thing I've played this year.

On top of that, it's got the best sound track for a game that I've heard in a very, very long time.

It's inspired by the Firefly TV show and really does a great job of capturing the look, feel and character of the 'verse.

Even at it's regular price, it's worth the time and money. Do yourself a favour and DON'T miss out on this one!

reviewText:
This is my first review in Steam :) I hope it would be helpful for you.

I played for 45 hours and I definitely give thumbs up to this game. If you are a fan of Firefly, and if you like Star Trek - Star Wars style space combat, this game is for you. Although not being a masterpiece; the game has a nice atmosphere, wonderful music and sound effects, flashy explosions and lasers, detailed unique ship designs, in short: it has a %85 healthy body and mechanics.

Pros & Cons:

- The depth of space looks nice, however the colours are mostly vivid mostly and too luminous for space. Though it's less depressing :))

- Warp and Jump concepts are very nice.

- Thumbs up for weird aliens, their creative languages and weird ships (gets weirder further you play the main mission :)

- The game lacks of citizens living wandering around when you visit a station. When you visit a bar, you can only have the bartender and your hired gun, which is so unrealistic.

-Diplomacy needs to be worked on some more. And yes, I agree with the other guy: developers need to put a reputation" system inside the game. When a guy destroys 100 capital ships and some 500 fighters
date: weaker enemies should run away from you on sight
recommended:
or at least try ;) There is a "Hail-dialogue" system in game. Little bit impractical. You can choose to intimidate your enemy which I succeded several times. Still nobody says "Oh noo! it's the guy who eats destroyers in breakfast! We frakking need to disappear right now!"

- After 30 hours repeated side missions decrease the fun. Fortunately the main quest saves it from boredom.

-  The turret manual targeting sucks
hoursPlayed: it's pretty hard to choose your target in real time combat. You can of course "tab" and lock your target but I don't like wasting my time when i have 20 meteorites to hit around me (yeah you can do mining and sell the ore you extract)\n\n- You have many options to outfit your ship with deflectors
voteText: shields
helpfulPercent: rockets
votesHelpful: lasers and such and especially with useful components. The turret's locations are important
votesTotal: nevertheless you can't just drag and drop your weaponry on the ship as you like. You will need to know by trial and error which turret is which and install-uninstall the weapons until you find the right one (I have 8 turrets on my ship for instance).\n\nThat's it for now :)"

reviewText: Rebel Galaxy from Double Damage Games is the space shooter for the fans of Joss Whedon's Firefly who thought the writing and characters were too complex. reviewText: Bought this game during a down period in my Space Engineers saga (that game is currently being prepared for the planets release and is chock-full of truly annoying bugs) and didn't expect to enjoy it so much. It's no Hearts of Iron III in terms of complexity but, heck, sometimes you just want to watch pretty explosions and feel like a space cowboy, right ? On this front, Rebel Galaxy delivers in spades. It's got more personality than a Hell's Angels clubhouse and the looks of that blonde cheerleader you lusted after in high school. I've read somewhere that it was made by two guys. If that's true, that's pretty amazing. Massive overachievers, they.\n\nI bought it about 10 days after release and have yet to encounter any significant bug. Sure, I would have liked a bit more depth in the missions, perhaps some RPG elements, or a touch of strategy but it would be a national politician-level lie to say that I didn't get my twenty bucks' worth of entertainment out of it. Well done devs, you've made me happy.

reviewText:
So I finally beat the main story and every single minute of it was fun. Early on when I started following this game they said it was a mix of Freelancer/Privateer + AC:Black Flag + Sid Meier's Pirates! + Star Control 2 and that is a very apt description.

As a kid I really loved Freelancer. Exploring a large system on my own, outfitting and upgrading my ship, taking missions from various factions, etc. This scratches that itch like no other since Freelancer. While I hope Elite: Dangerous and Star Citizen will be able to get there they seem far too focused on the multiplayer experience.

If you loved Freelancer and enjoyed AC: Black Flag's combat this is the game for you.

Pros:
Fun Combat
Nice story that doesn't over stay it's welcome
Plenty of ships
Lot's of options for ship customization

Cons:
Pirate story not as deep as I'd hoped
I wish there more varied random events in systems like wormholes

reviewText:
A boy has the right to dream...
...there are endless possibilities stretched out before him.

Rebel Galaxy takes the classic free-form, open-world space sim a la Darkstar One, gives it amazing, brutal, fast, exciting combat, adds a strategic economy with stock market-esque line graphs, a bunch of well designed, fun-to-fly ships, pumps in some grungy western blues rock, and then throws you into the middle of your favorite outlaw studded sci-fi show. We're talking Outlaw Star, Firefly, Dark Matter, Battlestar Galactica, etc.

I was initially sold on the soundtrack alone (seriously, just watch the first trailer and you'll know what I mean). I thought I would lament the loss of a Z axis in flight/combat, but because of playing on a flat plane, it plays very similar to Assassin's Creed Black Flag's ship-to-ship combat, and as such it's very smooth, easy to grasp, and fun.

Pros:
+ Excellent Soundtrack
+ If you don't like the soundtrack, or want to add your own flair, the soundtrack can easily be replaced with your own music, separated by category (idle spacefaring, combat, space station), and your own music can be played along with the included soundtrack
+ Smooth combat
+ Lots of spacecraft
+ Well made stock market style economy
+ Planetary events add strategic value to trading
+ Feels like you're right inside the Outlaw Star or Firefly universe
+ Later fights are challenging, but fun
+ Warping between planets is very relaxing
+ Space is big. Each solar system is pretty massive, so expect to warp a lot
+ Inside jokes and references to other sci-fi media is plentiful

Cons:
- A bit grindy, especially early on
- Missions are fairly repetetive
- Some later fights can be brutal
- Losing a big battle means going back to the last station you docked at. Dock often
- No piloting small fighter craft


8/10 Would soar like a leaf on the wind
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to sit in the captain’s chair of an all-powerful dreadnought with enough firepower to evaporate a fleet of foes? Then this might just be the game for you.

In Rebel Galaxy you take reigns of a huge ship and carve your own path through a randomly generated quadrant of space. You can choose the path of a hero and save those you meet from a vast array of pirates and rogues. Or you can fall prey to greed and debauchery, siding with the Red Devil Cartel and carve your way through every enemy that stands before you.

But that being said you could choose to do neither. There is always the option to be a humble miner and strike it rich in one of the vast amounts of asteroid belts and nebulae that litter the universe. Or perhaps the life of a trader is more up your alley, with a huge amount of commodities and a living breathing market place that varies from station to station and can be influenced by every day events the choice is yours.

The game looks great, it may not be the most stunning graphics available today but I loved how it looked. The ships have super details models, the stars and planets were a joy to look at. The battle effects were bombastic and colourful. Every shot from my huge broad side barrage lit up the night sky as it ripped through the hull of my enemies.

The audio is fantastic too. The music chosen for the sound track really adds to the title; each song filled with a defiance that really gets the heart racing and only adds to the reminiscence of Firefly or so many spaghetti westerns that said screw you to the man. The sounds were great as well, the whirring up to using your warp drive or the blasting sounds of laser-fire as it rips through shields and hull alike. The only let down is some of the voice acting was not stellar, but what’s there is good enough to convey the story.

Speaking of which the story serves only one purpose, to convey your ship from one star system to the next. Most of the adventure in this title is not from the main plot but from the tales you form yourself. Taking on a trade mission and getting ambushed in a system that is far beyond your ships abilities, warping in to help a trader being pirated by xeno scum or the joy of stumbling upon a fleet of pirates and having them throw your offer of surrender back in your face and blasting them to dust as punishment. The main plot is not bad by any means but the game is so much more.

Now gameplay, there are so many facets that it would be impossible to go through them all. The main game is either menu-based, exploration or combat. The menus are as expected. But the meat of the game is its exploration, so much to see and do and the ship controls fantastically. The one drawback is turning speed; the manoeuvrability of the larger ships is very slow and can make tight turns laborious. Combat on the other hand is snappy and fast and only hindered by turning speed. But since a lot of your turrets autofire you feel like a god when your ship can decimate everything in its path on its own and when finally you bring the broadsides to bear its goodnight to whomever you are aiming at.

The ships themselves are fully customizable. From engines to weapons, turrets to warp drives, even the size of your cargo hold, everything can be modified, changed and improved. Starting with the most basic of equipment you soon build a ship Mal Reynolds would be proud to call his own. From the tiniest corvette all the way to the mightiest of destroyers each has its own quirks and I enjoyed playing all of them.

This game is phenomenal and will have you enraptured for hours. Some people may feel it’s a little slow to begin with or the combat is a little tricky with slow aiming, but if you can get past all that it’s a real gem and I had a whale of a time with it. Plus at full price it is still cheap I would recommend buying this all day any day sale or no.

Have Fun ^_^

reviewText:
I've been a fan and follower of just about every space game out there ever since Star Trek played on the TRS-80 back in 1980. On and off of Steam I've bought and tried most of the Elite-type, x4 style, in cockpit, top-down, you name it... I've tried and played it. Not many have been as fun to play as rewarding and smooth as Rebel Galaxy... in fact I'd say only one other game comes close... But Rebel Galaxy takes my vote for sure!

I look forward to seeing if and when this game gets modded, where it can be taken... It'll be a fun ride for sure.

If you enjoyed Privateer, Elite, Freelancer, X-Terran Conflict, Wing Commander and similar... You're sure to love Rebel Galaxy. I haven't even left the first star system yet there's SO MUCH to do! I'm in my second ship, but with all the upgrades, addons and captured hardware my tier 2 ship can handle some pretty bad-A ships.

I am truly enjoying the experience!! I give it 8 out of 10 stars. Why two stars less? I would have liked to have been able to build my own starbase or home base. And possibly have planetary landing and exploration... Hopefully in future addons or DLC's... who knows. ;)

This game has blown me away. Everything from the theme down to the actual gameplay. I love the music and the look and feel of the game. Really captures that same theme that things like Firefly managed to capture.

My main concern when going into this game was knowing that it didnt have full free range 3d movement. You are basically a boat, on a 2d ocean that spans in all directions. (ie: you cant go up or down like in most space sims). Shortly after playing though I realized something. You arent a space pilot in some action game. You are more like a bridge commander. reviewText:
Tl/dr: It is a really fun and nice game from some Indie developers, and while there are some bugs and exploit possibilites in the game, the devs throw patchs from day to day, so in a short time I'm sure they will be all gone. It is definetly worth its price, for 20 bucks you get 20+ hours of fun, far better than a cinema!
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The gameplay is simple, but if you got the vibe of it, it's hard to stop playing. It's not a space-sim, but a more arcade-ish game with a very strong atmosphere. catchy soundtrack (which you can extend/replace with your own music from your hard drive if it's not your style), Beatiful skyboxes, plenty and mesmerizing explosions, laser projectiels and engine trails.

The combat is really fun, you have to position well so you can fire with your main weapons on the side of the ship. It might be a bit challenging first but as soon as you learn the tricks and how to sail in the blins spot of the other ships, it becomes much easier, but stays as fun as in the begining. there is no better feeling when you destroy a ship 3-4 times bigger than yours on your own.

The controls are made for controlers mainly, and many people say that keyboard+mouse is bad, but personally i had no problem with it, only when you aim with the turrets, the camera can stick to strange places, but it doesn't matter as they will be on auto fire 80% of the time, while you ahndle the broadside guns.

The story mission is a bit short and simple, and sadly many characters get only a little screen time. But the dialoges are really well written. Overall if you rush the game it can be finished pretty quickly(possible evein in 5-10 hours, but if you fiddle around it can last up to 25-30 hours! it took me around 20 hours to finish the main story [while i did plenty of sandbox stuff] and other 3 hours to get tthe best stuff in the game.), but even if you get the best weapons and defensises on your favorit ship, the combat is still fun and you can spend a hour easily to blast some poor souls into the space.

reviewText:
Been immersed recently in Rebel Galaxy, though the game lacks the ability to move up and down, it makes up for it in the following ways.

1- The Music is perfect, every time I go into space combat in EVE or STO or any other space game; Star Citizen, Elite, etc. I always have to patch into Pandora and set some rock and roll or techno. This is the first space game I never touch Pandora in, the music is perfect for the combat and for the moment.

2- The variation of ships for a game at this price point makes me wonder why its not more expensive. To me this game's value would have to be set at 39.99 or 49.99. I have seen games at a 60 dollar price point that has less content and less hours of gameplay than this. Everything from frigates to Dreadnoughts are in the game with unique and epic designs to be found in each one.

3- The Story for me is actually interesting, without making any spoilers, I am very interested to see whats next. While doing these missions it reminds me of firefly pulling into a space station and checking the mission board for any missions I can make a few credits on. Get some munitions or better weapons.

4- The graphics are quite good, the explosions are beautiful the weapon designs are stunning. Coming from someone who is an avid player for Star Citizen, to say I'm actually quite pleased with the graphics of this game speaks a lot for itself.

5- Some may not see this as a plus, but you cant just get carried away in combat, not paying attention to your shields, not using your deflector shield and rotating your ship can lead to some frustrating moments when you see your ship explode from damage. I got so into the combat that I didn't realize my ship was taking critical damage and suddenly... BOOOOOM SPOOOSH BAWWW.

Only negative I see for this game is the lack of 3 dimensional movement. However I have played games that don't have a jump function and they are amazing. The guys who developed this game did an astounding job making it, and it is a must have in anyone's game library that even remotely likes space ships.
my rating is a 9.5/10

reviewText:
I have loved the space game genre since I was 8 years old. The fact that I am recommending this means that out of the 95% of released space sim titles I have played to death, Rebel Galaxy manages to stand out a cut above many of them. I am not even a quarterway finished with the main storyline, yet 10 hours in, the amount of content is quite impressive, and makes gameplay enjoyable to say the least.

First and foremost, this is a third person spaceship simulator. There is no empire building or 4X gameplay involved.

You primarily fight, trade and explore in Rebel Galaxy, and start off doing the main campaign which you can deviate from at anytime. Of course the campaign has you flying around a little bit to do other things, but fighting is usually involved. Wonderful thing here is though, interactions with NPCs in the campaign and in general allow for non-violent alternatives to do a mission, or, for instance, to handle a pirating attempt or an illegal cargo inspection by system militia.

There are about a dozen solar systems in Rebel Galaxy, so you are given some wiggle room to move around. Content such as missions, NPC spawns, and solar system events are randomly generated. There is enough variety to keep things from going stale, and as you get farther away from your starting solar system, more content (ships, equipment, guild allegiances) is available to you.

Combat is a bit different in Rebel Galaxy. And your ship's motion is limited to 2D movement only (while fightercraft and the environment objects can have 3D motions and positions). I will seperate this into two parts. Offensive capabilities and Defensive capabilities.

Offensive capabilities
Includes 1) A primary weapon 2) A secondary weapon 3) Turret systems 4) Mercenaries 5) Deflectors.
Primary weapons can be either pulse laser types or beam laser types. You fire broadsides (i.e from the side) at the enemies on either side. Very powerful, and include a small charging time for an auto-aim accuracy bonus.
Secondary weapons are either mines or missiles (point & shoot or seeking). Good damage.
Turret systems can be either pulse or laser types. You can take control of your turret groups (1 at a time only) and fire at enemies in a 360 degree arc. Critical against fightercraft and provide good sustaining damage against larger craft.
Mercenaries are fightercraft/gunships that follow you around for a 1 time fee. They are very durable, are good fodder, and you can only have 1 with you at any time.
Deflectors are a sort of temporary shield you can activate which absorb damage. You can also ram enemy ships with them to inflict damage.
Defensive capabilities
Include 1) Deflectors 2) Shields 3) Armor 4) Hull 5) Engine boosters
As mentioned, Deflectors are temporary shields that asborb damage until you run out of charge, in which case you must wait for them to have charge in order to use them.
Shields are divided into 4 sections that protect your ship (front, port, starboard, aft) from all damage and collisions.
Armor protects your ship's hull. Damage to armor can damage to ship systems.
Hull is your powercore. If it goes to 0, you die.
Engine boosters can be used to maneuver weapons fire, outrun missiles, outrun foes, and kite enemies.
Combat aside, the graphics are very nice and well optimized. Also, the soundtrack is wonderful, it reminds me of Firefly.

As with any game, there is a bit of a grind involved to gain credits in order to unlock higher tiered ships and equipment. Best way to go about this is doing a bunch of high paying missions (mission payouts generally increase as your overall strength increases) alongside a storyline mission once in a while. Or however you want. Imo the grind doesn't feel like a grind sometimes. It's pretty fun to blow ♥♥♥♥ up.

All in all, I dig it. Combat is different, not shallow. Plenty of content. Good soundtrack. Solid mechanics.  Decent plot. Way to go Double Damage Games. I hope you keep making titles in this genre!

reviewText:
Charming, if limited, arcade game written by the creator of Torchlight.

Whilst it really isn't anything special, Rebel Galaxy enjoys a level of charm not often seen in the modern gaming world. From the sci-fi western setting to the naval-esque space combat, Rebel Galaxy takes a lot of smart-but-simple game mechanics and throws them together in one thoroughly enjoyable and deceptivel moreish space romp.

Whilst it will feel familiar to both fans of games such as the X series as well as hardened ARPG players, both will see where the limits shine: from the limited dimensions of space combat to the under-developed item metagame, Rebel Galaxy is very much a jack of many (if not all) trades, but a master of none.

reviewText:
I bought this in a previous 50% sale and would say that at this price it is definitely worth it however after having played it (and finding it hard to put it down each time) I think I would have paid full price too!

As many reviews have already stated this game is like the love child of Sid Meier's Pirates and Freelancer, it's neither one or the other but has emulated some of the features from both games and merged these into an interesting hybrid.

The 2D naval style fighting makes it less complicated than a 3D counterpart but don't let that fool you that it's less of a challenge. The variety of ships, weapons and modules give it enough diversity to keep you playing for that next upgrade but without bombarding you with sheets of complicated stats. The soundtrack isn't going to be everyone's taste but I think it's awesome and really suits the pace of the game.

Yes it's a bit clichéd, the main story is short and it's quite simplified compared to others in the genre but that's the beauty of it - it isn't trying to copy a successful franchise and then failing miserably; it has it's own spin on space rpg that's different whilst being familiar at the same time.

reviewText:
-->Hey there, honest and trusting trader ! Would you like to get your hand on some diamonds? Preety rare stuff...
<--Of course, well armed and eyepatch-wearing traveler! Let me get the credits from my secret compartment!
-->These are premium diamonds...I expect a fair price, dear lonely and without escort trader...
<--Here you go, fair and mighty defender of citizens!
-->Wow, that's a really good price. Thanks! Now... please stop your engines and drop your cargo!
<--With plea...what?!
-->You heard me the first time.
<--...I surrender, please don't fire.
-->Schmuck. Begone now.


Now to the point. At a  pretty low price you will  recive a pretty long free roam game. The combat is 2D with the exception of fighters. It's a mix between space and naval combat (spaceSHIPS, ya know). Incredible beatufil graphics, low system requirements(my gpu burned out so I'm playing this on a GT630 on max settings without AA), very few minor bugs that are crushed by the devs with ultra light speed (I had an issue with my ship, I posted the bug, the dev req. the save, I provided, in 30 min the dev sent a modified save my way and posted that the fix will be in the next patch).

If you enjoyed : Starpoint Gemini 2, Space rangers 2, X3, X2, Freelancer, Homeworld, Sins of a solar empire, etc.... aka good quality, gorgeous space games, this is a game that can stand beside them in feeling and level of detail. Also it's f___ing AMAZING that the main team is made out of 2 TWO developers. Incredible. This game is almost AAA quality. First time I see such a great game launched by an indie team.

The game is on a niche of it's own. Not many like this, although a little similarity with Starpoint Gemini 2.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND GETTING THIS AT FULL PRICE.

reviewText: It was pretty fun, the naval combat/broadsides mechanism was cool, and it's a solid 35 hours of gameplay, but it doesn't have tons of replay value and once you've hit endgame content, it stops being particularly difficult. You basically only die at that point if you get completely surrounded, your engines get disabled, and you're outnumbered 25 to 1. Which does happen, but not often. One on one, you'll wreck absolutely every ship in the game without really trying once you're running Mk6 everything.\n\nThere's still a handful of annoying bugs, but the developer's fixing them very quickly and they're being super-responsive to bug reports.

reviewText:
Good game for the money with some major drawbacks.

Pros:

- Great atmosphere
- Enjoyable Costumization
- Enjoyable Fights but (see cons)
- Good difficulty balance
- Nice random events but (see cons)
- Great soundtrack
- Beautiful universe and ship design

Cons:

-Fights get stale fast and are in terms of tactical depthness pretty bleak after a short while.

Enemys get spawned in around you which is a huge letdown. The fighst needed features like e.x. Take cover behind asteroids to avoid incoming fire from enemy, Take cover behind enemy ships to avoid fire. Maybe features like cloaking (you can detect every ship with a simples can, th game needs a system like world of warships), sideway boosts or big space battles with way more ships but a tactical feature to command and order friendly ships to win battles. (stop the game like the scannermode give us a overview and command features)

- Market system is to simple after a while and it should add new goods if you get to new systems or have individual goods that you can sell in different systems and more economical possibilitys.

- Random events like distress calls or bountys are great but two features get boring pretty fast

- Events on planets have a good impact on the econemy features but some events don't effect the prices as much as they should in my opinion.

- Rewards for e.x. destroying big battleships or pirate kings are inconsistent and don't scale properly

- And last but not least my most important complain:

The missions are too similar and there are only a handful of Story missions. The pretext of the Mainstory is good but it feels like the WHOLE CAMPAIGN should be only the FIRST CHAPTER of the whole story unfolding. Everything feels impersonal. You are traveling space for years and you have interaction with 4 notacible Characters in the whole game if you count all mercenarys as one character of interest.

I'm aware that this is a fairly small project from a very small developer team but the wasted potential on this game is making my head spin. So for now, as regrettable as it is, I can't wholeheartly recommend for you to buy this game.

Recommended for the $18 I paid for it, probably nothing more... maybe $20:

-Post-campaign is lackluster - Dreadnought class wrecks anything within two beam broadsides
-Trading is weird. Traders offer to give you an item for 5k while they offer to buy the same item at 9k. Wat
-Story is super bland - EVERYONE is forgettable; even the last boss is forgettable as I neutroned his ♥♥♥ into oblivion with barely any hull damage.

You control your ship on a 2D plane while the non-capital ships have 3D movement. Feels like AssCreed Black Flag naval combat in space - could be a negative for some but nevertheless, still fun.

tl;dr: Not GOTY content, but enjoyable at the pricepoint - realistically can enjoy it for about a week before moving onto something else

reviewText:
I am going to make this as simple as possible:

PROS
* Awesome soundtrack!
* It's like Firefly, with aliens...
* Lots of ships, lots of gear!
* There is a story, but it's not required to enjoy the game!
* Combat is fast and furious.
* Lots of potential for future content.
* Random galaxy with each new character.

CONS
* It's space, but it's not a 3D experience... wut?
* No multiplayer... here's a suggestion: Rebel Galaxy: Empires (MMO)
* Travel is very time consuming which means a long grind for good gear.
* While the soundtrack is awesome, the limited number of tracks becomes repetitive.
* Ship customization/personalization is unavailable (paintjobs)
* Combat can be a bit chaotic at times. I find, by the time I get to precise targeting, the battle is over.
* No crew or ship boarding. No hijacking of other ships.
* It feels empty at times... I have a HUGE ship. Where are my crew? Better crew, better performance?

All in all, I am 8 hours into the game and JUST traveled to the second system. It's very easy to get lost in just existing in the galaxy without ever chasing the storyline. RG has incredible potential to be one of those games that I just play when I have nothing else to do. I can jump on, do a few missions, and jump off. I can play one character as a law abiding merchant that helps others and keeps their nose clean, and then start another character to join up with pirates and be a menace to the galaxy. There are many missed opportunities (3D galaxy, multiplayer, crews, explorable stations, actual character creation, etc) but there is a lot of room for them to expand on the game in the future. As it stands currently, it is a game I will use as a time filler when I just want to kick back, relax, and enjoy a stress-free gaming experience.

reviewText:
I was on the fence about a 2D space combat game, but having played it it's a fun game.

It has some problems, the control system seems to be based around a gamepad so there are a few limitations on the UI that wouldn't otherwise be there. There are also some curious design decisions like being unable to access your cargohold/factions list/tactical menu etc while docked.

There is no RPGesque character development, the only limitation on what ship/equipment you can use seems to be money and to a lesser extent faction.

The combat in the game is fun. There is a large variety of equipment available to outfit your ship in order to compliment your playstyle. For instance you can gear your ship up for long range sniping, close range, and even fitting special deflector shields in order to cause extra damage ramming into other ships. In general the combat seems very well thought out.

On the other hand the trading and mining feel a bit lacklustre. Mining, even with the perfect" mining setup is haphazard and rarely nets you anywhere near the amount of money combat would in the same amount of time. Trading seems too random in that it's very hard to charge what good will be worth more at any given station. I freely admit though I haven't spent a lot of time trading
date: so it's very possible that if I invested more time in it I'd understand the system more.\n\nI've read complaints about the save system. It's a standard autosave only game
recommended: and the autosave only takes place when you dock. This means that if you pick up 3 missions
hoursPlayed: complete 2 and then die in the 3rd one you'll lose all that progress. However
voteText: that's not necessarily a bad thing as you just weigh up the risk and dock if necessary to save.\n\nThe soundtrack in the game is...interesting. I kind of liked it at first
helpfulPercent: but it becomes very repetitive after a couple of hours. However
votesHelpful: using the launcher you can easily add your own music.\n\nIn summary this game is definately worth picking up if you enjoy space action games."
