reviewText:
One of my favorite games of the year!

This game reminds me of a simple, single-player version of EVE Online.

While there is a basic main story line, the game really allows you to do whatever you want.
It’s not uncommon for me to hear a distress call, save the mining vessel from a fleet of enemy ships, then scan the barge and realize I need what he has and destroy him anyway. Even worse, sell him some items then destroy him to get them back after being paid. All while trying to maintain a good standing with certain factions.

The music is top notch. I could listen to it all day and it really sets the scene as a free-lance/cowboy pilot.
Visually it is also wonderful. While not on the same level as EVE its enjoyable to fly through.

The combat is unique (in a good way). It is a hybrid between targeting and letting your AI handle the work and manually aiming and shooting. I like this a bit more than the EVE combat system.

The developers are also on-point. Very active in the community and make promises they can keep.

Overall I would give this game a solid 8 out of 10. Well worth the money for any gamer who likes space action or adventures.

reviewText:
I knew I was making a good choice when I decided to put this game on my watch list before release to buy it upon release day and man I was not dissapointed, this game is a great and beautiful alternative to Elite: Dangerous, X: Rebirth, easy to use, straightforward controls, if all you want to do is go about blowing stuff up without grinding through trades for hours on end before you can do so then this is the game to buy! The soundtrack for the game is very relaxing on long journeys, not that the journeys are long to begin with, at least not by the last games mentioned standards and there's no going back and forth to take and complete missions, all you need to do is simply go to a station, pick up a mission and complete it and the money will be automatically rewarded to you without the need for travelling all the way back to the place you picked the mission up from.

Here's a pros and cons list for those who want a more straightforward run down.
Please note that I haven't ventured further than the beginning system at the time of this review, these are based on what I've experianced so far.

PROS:
-Great soundtrack.
-I can run the game on max settings without lag on a low grade 1GB GPU and a 2.8 dual core CPU
-Easy to use controls.
-No back and forth missions (aside from the story missions)
-Beautiful scenery
-AI behaviour for turrets and your wingman (should you choose to hire)
-Accurate mission ratings from very low to very high (go into high and very high ranked missions carefully)
-Nice balance of strengths and weaknesses between ships and equipment

CONS:
-Price jump in higher grade ships and equipment is quite large
-high risk missions (which often involves killing multiple ships) rewards the same amount of credits as some bounties which are much easier.
-Faction relations don't give much benefit asides from that faction deciding to shoot you or not and allow you to dock at stations.
-It's hard to manually target anything that you have to pan the camera to target with turrets (or maybe that's just lack of skill on my part)
-While I do like the intention of the mechanic it can get somewhat annoying when you are pulled out of warp drive by an asteroid field on a regular basis because you couldn't see it coming and are suddenly smack in the middle of it after managing to avoid some asterdoids by pure luck and end up having to manually fly through it before you can go into hyper again.

reviewText:
Summary:
This is a nice, action-ladden space opera. Decent presentation, virtually bug-free and quite a lot of fun for many hours.

Further Info:
Think of Starpoint Gemini 2 done right. It has nice (albeit cheesy) music, pretty nebulas and explosions and Laser Beams. Like, a lot of beams. And missiles. There are a lot of spaceships that you can customize with different type of weapons to accomodate your game style. Whether you prefer to attack from afar or get in melee (including ramming), there is the right equipment for you.

So if you like to blow up spaceships of all kinds, this is your game. However, if you like a realistic space sim, stay away from it. There is nothing realistic in Rebel Galaxy. Flight physics are very basic and very forgiving. Space in the game is only 2D, at least for you. There are objects and enemy fighters that can fly above or below you, but you cannot. To me, this is a great design choice. But this means that you will not really do any dog fighting. Instead, combat feels like seaships battling with the sea removed. This impression is supported by the fact that ships in Rebel Galaxy have their most powerful weapons mounted at their sides and not the front.

And by the way. While you can mine in this game and trade, you will likely spend most of your time blowing up spaceships. Mainly because mining and trading is very rougly implemented. I guess, if you make a space opera, you have to allow people to mine and trade. Because people expect it to be there. Even if it is boring as ♥♥♥♥.

There are a couple of negative points I would like to mention: the loot system is very basic. There are a few weapons you can only get from destroying other ships, but these are very rare and not really special. So upgrading your ship is mainly done through spending credits you earn through missions. And while the ship customization options are fine, I would have preferred still more options. Like putting extra power into weapons by sacrificing shield strength. Or installing an extra tower while giving up a support module. Also, the story is sort of generic. No big surprises there.

Still, this is another game that revives the space opera genre, which was believed dead long enough. And if you are actually still expecting Star Citizin to be great, this might be a game that shortens the long wait.

8.5/10.

reviewText:
If you're looking for elitist  3D space combat with twitchy impossible combat and hardcore navigation and think it's fun to die trying to dock your ship, don't waste your money.

If you want a fun game that's rewarding in small doses or good for an epic gaming weekend, this is it.  But warn your friends and family that they will be seeing less of you for a while....

It's a beautifully done space combat/trading/questing game.  You can be a trader, you can be a miner, you can be a pirate, you can be a quester, or most likely you'll find yourself doing a little bit of all of it.  Or a LOT of all of it.

I will suggest playing with a controller...I'm a longtime keyboard and mouse guy and I never use a controller for anything.  Thats a big part of why my Nintendo was gifted to my nephew and my xbox hasnt been plugged in for 2 years, but with this game the controller just feels right and works perfectly.


Pros:
*  It looks 3D, but it's mostly a 2D game, so it simplifies the navigation and combat
*  Its very open.  There is a story line to progress through , but you're free to ignore it, or progress at your own pace
*  You can fire it up, do a couple of quick quests, and feel like you accomplished something.
* And then a couple more, and then just one more, and then another one.....and 8 hours later you've played a quick game
* It autosaves every time you visit a station.  So if your next quest goes horribly wrong, and you die a fiery death, then reload and try again.
* If an objective is too hard, there are plenty of options to go make a little money, buy some better armor and weapons, and try it again.  Yet somehow it doesnt feel grindy, it's fun.
* After over 30 hours, I still have the music turned on.  I saw one review call it Cowboy butt-rock" - I'm not sure if they meant that as a compliment or an insult
date: but it kind of fits.  Either way
recommended: I like it.\n* The one time I had a problem
hoursPlayed:
I posted a question on the support forum and got a response in 15 minutes

Cons
* If you're not a fan of the "Cowboy butt-rock"

reviewText:
Okay, so as I write this I am currently only at eleven hours of playtime, not a whole lot really. And in the grand scheme of things? I've barely scratched the surface of this game. You're dumped into a solar system, with a few planets and maybe ten-ish? stations to visit and get some random missions from. Cool, great, awesome. Did I mention this is only one solar system out of a galaxy?

Sure it's in space, the game isn't really going to be absolutely teeming with life or a huge population, but whenever you find a landmark there's usually some miners, pirates, the Militia, or some traders that are around, and it's up to you how to interpret who is friend, who is foe, and who is prey.

Can you be a pirate in this? Absolutely. Can you trade and smuggle illegal materials from different stations? Of course, just be careful of Militia patrols - they're in bigger, and meaner ships than you are to start out with, and they tend to shoot first and ask questions later if you're on the wrong side of the law. And of course you can also play the role of a bounty hunter, chasing after Pirate heads to fuel your bank account and taking up odd jobs to buy a few new guns along the way.

You can also be a trader, taking supplies from one station, then going and selling them at another station to make a huge profit. There's a news-feed option in there to let you know what the latest prices are for each station, if you're patient enough. Just look out for the pirates. Or, if you're a wuss, you can just be a miner and shred through astroids with mining lasers, selling the metal ore for profit, and running the hell away from the Pirates who like your cargo, but don't like the work.

As far as the combat goes, there's nothing really all that complex about it. You've got Broadside weapons, Turrets, and Secondaries. Broadsides are pretty self explanitory - they're guns mounted in the port and starboard sides of your ship (Left and Right) that are your main ship-killing weapons. What's neat is you can just spray-and-pray with them if you want, or you can charge them up, take aim, and have a well-timed barrage that leads your target so it lands right into their hull. Although if you're point blank, sometimes the spray-and-pray is better for use as a DPS race.

Then you have turrets. You can have some pretty simple stuff... missile turrets, laser turrets, beam weaponry, and even some flak guns to take down those pesky fighters and bombers swarming around your poopdeck.

And lastly there's Secondaries. Secondaries are essentially up to you, and effect certain places where your craft will be effective. You can put... bigger flak guns, you can put mine launchers, dumb-fire missile launchers, heat-seeker missile launchers, and so on.

As far as the story goes? I haven't really gotten that far into it yet, but from what I can tell it's super simple and not really anything that you're gonna get lost on. Find some alien-tech doohickey and then go on an adventure to find out what the heck it is and what it does.

Bottom line is this: If you like Starpoint Gemini, but thought the combat and world was exceptionally boring (like I found it to be...)? You'll like this. If you like pretending you're piloting Serenity or the Outlaw Star, you'll like this.

You can't take the sky from me.

reviewText:
If you remember games like Freelancer and Freespace 2 and wish there was a modern game like them, then this is the game for you. It's a single player space adventure with naval style combat, complete with broadside attacks. Upgrade your weapons, shields and more or save up to buy a whole new ship - anything from a nippy little corvette to a huge and powerful dreadnought.

[PROS]
* The soundtrack is immense. It's sort of bluesy and grungy, with a definite western feel (think Firefly). The heavy guitar riffs brought a smile to my face more than once during a pitched battle.
* The story. Engaging and fun, with just the right amount of grinding side-quests in between.
* Active developers. The game is post-launch, but they're still working on it and perfecting things, which is always nice to see.
* The graphics. The ships are very detailed in perticular, with artistic and individual designs for each one. None of the 'stock blocky ship 1a' nonsense you get in some games of this ilk. They all have their own distinc look and feel.
* Firefly. A lot has been made of the similarities and they are there. Mostly in the asthetic rather than the actual gameplay, but it really feels like that's the universe you are playing in. What's not to love about that!
* Freedom. Choose to stay in a fast ship with high maneuverability, or spring for a lumbering dreadnought, armed to the teeth. Looks like a fish, moves like a fish, steers like a cow. There really is no perfect choice. You can switch between ships you have bought with no penalty too, which is a great touch.

[CONS]
* Campaign could be longer. A mid-level ship is more than sufficient to complete the whole thing, so the awesome but expensive top-tier ships don't get a proper airing. However  The campaign ends on a cliff-hanger, so a sequel or expansion might be in the works.
* Navigating can get a bit irritating. You drop out of FTL travel when you get close to an asteroid, or any other obstacle and they are everywhere. This would be okay, but you can never see them coming in advance. I got used to it though, since travel times really aren't that long anyway.

reviewText:
I am going to make this as simple as possible:

PROS
* Awesome soundtrack!
* It's like Firefly, with aliens...
* Lots of ships, lots of gear!
* There is a story, but it's not required to enjoy the game!
* Combat is fast and furious.
* Lots of potential for future content.
* Random galaxy with each new character.

CONS
* It's space, but it's not a 3D experience... wut?
* No multiplayer... here's a suggestion: Rebel Galaxy: Empires (MMO)
* Travel is very time consuming which means a long grind for good gear.
* While the soundtrack is awesome, the limited number of tracks becomes repetitive.
* Ship customization/personalization is unavailable (paintjobs)
* Combat can be a bit chaotic at times. I find, by the time I get to precise targeting, the battle is over.
* No crew or ship boarding. No hijacking of other ships.
* It feels empty at times... I have a HUGE ship. Where are my crew? Better crew, better performance?

All in all, I am 8 hours into the game and JUST traveled to the second system. It's very easy to get lost in just existing in the galaxy without ever chasing the storyline. RG has incredible potential to be one of those games that I just play when I have nothing else to do. I can jump on, do a few missions, and jump off. I can play one character as a law abiding merchant that helps others and keeps their nose clean, and then start another character to join up with pirates and be a menace to the galaxy. There are many missed opportunities (3D galaxy, multiplayer, crews, explorable stations, actual character creation, etc) but there is a lot of room for them to expand on the game in the future. As it stands currently, it is a game I will use as a time filler when I just want to kick back, relax, and enjoy a stress-free gaming experience.

reviewText:
Love being a space cowboy in Rebel Galaxy, it just feels good to fly around and fight other ships!

Graphics are amazing even on my mid-level system, my jaw dropped when I first loaded up the game. My laptop has a hard time running it though.

Great pacing, lots of things to do; explore the solar systems, smuggle cargo between space stations, start fights with space pirates and steal their cargo, sell loot and upgrade your weapons...buy a new ship once you've saved up enough.

I also like how you can customize your ship to fit different playstyles, there's no wrong answer, combat always feels intense and rewarding. Outfit long range cannons and missles to snipe opponents from afar, for medium range fightfights use blaster turrets and rockets, or cover your ship in lasers to cut ships apart up close!

You also get to pick whether you prefer a huge tank-like ship or a sleek corvette, customize your speed and durability based on your play style.

There are no levels, the more money you make the better ships and equipment you can afford, so buy trade items low, stock your hold with valuables, and sell to the buyers offering the most at the commodity markets at the space stations.

One other thing I love is the music. Not only does it come with great music by default, you can use your own MP3 collection, and it will change songs for Ambient, Combat, Idle, Menu, and Space Station. So I made folders for each music type, copied songs that fit the mood into the folders, and added those folders to the game's music library. So when I'm cruising through space I can enjoy some low key Beck and Radiohead, but when a fight breaks out the game will start blasting Green Day or the Klaxons!

Buy it! Don't even hesitate, don't even worry, don't even give it a second thought.

reviewText:
Quick Summary: Rebel Galaxy is an open-universe space combat/exploration/trading/mining/pirating game.

Quick Score: 8/10 - Great gameplay, graphics and sound, can get grindy and repetitive.

Full Review:

I'll talk about, in order of relevance to me personally, Gameplay, Graphics, and Sound.

Gameplay-
If you liked the ship combat in Assassins Creed Black Flag, then you'll find something to love here. The game takes place on a flat plane, which means no z-axis navigation. You're solely on the X-Y Plane. And that's a good thing, once you see the competition you're up against. But don't worry, only the smaller craft go up and down, the larger ones don't. You can individually man a selection of turrets or your broadsides in combat. There's a variety of each type to choose to suit your playstyle. If you like to get up close and personal, or keep your distance, there's a weapon for you. When you are not controlling the turrets directly, they are controlled by the AI, which you can configure. You can set them to lock onto specific targets, fire at will, or be completely manual. It's up to you. Even navigation is largely the same as Black Flag. Accelerate in stages, decelerate in stages with optional braking, and turn from side to side.

Aside from that, there's things like factions you can side with, an economy to exploit, mining activities, and so on. A story is present, but can go largely ignored. Feel free to blow ♥♥♥♥ up and rack up the credits to the next ship upgrade. Speaking of, aside from aforementioned weaponry, defenses such as shields and armor and subsystems, which run specialised tasks as additions to your ship, can be upgraded. In a refreshing change of norm, you don't lose any credits when buying and selling items for your ship, so you're free to experiment until you find something that works. Even the ships you purchase come in a variety of sizes, from meek little frigates to massive and lumbering dreadnaughts and destroyers. There's plenty of ways to find a loadout more to your playstyle.

One complaint I often see in space games is the sheer lack of things to do between travels. Fortunately, Rebel Galaxy keeps you on your toes. What may seem like a routine flight to another station may result in attending to a distress signal, getting ambushed by the enemy, or crashing into a nebula, with rocks (sorry, unsure what it's actually called) to dodge, mine or destroy. You can't expect to set your target and make some tea.

There's also significant strategy in taking down opponents. Firing at the left side of the ship reduces the shielding for that side only, and not all the way round. Same goes for armor. So do you take an all-sides approach, or focus on one side of the ship? It's not so easy to just fire away, as you need to consider these things when attacking.

Should you wish to make some dough, you can take on side missions or perform things like trading, mining, bounty hunting, and so on. It shouldn't be too hard to get the credits required for your next purchase.

Graphics-
I'm not one to stress on how pretty a game looks. I'm more for graphics. But my oh my is this game pretty. I'm more the person who feels Mirror's Edge looks better than Crysis 3, and the same goes here. Not the Crysis 3 thing. Space is beautiful. Instead of making it a black cosmos, with little white dots, it's colourful. Distant nebulae pepper the view with dashes of red, green, blue, purple, etc. Ships look worn but strong. Damage modelling is pretty impressive. ou can see scorch marks and chunks missing, embers glowing with some of the inner components revealed if you suffer significant damage. Weapons look beautiful when fired. They glow brightly, be it lasers or missiles. Speaking of, there's a flare effect from oncoming missiles fired from afar. Gives it a very cinematic feeling. There's also enough lens flare to make JJ Abrams happy, but it's done tastefully. Rest assured you won't have your view blocked by it. The UI is clean and uncluttered, letting you really soak in the surroundings. Rocket trails, when at warp, leave long blue lines behind you, and they each have a different layout depending on the thrusters of your ship. The Pulse effect looks good, akin to sonar visualised. When braking your ship, the thrusters turn red, as though they were brake lights. I considered it a nice touch.

Sound-
Best soundtrack so far. The game comes with a preloaded country/western soundtrack, that actually fits really well with the game. Should it not be your thing, feel free to add your own music collection, with the ability to set specific folders to different moments in the game, ie Combat, Travel, and so on. I personally set some dubstep for combat. As for sound effects, they're powerful. Flak cannons properly deafen, missiles have their own distinct sound, and everything comes together without sounding deafening. Even the AI which reports on your ship's status is plucked straight outta Sci-Fi stereotype, but hey, it works! Voice acting for the other characters you meet along the way is decent, but some of the quips from your enemies will begin to repeat fairly early.There's variety in language too. Different species may speak different languages, but in a way that sounds realistic. All in all, pretty good.

Conclusion: The game gets repetitive, sure, so its longevity  really depends on how much fun you can have. I personally see this as the kind of game I can invest quite some time it, but your mileage may vary.

reviewText: Call me utterly surprised. This game came out of no where from me, and if not for a reccomendation from someone I trust I would have never even heard of it. This is a game by a series of devs that know their stuff. The controls are very slick and accessible, the ship piloting is fantastic, and it's the kind of thing that could have had a waffly, generic scifi electronica or trumpet track and instead has some of the most radical rock/country (yes, I am advocating something that is at least in part country, but I mean listen to the trailer people) I've ever heard backing it pretty solidly. That tangles with the interesting strategies for space battles, the system for navigating faction trust and how you can play out numerous missions without even touching the main story. This is an excellent example of emergent gameplay and, while the story to me is really just so much background noise, even the little things characters do and say add to the setting's charm. This is AAA+ to me, amazing and simply made me a fan of this dev in whatever they do.

reviewText: OK, So I know I dont have a whole lot of time in this game but my favorite genre of games is space flight/simulators. As far as a single player space simulator this is by far my favorite. reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy looks like an odd game to start with. How many games are there that have you flying around space, buying, selling, mining or stealing? I have played quite a few over the years. Most of them have you moving around in 3 dimensions; after all, space is not flat plane is it? So, why does Rebel Galaxy use two dimensions for you as the player but 3 for many of your opponents? Surely this is silly?

Surprisingly I have to say no, it actually works really well. I am around 4 hours into the game now and I must say that I like the battle mechanics and the flight from one part of the system to another is pretty smooth. (Could be a bit quicker possibly but that is just me.

So, what is it that I enjoy? Raking your opponent from stem to stern using broadsides in space is cool. This is why the game is on a flat plane. By using your main weapons as broadsides it would not work if you had to roll to bring your guns to bear.

The ecomomic system seems to work well, I like the way that when buying or selling you can see the average price in the sector. This will reduce the need for notes or trying to remember how much you paid for nuts and bolts, yes this is a real cargo. I like the idea of cola being illegal btw :-)

I think that this is one that I will be playing for some time. It has been on my wish list since its release and in the sale I thought I would go for it. Now, the big question is would I have still enjoyed it at full price? So far I have to say yes I would have. There are loads of missions to do, a storyline to follow or if you just want to blow up asteroids for ore you can. There are loads floating round.

You can configure your weaponry easily, with plenty of ships to fly , I haven't seen any dodgy models yet, all looking rather swish.

So, go and buy the game if you like flying in space, blowing things up, mining or finding lost relatives. You won't regret it.

Should have said about the music. Cant think of ANY game that has more fitting music!

reviewText:
Over all I like this game. It is a fun combat focused game. the brodside style is great but can make it a little challenging in the belts with all the rocks you can run into while looking to the side. The voice acting is ok and sounds like your dealing with folk living in the backside of creation, does remind one alittle of Firefly.

That said the game feels a little flat for an open world style game. Some things are missing that other open world games have, ie the Elder Scrolls series.

Other than the main story line there is nothing to do except the mission boards and get credits for your next upgrade. You can join the guilds but the only reason to is for the gear that only they have. There should be guild specific storylines, as in other open world games, with thier own consequences and rewards (not just creds but uniqe gear as well) to make it worth your time to join.

I enjoy playing this game. But would like to see some DLC's or mod's come out to fix these little flaws. All in all thumbs up.

Gameplay-
If you liked the ship combat in Assassins Creed Black Flag, then you'll find something to love here. The game takes place on a flat plane, which means no z-axis navigation. You're solely on the X-Y Plane. And that's a good thing, once you see the competition you're up against. But don't worry, only the smaller craft go up and down, the larger ones don't. You can individually man a selection of turrets or your broadsides in combat. There's a variety of each type to choose to suit your playstyle. If you like to get up close and personal, or keep your distance, there's a weapon for you. When you are not controlling the turrets directly, they are controlled by the AI, which you can configure. You can set them to lock onto specific targets, fire at will, or be completely manual. It's up to you. Even navigation is largely the same as Black Flag. Accelerate in stages, decelerate in stages with optional braking, and turn from side to side.

Aside from that, there's things like factions you can side with, an economy to exploit, mining activities, and so on. A story is present, but can go largely ignored. Feel free to blow ♥♥♥♥ up and rack up the credits to the next ship upgrade. Speaking of, aside from aforementioned weaponry, defenses such as shields and armor and subsystems, which run specialised tasks as additions to your ship, can be upgraded. In a refreshing change of norm, you don't lose any credits when buying and selling items for your ship, so you're free to experiment until you find something that works. Even the ships you purchase come in a variety of sizes, from meek little frigates to massive and lumbering dreadnaughts and destroyers. There's plenty of ways to find a loadout more to your playstyle.

One complaint I often see in space games is the sheer lack of things to do between travels. Fortunately, Rebel Galaxy keeps you on your toes. What may seem like a routine flight to another station may result in attending to a distress signal, getting ambushed by the enemy, or crashing into a nebula, with rocks (sorry, unsure what it's actually called) to dodge, mine or destroy. You can't expect to set your target and make some tea.

There's also significant strategy in taking down opponents. Firing at the left side of the ship reduces the shielding for that side only, and not all the way round. Same goes for armor. So do you take an all-sides approach, or focus on one side of the ship? It's not so easy to just fire away, as you need to consider these things when attacking.

Should you wish to make some dough, you can take on side missions or perform things like trading, mining, bounty hunting, and so on. It shouldn't be too hard to get the credits required for your next purchase.

Graphics-
I'm not one to stress on how pretty a game looks. I'm more for graphics. But my oh my is this game pretty. I'm more the person who feels Mirror's Edge looks better than Crysis 3, and the same goes here. Not the Crysis 3 thing. Space is beautiful. Instead of making it a black cosmos, with little white dots, it's colourful. Distant nebulae pepper the view with dashes of red, green, blue, purple, etc. Ships look worn but strong. Damage modelling is pretty impressive. ou can see scorch marks and chunks missing, embers glowing with some of the inner components revealed if you suffer significant damage. Weapons look beautiful when fired. They glow brightly, be it lasers or missiles. Speaking of, there's a flare effect from oncoming missiles fired from afar. Gives it a very cinematic feeling. There's also enough lens flare to make JJ Abrams happy, but it's done tastefully. Rest assured you won't have your view blocked by it. The UI is clean and uncluttered, letting you really soak in the surroundings. Rocket trails, when at warp, leave long blue lines behind you, and they each have a different layout depending on the thrusters of your ship. The Pulse effect looks good, akin to sonar visualised. When braking your ship, the thrusters turn red, as though they were brake lights. I considered it a nice touch.

Sound-
Best soundtrack so far. The game comes with a preloaded country/western soundtrack, that actually fits really well with the game. Should it not be your thing, feel free to add your own music collection, with the ability to set specific folders to different moments in the game, ie Combat, Travel, and so on. I personally set some dubstep for combat. As for sound effects, they're powerful. Flak cannons properly deafen, missiles have their own distinct sound, and everything comes together without sounding deafening. Even the AI which reports on your ship's status is plucked straight outta Sci-Fi stereotype, but hey, it works! Voice acting for the other characters you meet along the way is decent, but some of the quips from your enemies will begin to repeat fairly early.There's variety in language too. Different species may speak different languages, but in a way that sounds realistic. All in all, pretty good.

Conclusion: The game gets repetitive, sure, so its longevity  really depends on how much fun you can have. I personally see this as the kind of game I can invest quite some time it, but your mileage may vary.

reviewText:
This is my review, the game is great, love it quite abit. Being a Former EVE Online player, and multitude of other games I got in my own collection, The controls for this is very simple... for I will admit, I am no pilot! I am the only person in the world whom can crash an aircraft on takeoff!

But the controls are easy, and I love it.

Okay so here are the pros that I can safely say: for one, 19 bucks for the game is a bargin compared to other games, such as Elite: Dangerious (I tried it, cant fly), I like the trade system in the game, cause lets face it... repairs can suck at times, and drains the living hell out of your coffers. It doesnt hurt to dabble in it afterall, suppliment your income to ensure your vessle is in combat shape? why not right?
Another is the combat system, The turrets, the Turrets! Oh how wonderful it is to be able to set the turrets how you wish. Leaving you to focus on defence, Sub Weapon systems (EMP Flak for the win), and the broadsides! while the turrets can rip the little fighters apart (they suck at times). the Manuvering is very smooth if your comfortable with the standard Keymotions from MMOs, you know the ASDW.

Okay, time for the Nitpicking;

the Cons;

Ship content; I was told by a Dev (Thank you by the way) They will adjust ships to better suit how each is to stack up, so no one size fits all vessle... But still, we could use more ship types. even have Fighter Crafts of our own, even Bombers (For you batshit crazy aces out there, you know who you are), And maybe JUST Maybe, look into adding Multiplayer content, like conversion option for Single or Online version. Some people wanna rub other peoples faces into their afterburners afterall, and some are lone wolves in a sense.

Mercinaries: Well not really judging, but would be nice if there was more of them to choose from, its like... each part of the space you go to, its sometimes the same pilot sitting at the bar (Stalker much?), So be kinda nice to have to hunt down your fav merc, and make them worthwhile to hang onto (rather than rehire them later in the game just to keep up with the enemies in the area)

Factions: Needs a hint more love, maybe more factions?, and of course adding stuff for the factions to do (stuff that can affect each galaxy?) So Devs if your reading this and not vomiting from my pretty sad review. Take a moment from giving yourselves a far well deserved pat on the back, and look into Factions. Then Add and Fluff (and polish them out), it would give you ALOT more stuff to do, and would (hopefully) get alot more people to buy it

So all and all in a Nutshell (if your still sane after reading this, grats, if not... I heard the Jello in the institutes is nice),

The Game is great with next to no complaints, great soundtrack (be better if you can change the channel at times), Good content, and player control. I highly recommend getting this game...

Oh by the by, for you new players out there... hire a merc, they are a real help!


-----Spoiler alert!-----

THE CAKE IS A LIE!!

reviewText: OK, So I know I dont have a whole lot of time in this game but my favorite genre of games is space flight/simulators. As far as a single player space simulator this is by far my favorite. You are not limited to just fighting all the time you can MINE and TRADE as well!!!! So if you feel like taking a break from all of the Multiplayer space games (Eve online, Star Citizen, Elite Dangerous, ect.....) this is the game for you. This game is a simplified, single player version of Elite Dangerous. Also the graphics for such a small game are quite AMAZING!!!! They show hull damage significantly better than most space games out right now. So in short great game probably gonna put in an easy 100 hours into it. Wish I could give it more thumbs up.

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy looks like an odd game to start with. How many games are there that have you flying around space, buying, selling, mining or stealing? I have played quite a few over the years. Most of them have you moving around in 3 dimensions; after all, space is not flat plane is it? So, why does Rebel Galaxy use two dimensions for you as the player but 3 for many of your opponents? Surely this is silly?

Surprisingly I have to say no, it actually works really well. I am around 4 hours into the game now and I must say that I like the battle mechanics and the flight from one part of the system to another is pretty smooth. (Could be a bit quicker possibly but that is just me.

So, what is it that I enjoy? Raking your opponent from stem to stern using broadsides in space is cool. This is why the game is on a flat plane. By using your main weapons as broadsides it would not work if you had to roll to bring your guns to bear.

The ecomomic system seems to work well, I like the way that when buying or selling you can see the average price in the sector. This will reduce the need for notes or trying to remember how much you paid for nuts and bolts, yes this is a real cargo. I like the idea of cola being illegal btw :-)

I think that this is one that I will be playing for some time. It has been on my wish list since its release and in the sale I thought I would go for it. Now, the big question is would I have still enjoyed it at full price? So far I have to say yes I would have. There are loads of missions to do, a storyline to follow or if you just want to blow up asteroids for ore you can. There are loads floating round.

You can configure your weaponry easily, with plenty of ships to fly , I haven't seen any dodgy models yet, all looking rather swish.

So, go and buy the game if you like flying in space, blowing things up, mining or finding lost relatives. You won't regret it.

Should have said about the music. Cant think of ANY game that has more fitting music!

reviewText:
Okay, so as I write this I am currently only at eleven hours of playtime, not a whole lot really. And in the grand scheme of things? I've barely scratched the surface of this game. You're dumped into a solar system, with a few planets and maybe ten-ish? stations to visit and get some random missions from. Cool, great, awesome. Did I mention this is only one solar system out of a galaxy?

Sure it's in space, the game isn't really going to be absolutely teeming with life or a huge population, but whenever you find a landmark there's usually some miners, pirates, the Militia, or some traders that are around, and it's up to you how to interpret who is friend, who is foe, and who is prey.

Can you be a pirate in this? Absolutely. Can you trade and smuggle illegal materials from different stations? Of course, just be careful of Militia patrols - they're in bigger, and meaner ships than you are to start out with, and they tend to shoot first and ask questions later if you're on the wrong side of the law. And of course you can also play the role of a bounty hunter, chasing after Pirate heads to fuel your bank account and taking up odd jobs to buy a few new guns along the way.

You can also be a trader, taking supplies from one station, then going and selling them at another station to make a huge profit. There's a news-feed option in there to let you know what the latest prices are for each station, if you're patient enough. Just look out for the pirates. Or, if you're a wuss, you can just be a miner and shred through astroids with mining lasers, selling the metal ore for profit, and running the hell away from the Pirates who like your cargo, but don't like the work.

As far as the combat goes, there's nothing really all that complex about it. You've got Broadside weapons, Turrets, and Secondaries. Broadsides are pretty self explanitory - they're guns mounted in the port and starboard sides of your ship (Left and Right) that are your main ship-killing weapons. What's neat is you can just spray-and-pray with them if you want, or you can charge them up, take aim, and have a well-timed barrage that leads your target so it lands right into their hull. Although if you're point blank, sometimes the spray-and-pray is better for use as a DPS race.

Then you have turrets. You can have some pretty simple stuff... missile turrets, laser turrets, beam weaponry, and even some flak guns to take down those pesky fighters and bombers swarming around your poopdeck.

And lastly there's Secondaries. Secondaries are essentially up to you, and effect certain places where your craft will be effective. You can put... bigger flak guns, you can put mine launchers, dumb-fire missile launchers, heat-seeker missile launchers, and so on.

As far as the story goes? I haven't really gotten that far into it yet, but from what I can tell it's super simple and not really anything that you're gonna get lost on. Find some alien-tech doohickey and then go on an adventure to find out what the heck it is and what it does.

Bottom line is this: If you like Starpoint Gemini, but thought the combat and world was exceptionally boring (like I found it to be...)? You'll like this. If you like pretending you're piloting Serenity or the Outlaw Star, you'll like this.

You can't take the sky from me.

reviewText: Rebel Galaxy is a thoroughly enjoyable space RPG-style game.  The game page and other reviews do a good job of providing more detail on the gameplay, so I won't waste too much time covering that.  Basically, it's a naval combat game in space (movement is in 2D only).  That being said, this style in no way detracts from the game's value.  You spend your time doing missions, mining, trading, and/or hunting bounties to make money which goes toward upgrading your ship.  There is also a main campaign" that takes you through a simple yet adequately interesting story.  On the downside
date: the factions are a bit bland (as is mentioned in several other reviews) and there really doesn't seem to be much replayability (at least I personally have no desire to replay now that I've beaten the game).\n\nIf you want to pew-pew other spaceships in a beautifully rendered
recommended: decent sized "universe" while listening to an admittedly catchy soundtrack (seemingly ranging in influence from CCR to Pearl Jam at times) then this game is worth looking into.  It runs smoothly with no bugs or glitches (for me
hoursPlayed: anyway).  Ultimately
voteText: I found the game experience to be well worth the cost.\n\n8.5/10"

reviewText:
If you were ever a fan of the Escape Velocity franchise you'll fall in love with this game. While it is missing some key elements from games like Escape Velocity such as being able to board and capture vessels to build a small fleet of escort ships it definitely fits the classic bill of running missions out of seedy bars on backwater stations and running those luxery goods from place to place to rake in the dough hand over fist.

Soundtrack is heavily influenced by the dark and outlaw country genres of music, predominately by guitarist Blues Saraceno and acts such as The Blue News whichs adds a very heavy credit to it being a premier Space Western. Spend more than five minutes in the game and you'll be wishing you were raiding Space Trains belonging to Space Yankees who sacked the Space South after Sherman's Jump through the Orion Spur.

Graphicly it is a decently impressive game that doesn't really fail to impress when it concerns ship, station or other object design and detail... also love burning up in atmospheres of planetary bodies, so gotta watch that hahah... seriously don't fly too close or you'll melt yourself six ways from STS-107.

Overall if you want to jump into something that'll suck you in for a couple dozen hours its well worth the purchase for the sound track alone, which you can stand alone play from the game's data files (if you have anything that converts .ogg format)

reviewText:
Finished the Main Campaign so figured I'd write a quick review.
It won't be in depth, but it might help you choose whether to purchase.

This game is REALLY good fun, there are multiple factions and Guilds that you can work for, whether you want to be a Trader, Pirate, Mercenary.

The combat is really smooth and fun, graphics are beautiful and the soundtrack.. OMFG the soundtrack....
By far the best Soundtrack of any game in the last 5 years.

Interesting (if somewhat predictable) storyline, don't expecct a full on THIS IS OVER type of ending, it's pretty open, and I really hope they expand on this game, or make another one.

Great work by such a small Dev team.

I highly recommend this game, and would have paid more for it, if they'd priced it higher.

You won't be let down or feel like you wasted money, you get more than enough for such a small price.

Why are you still reading this... buy it... :P

reviewText:
Started out with an obsolete crap-ship that could be killed by an asteroid.

Killed a lot of criminals.

Ended up with a dreadnought so powerful I could take on three other dreadnought class ships at once without skipping a beat.

10/10 would completely ignore the trading/mining system again.

Seriously for its price this is an amazing game. It has just the right amount of complexity while maintaining its low pressure nature and has very fun combat. Perfect game to blow off steam just cruising around in your ship.

It has a respectable amount of customization options and fighting styles.

My only real complaint is that there isn't an endgame area with powerful enough enemies for my invicible Revenant :( But as you can see that was after 30 hours of playtime.

reviewText:
A space fighter/flight game is an itch that has gone unscratched for a very long time and for a very simple reason; They’re not terribly user friendly to start with. They're mostly varying flavors of spreadsheets and menus.

Rebel Galaxy avoids this problem by... not being a very complicated game. It’s stuck on a single flight platform which completely omits the need for severe flight tactics, and is instead comparable to Assassin’s Creed: Black Flag’s style of naval combat, down to the similarly used “Broadside” cannons. After that, it’s a matter of strategically placing some of your turrets as they autofire at your enemies while you control one, usually some type of rapidfire thing to cut through your enemies.
Enemy ships, usually the small fighters, tend to have access to the 3D plane which is not as much of a problem as you might expect as it usually just means you need to plan your position to open fire. Again, your guns can shoot them depending on placement.

Meanwhile it has a sort of MMO-like questing style of clearing enemies, shipping goods, defending traders, as well as a story mode. I actually have a lot of fun just ignoring the main quest (As you do), running around making ALL the money, upgrading my ship, and having a giggle when my main quest’s risk rating reads “Very Low”.

As an aside; The music is wonderful and it took considerable resistance not to name my ship “Serenity”. It’s got a couple hours of full length (~3 minute) songs that will change in space stations or open battles which helps mix it up a bit.

If I had a complaint, it’s probably that there’s not too much to do mid flight. Mid transit, there’s not a lot of popups when you’re fighting thousands of whatever-unit-of-distance it’s using. It amounts to three things interrupting your warp speed: Distress Signals, Ambushes, and Asteroid Fields/Nebulas. Beyond those, you might want to stop to play some piracy and raid trading convoys that go between space stations, which manipulates the market for you to take advantage of.
I just wish there was more to do when I'm aiming for an objective that's tens of thousands of whatever-unit-of-distances away.

Ultimately, it’s nice to find a space game that I can be moderately good at. Everything is put together pretty well, and while some may call it too simple; I find it works in the game's favor. Space games these days feel the need to overcomplicate themselves, and Rebel Galaxy avoids that.

reviewText:
I know it isn't technically a RPG but it feels like a RPG. And it is a short RPG at that. This is a good thing. If you don’t want 100+h RPGish game this is a good game for you. The gameplay loop, trade/do missions -> buy new/better gear -> repeat, sustains the game for the duration.  At the last main story mission, I felt satisfied. If it had been any longer I might have gotten bored. That being said I would probably buy an expiation containing a new tier of ships, so I could play ten more hours.

The music is unexpectedly perfect, slide guitar.

I like this game.

reviewText:
After playing several hours of this game I can say without a doubt, Rebel Galaxy is AMAZING.

*It's the perfect blend of action packed navel combat with dynamic trade economy.
If you thought X was an interesting concept, but though that the gameplay felt like doing spread sheets in a 3D shooting gallery, then look no further, Rebel Galaxy is your game.

*The combat is fun and easy to pick up, with its Black Flag style broadside combat, but has alot of depth and strategy aswell. I found that a fast frigate could out do a powerful, lumbering dreadknoght with speed and manuverability, or that using your ship's suppior broadside's range could keep you out of harms way.

*The economy is dynamic and interesting but not overly complicated cough cough X!" and scoping out trade roughts in the games massive
date: proceduraly generated universe was alot of fun.\n\n*The style was another big draw with it's awesome southern rock/blues/country soundtrack and it's wild west
recommended: bad-side of town vibe. Not to mention
hoursPlayed: the ship models are fantastic!\n\n*The game also has alot of choice for missions and encounters. Do you help the pirates take down the merchant for a haul of loot
voteText: or do you take a stand and protect the merchant to increase your reputation with the citizens?\n\n*And finnaly
helpfulPercent: the devs are great. They're helpful and dedicated and constantly patching the game and listening to the community\n\nIn the end

votesFunny: swashbuckling adventure sure to keep you flyin' for along time."

reviewText: Very easy to get into, casual to play, with enough depth to keep you interested and keep coming back for more. I found the game mechanics to make sense, the controls easy enough to figure out with explanations  what controls do what in the menu. This isn't Elite Dangerous or something hardcore and it's not meant to be. As example, to keep the fighting engaging and keep tactics interesting, the game employs an old style sailing ships battling by broadsides method of combat. I've read some reviews noting this as a bad or lazy mechanism... I found it wonderfully engaging and allowing battles to feel epic. I'm able to pick the game up after weeks of not playing and jump right in. Fun times! The soundtrack is absolutely fantastic to boot.

I'm a bad guy. I really am. And the fact that you can rack up with some of the toughest guys in the game and still beable to manage the story well enough just makes this great. reviewText:
Takes the fun/addictive elements of freeform space sims while avoiding the over-complexity of some of these titles (such as the X-series). As usual you start with an underequipped ship and earn money for better weapons/systems, new ships, and even mercenary support if you want it. You can earn money via missions (randomly generated and storyline), trading, mining, piracy or bounty hunting; it's up to you if you want to stay the right side of the law or if you aim to misbehave. It's worth noting that your starting ship is a corvette and the ship classes only get bigger from there on (right up to massive dreadnoughts). Because you're always commanding a large ship, combat is very different from a fighter-focused space sim and as others have pointed out it the 2D movement gives a 'naval battle in space' feel to it (though faster paced); it actually works pretty well, making the battles very fun to play - which is a good thing, because there is a lot of combat in this game.

Visually this has a beautiful-looking universe, some spectular space battles and a wide variety of nice ship designs (from Serenity-style rustbuckets to more conventional-looking starships). I like the fact that the different ships cater to different playstyles -  bigger isn't necessarily better as there are other factors like speed, manouverabilty and weapon placement, so instead of a linear progression to the 'best' ship, people will find their own favorite ships along the way.

There are some aspects of the game that could do with some improvement such as the scaling of encounters and missions - the actual difficulty of missions doesn't always seem to match the stated risk level. Also it's quite possible to get into fights where the only chance of survival is to run, especially at the beginning of the game; though this is not a bad thing in itself, the fact that the game pops up a combat tutorial note on your first fight (even if you're totally outmatched) could confuse new players into thinking they should always be able to win their first battle. I can see why the single checkpoint-type save is controversial, but personally I'm fine with a single save AS LONG AS there is some backup in case of corrupt saves - fortunately haven't had a corrupted save yet, but would be pretty peeved if this happened after hours of play.

The slide-guitar soundtrack does help create that 'wild frontier' Firefly vibe, but it also starts to get a bit old after about 10 hours - fortunately there is an option to stream your own music - looks like a cool idea, but haven't tested it yet myself.

Overall this is probably the most enjoyable space game I've played since Freelancer.

This game was made for consoles and it shows through the entire game.  The mouse and keyboard work well enough....  But you can tell in so many places that it could work so much better and do so much better with a PC in mind.

You buy and sell gear at the same price.  So you can experiment without punishment.
Very very few weapon types to pick from.  Your lucky if you get more 2 choices for the rest of the gear.  It seems to cap at maybe 3 options for everything else (shields, armor, engines....)
Felt like alot more variety in terms in ships.

Does have decent voice acting.  But the story goes by fast and thats the only part that has it.

reviewText:
This game is both oddly addictive and frustrating.  Hours of play go by without me noticing, but every time something annoys - combat mechanics, navigation, etc.

The good:

Right out of the gate, you can do stuff.  You’re not limping around with crappy, starter equipment very long. The first couple missions are just challenging enough, and give you a decent reward to do some upgrades.  There’s no dishonor in running away from fights until you get good enough equipment to fight back.

It’s really is immersive, and I love that you can play your own custom soundtrack which enhances that. I haven’t done much with the main story yet, having too much fun tooling around the galaxy doing side missions and exploring stuff.

Equipment upgrades don’t depreciate, so you can sell them back for the same as the purchase price.  This is great when you’re starting out and just figuring out the game mechanics.  It eliminates those costly newbie mistakes that handicap you as you advance.

The annoying:

Some of the mechanics clunky.  For example: When mining, you blow up the asteroid then have to go hunting for what pops out using the pulse feature, boost your way to the loot (being careful not to overshoot it), then painstakingly angle into the sweet spot that will auto trigger your tractor beam. I’d really like to be able to target stuff manually and then grab it.

I have to agree with other reviews about the lack of Y axis. It is really frustrating, particularly in a big firefight when you have a swarm of nimble enemy fighters attacking you at all angles, disappearing along the vertical just as you go to nail them and all you can do swing from side to side, waiting for them to get back to the horizontal

Difficulty ratings are a crap shoot as far as accuracy.  I’ve gotten my tail kicked on a “low” risk mission and blown right through a “high” risk mission.

Misc:
The game doesn’t recognize my Xbox 360 wireless controller (which works with other Steam games), but does recognize my old Logitech F310 USB gamepad.  I find that handles the game better than K&M.

Be a mercenary, pirate, militia, police the galaxy, space trucker... you can do it all!

4. PROFIT!

reviewText:
Disclosure: I received the key from the devs a few days before release.


Pros:
-Amazing interface that works perfectly with both Mouse+Keyboard and gamepads.
-Easy to follow Video+text tutorials simmilar to those in Deus Ex Human revolution.
-Addictive combat on a 2D plane but with a twist: fighters and gunships evade fire in 3D, which opens up more room for specialized weapons. (and the developers capitalized on that fact)
-Everything is voiceacted. And it's good :)
-Progression is slow but steady. It will take you dozens of hours to get the best ship & gear but since you constantly advance a weapon turret here and a subsystem there it will feel a lot less grindy.
-Progression is completely open and the campaign reacts to your behaviour (so, if you choose to be a pirate it just works!)
-You can mix your on audio files to the soundtrack collection and even differentiate Combat, Station, Ambient and other types of music usage.

Cons:
-I would have really loved this to be a $40+ title with even more ships, factions and better skyboxes. (then again, I was convinced this game would be $30 AT LEAST, so it's still amazing)
-I wish it had multiplayer

reviewText:
TL;DR: A solid, arcade space privateer game that'll scratch the itch of many a space cowboy out there, complete with excellent music to fit the theme. Fans of space games (or Firefly) may find a charmer right here for a price that wont break your wallet too hard.
+ Solid gameplay mechanics and progression that'll keep you busy for hours, having fun being your own space captain. Solid combat (deflector shield = timed block, broadside ship combat), calming (if flashy) mining, and cutthroat trading are all here. Be a Han Solo, or a Boba Fett, or more.

+ Quirky singleplayer storyline, but as with an open-space game like this, you can easily ignore it and go your own way. Think Skyrim + Space Cowboy and you're not far off.

+ Colorful and unique art direction for environments, ships, and characters that you meet. Ships and weapons have clear design lines they follow. Enemies are color-coded for easy identification. Space is colorful and interesting to look at. Damage on ships is well-rendered, complete with breaches in the hull, burning, and metal skeletal remains in impact holes. Weapons are visually impactful, and can be clearly discerned in the heat of combat.

+ Characters you meet have a lot to say, voice-acted too, complete wtih unique alien languages to boot!

+ Excellent cowboy" music that sets the mood perfectly
date: firing at the perfect time. Crescendos with the right track for high-intensity combat. Drops it down to a mellow tule when in station. A forlorn tune for when travelling. Its perfect

- Camera is too zoomed in. Its difficult to keep situational awareness when the camera zooms so far in you cant see your entire ship anymore

Okay, so i've bought this game because i was incredibly bored and wanted something to be able to wait for Fallout 4 with i am glad i did.

reviewText:
Okay, so i've bought this game because i was incredibly bored and wanted something to be able to wait for Fallout 4 with i am glad i did.

Something that you probably need to know, is that this is kind of close to a simpler version of Elite: Dangerous, and honestly, i have had much more fun with it than i had with Elite: Dangerous, i'm glad this game is this simple; i've had problems with Elite: Dangerous because it was so complex and hard to get into, just to learn the games controls took a long time, but this game i could easily get used to it.

This game is alot of fun, and deserves the price it's put up for, i'm glad i bought it.

reviewText:
Be a mercenary, pirate, militia, police the galaxy, space trucker... you can do it all!

This is basically Sid Meier's Pirates! in space. It's brilliant, accessible, and deeper than you think. An amazing space action game.

Space Pirate 101:

1. Find a space trader
2. Sell goods to trader
3. Threaten trader and take their cargo (including what you sold to them!)
4. PROFIT!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
There is something incredibly satisfying in aligning your ship alongside another and unleashing every single broadside cannon you have. In combination with the incredible music giving every fight you take a Wild West spin; you truly are on the lawless outskirts of space.

You start with nothing and climb all the way to the top in any way you want. Trader, Miner, Mercenary, Pirate. Just be careful who you make enemies with, anything goes in this game.

On the subject of trading, Rebel Galaxy contains a simple yet effective trading system with market values that will change in response to local events. Discover trade routes from station to station, capitalise on resource shortages, a station currently being blockaded will be in desperate need of supplies.

When you feel strong enough, use a jump gate to travel to one of the many other systems. Make sure you are prepared though; higher risk brings higher reward but you won’t be smiling facing a Dreadnought class ship armed to the teeth.

This game stands out as one of its quirks is that it is locked on a 2D plane, honestly I think this brings its benefits. You're at the helm of a capital ship, you wouldn't be doing amazing tricks. It also simplifies the controls, meaning you can focus less on keeping the ship level and more on the actual fight.

Just listen to the soundtrack, it completes this game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IBAYW0WGKtE&index=1&list=PLvJV9BRNJsmVdv17rkxzUuy6jdB7oQXch

reviewText:
Decent game, Looks great, plays great and is overall fun.  You will say two things while playing this game.

#1  Great i just got dropped out of warp again within five feet from the last group of enemies that just dropped me out of warp,

#2  I don't understand why the game even bothers to give you options to buy better shields and weps. Enemies get through your shield in seconds and your weps never get through the enemies shields fast enough.  It's annoying to have to constantly having to fix your hull and buy ammo.


Like I said, good game overall for a sp game.  It's a shame the developer added more mobs that jump you every five feet instead of a story that works or better combat mechanics.

Plus there is little to no replay value for this game, replaying this game gives you nothing new and the story is a one way trip.

I would wait until this game is on the 5$ discount rack.   It's not worth the price they are asking.

reviewText:
Short : its like elite-freelancer with more soul (firefly like) on 2D plane with different combat mechanics.
Overall i realy like the game, below in points:

1-Very nice mood. Its really got that Firefly mood. Teh galaxy is alive, plenty of events that affect the game (for example a holiday wiht gifts custom on a planet means certain items will have very high price etc ), you can get tips from bartendes, hire mercenraies, help traders under attack and get rewards from them etc. I liked Elite but tough beatifull, it felt a bit sterile and souless to me. Here i love it,The music is quite unusual for this type of game, inmstead of electronic trance-ambient you got hard rocking blues. I love it, tough if you dont dig rock/blues might a problem.
2- Open end game. Follow the story or just take missions, bounty hunt trade, whatever you like. Plenty of ships and upgrades.
3-Ship control is unusual. It looks 3d but in truth is a 2d plane.You got a third person view , Eve online like, but you must aim in combat.
4-Combat: its quite unusual and initially i was disspointed by it , i yearned for full 3d and standard cockpit view. But at some point something clicked  and i began to really like it.Its broadside based,  you can aslo control turrets.
5- The graphics are nice, and i ahvent run into many bugs (i think i crashed once)

If you are past Privateer/Elite/Freelancer fan, i think you should enjoy it very much, tough i recommend wathing vids to see the unusual ship control/combat in action.

reviewText:
Wasn't paid for my review.  Let's get that out there in the open.  *pushes beer under his bed with his feet, all slick-like*

AHEM


The game is a prettier, more entertaining version of Space Rangers.  You can choose to slay pirates, trade comodities, or mine your way into a larger, faster, more powerful ship all pimped out with the latest murder gadgets ranging from flak guns to missle turrets.  Broadside firing is a nice plus in the middle of battle while all the other guns are auto targeting.  Lots and lots of fun.


Pros:

+Lots of upgrades
+Lots of stuff to explore/hack/kill
+Space is beautiful and makes me wee nips perky
+Tons of missions
+Lots of ship variations (Though I'm limited on what I can see this early in)
+Battles need finger dex and quick reflexes when against more powerful ships (I'm assuming controller is easier)
+Character models are pretty cool
+Warp auto disables when you get to target, so no need for timed disengages
+Customize firing/targeting for auto-turrets as you move into a good firing position for broadside
+Battles can be rather long, but hella enjoyable when you beat out capital ships with crappy weapons/armor
+Love the western-rock music vibe


Cons:

-Missions are the samethings over and over
-Autosaving only kicks in when you dock, so DOCK OFTEN or exit to force autosave
-Warps disengaging due to pirate ambushes are no bueno early in game
-Warps disengaging in mine fields is no bueno
-Warps disengaging in electrical storms is no bueno
-Warps disengaging in astroid belts is no bueno
-Auto plotting courses would be nifty
-Dev is buying reviews with early access codes all illuminati-like
-Didn't come with beer


I give the game 5 Landsharks out of a 6 pack

reviewText:
A short learning curve, but the games throws you into the action fast in a universe where you can't count on everthing you run into to be 'in your league'. After getting smoked A LOT, I learned how to judge fights quickly and get away if I stepped in something too deep. Looking forward to seeing if the trade system gets deep, but just as a shooter it's great.

First, it's 2D space, if that isn't obvious from the videos- but there's good reason for it. INstead of traditional 'chase them and try to shoot their ♥♥♥' style dogfighting, it's battleship style broadside combat with an interesting fighter/gunnery system where your turrets can be set to auto or manually controlled as needed.

Loving this game. Recommend a gamepad, I use an Xbox 360 controller. Tons of fun with it, and the controls are well mapped (although I find myself constantly forgetting about where to find what I need between the Start menu and Y meu)

reviewText:
The game is basically meditation (flying) punctuated by spur of the moment naval-broadside combat (your capital ship versus pirates). The core narrative and the bartenders (talk to them at each station) breathe life into the game.

The music while flying around at warp speed has been a really relaxing experience (something I rarely want from a game, but it works here).

Also: I've seen a lot of people trying to make Firefly references and I can tell you this game has nothing to do with Firefly aside from the space cowboy music and that you happen to be a captain of your own ship. There's nothing in the galaxy or story that is similar and you won't have a big crew of interesting people (which is what made Firefly the show that it is).

Play the game for what it is: space trading with naval broadside combat. If that sounds interesting, I think you'll find your money well spent (especially if you pick it up on sale).

reviewText:
It's what the first Starpoint Gemini would have been if it wasn't developed by slav♥♥♥♥♥, but with a spaghetti-western twang to it.
This is NOTHING AT ALL LIKE FREELANCER.
This game is NOTHING AT ALL LIKE ANYTHING IN ASASSIN'S CREED.
This game is NOTHING LIKE COWBOY BEBOP OR FIREFLY... it just has a couple tracks featuring a guitar --- ooooooooooh that's firefly! ooooooooooooh ride my hype-stick ooooooooooooh space cowboys - no... just no... it's Starpoint Gemini with a country track in the mix.

Do not ride people's hype trains, because actual flavors of what people hype up like that simply don't exist.

Which all-in-all is very very sad because thig game has a lot of good things going for it that stand out on it's own without being lumped into incredibly vauge and generalized references... just don't expect as much as people are claiming is there, because again, it simply isn't.

GAMEPLAY:
Quick. Don't expect tonnes of hours unless you force yourself to drag the game out.

Fun. Really fun - I couldn't put it down for the irst few days (then I beat the story and stopped caring because I had the best ship and gear, period)

Equally proffitable to trade or fight your way up (I got lucky abnd kept finding clouds of things called  ace of gozu" so my fight-intended gameplay did turn to occasional crude mining to leap forward in the game FAST)

All of the exact flippin' same mechanics from Starpoint Gemini
date:
meaning the whole game takes place on a two-dimensional plane... in space...

CONS:
Well I honestly hate how much like the first Starpoint Gemini it is. It's often distracting

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy: Fun but not Deep or Wide
Short version:
Arcadey 3rd person space shooter.
Simple plot with no twists or choices.
Entertaining but repetitive combat system.
Very basic ship customization.
Context:
I had just finished playing through Skyrim, a one-and-done game, and was looking for something completely different. Small scope, not fantasy, but a better role-playing experience. Because face it: trying to role play in Skyrim is just silly. What I found in Rebel Galaxy was a refreshing change of pace with no commitments.

Experience:
Starting out it really reminded me of Privateer crossed with Earth & Beyond. Loved the former and wanted to love the latter. I tried to role play (I wanted to be a bloodthirsty pirate) but the pirates weren't welcoming and money was tight so I went with Merchant and Mercenary after my first save game corrupted. For a little while I tried to get into the events" and trading but the simple math of the game finally proved itself out. Upgrade

The music is really good at first - setting your mind in the "Firefly" wild west mentality. Then it gets a little repetitive. Rather like the same 6-8 talking heads. I never got bored enough to switch to custom music and I did find myself humming some of the tunes at work.

Gameplay:
For a few hours the non-combat mechanics are worth exploring. Mine some asteroids. Jump from station to station moving commodities. Shop the mercenaries. Experience the array of 6-8 mission types. It didn't take long to get a handle on deciding what's worth it in risk vs. reward - factoring in time

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy is an amazing game if you enjoy space games. Although it is quite enjoyable, it has several major flaws.
Although I played the game for 20+ hours, the game story line is extremely short and only last this long because of the grind required to progress. The game feels a little bit like a free to play where you are constantly gated and required to upgrade your ship, weapon and defenses before being able to progress.
Here are my opinions on the game.

Pros:
Enjoyable combat system
Interesting story
Nice progression system
Good music
Combat SFX are very good

Cons:
Very limited character voices
Only 1 portrait per race
Radio static communication SFX is terrible
Story is extremely short
Game requires a lot of grinding
Very very limited choices on actions and discussion
Merchant and mercenary guild discussions are extremely plain, the progression of ranks do not unlock anything discussion wise.

I have mixed opinions on these:
You can finish the game with MK5 gear with ease.
MK6 is just bonus to farm for which will remove any challenge from the game


In the end, I loved playing rebel galaxy, and I streongly recommend it. I personally bought the game when it was 33% off.
If you enjoy these types of space games, do get it. Its just a shame that the game had soo much potential and ended up being so much less than it could have been.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I've played a lot of similar games.  This one carries a feel of a western in space.  It has some of the ambience of Firefly, but the multi-alien world setting you'd expect more from Starwars.  I wont claim that it is a polished gem, the likes of which you've never seen.  But I will say, I had a lot of fun with it once I got past the mild learning curve.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game has the understanding that many of the more recent space sims do not, namely that a living world creates immersion and that the major component for creating a living world consists of real voices, simulating communication with the player. Add to it some hearty music and Rebel Galaxy feels warm and alive, unlike its much more expensive predecessors.

The main gameplay feature that sets this space sim apart from all others is that the battle happens with Black Flag type naval combat, where the ship stays on a flat plain and fires cannons from the sides. While the system does work, part of what I love about space sims so much is the freedom to fly anywhere and by restricting the movement to a plain, you are cutting at the core of what is interesting about space sims.

Beyond that, it is a fairly standard space sim with some trading, a central plot, side missions, ship upgrades, etc.

My main issue with the game at the moment is its saving behavior. At the time of this review, the game saves whenever you quit the game and there is only one save. This means 2 things: 1. you cannot load a previous game if you mess up and 2. if anything happens to your save, you are screwed. This means you can't really have fun and experiment because the results of your experiments are on your permanent record. Dear developers, please add a normal save game feature.

reviewText:
TL;DR
If you like economics / 2D naval style combat / challenge, get this game.
It's worth more than you're paying.

Pros:
This game feels highly polished for the ~$20 price tag.
Economics function quite well, are not random, and you can earn Credits fairly quickly once you see the patterns. (i.e. if there's a Militia Embargo on an outpost, bring it military style products for a nice profit)
The ships are interesting and specialized. You feel accomplished when you get the next awesome ship and throw some killer components on it.
Computer requirements are well within reach for most PC gamers.
^>It feels very optimized and lag is infrequent.
The graphics aren't comparable to BF4 but, it's a very pretty game.
The story, though not entirely compelling at first, is well written as are the characters for their minimalistic impact on the game.
There's been ZERO glitching. That's just fantastic.

Cons:
Difficulty may seem overwhelming at first but, you'll quickly understand the importance of picking your battles and what upgrades are needed. Until you learn to broadside properly, high-range turrets will be your best friend.
I can't really think of any others at the moment. I've been having a really good time. :)

Suggestions:
Co-op Play would be EPIC in larger scale confrontations.
When on the Commodity Window make a sortable LIST of the other outposts you've visited and their pricing instead of the slow here's the price at this location" rotation. I've spent far too much time just sitting in my chair waiting for the outpost i want to see prices for pop up without having to go back into space and look at it on my map.
The distance between the sides of your ship and stellar masses when trying to warp is too great. Front space is wonderful but
date: if i can turn my Radovich completely sideways and not hit what made my warp stop that's a problem.\n\nAlso
recommended:
a question to the Devs;
Did a few members of your team REALLY enjoy "Armada" for the Dreamcast? Because this feels like what that game should have been. I loved that game when it came out and put far too much time into it and this feels heavily influenced by it.


Comp specs:
AMD FX-6300 OC'd to 4.5GHz
Radeon R9 280 OC'd to 280x specs
Ultra setting
hoursPlayed: Full Screen
voteText: 1080p = 140FPS most of the time."

reviewText:
Its not so much a space sim as an ARPG with space ships. But trading, mining, bounty hunting, piracy and even faction relations are all here. Sure, it takes place on a 2D plane, but the broadside combat more than makes up for that.

Customize your ship. Buy new ships. Chat with shady aliens. Run from the law or side with it. And maybe even find your Aunt Juno while you're at it.

Its a dangerous galaxy out there.

In a word: Shiny.

reviewText:
Not only is this game inspired by one of the single greatest television shows ever made, Firefly, but it also is one of the single greatest games ever made. It's combat mechanics are normal, yes, but they still feel new. If your playing on a mouse and keyboard, I highly recomend that you get some sort of controller. Trust me, the game gets at least 80% better with the smooth movements of a controller's anolog sticks.

Other aspects of epicness include its BADASS style. the graphics, gameplay, and ESPECIALLY music compliment this games similarity to Firefly. The only difference being that there are aliens, its rock type music instead of pure country, and the combat is space based, as opposed to firefly's ground based combat.

Speaking of music, it's amazing. It may have been made before this game came out, but its almost as if it was MADE for this thing. (link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nSkh6g5ksvc ) Its a mix of western country, and hard rock, and it practically is a music album that comes packaged with a game.

All in all, 9/10, minus one because I havent gotten too far into it yet, but so far so good. I'll make an edit once ive completed it, and I'm pretty sure (or at least I hope) it'll get a 10/10

column20: I enjoyed not needing a spreadsheet or helper tool to deck out my ride.\n\nAnd my big gripe that kills this game for replayability: no choices. I ran a straight line from beginning to end with some grinding (a lot
column21: really
column22: in the early game). No impact. No changes. The galaxy just rolls along without the events making any real impact or change. The story is alright but predictable. I was relieved when I saw the end of it.\n\nOne and done. Worth the $20 I dropped on it. No replayability but the once-through was fun."

reviewText:
Freelancer with badass capital ships.

Absolutely spectacular experience crafted predominantly by two (!!) geniuses.

Trade, pirate, mine, bounty hunt and complete various types of missions in a procedurally generated universe for cash.  Use that cash to buy a bigger and meaner ship and/or choose from tons of interesting and tactical diverse upgrades.   Topped with very deep and visceral combat that has juuust the right balance of automated and skill based systems.

Bottom line:  No game has ever captured capital spaceship combat quite like Rebel Galaxy and I can't wait to see where the devs take the series.
