reviewText:
Oh my, what fun!

So I read the reviews with people saying this game is like a mix of Freelancer, Firefly and Assassins Creed IV (the naval combat sections) and I guess those are pretty good comparison.

The game certainly has the Freelancer vibe, with an open universe, optional story-line, combat, trading, rep/guild affiliation etc.

The Firefly comparisons I think stem mainly from the music, but given you are flying a large vessel (not a smaller fighter) you do feel like you are captaining a ship with crew. and yes, you can 'aim to misbehave'

Combat and travel is strictly 2D, but before you judge that too harshly, it plays our like ship combat from AC IV, with broadside combat being the order of the day.

And it WORKS!

It actually reminds me of the animated movie Treasure Planet a bit. Oh yeah, I am totally now a space pirate!

Controller support is well implemented and I don't need to touch my keyboard to play (other than to hit 'play').

Just shy of 2 hours in and barely scratched the surface, but based on what I have seen so far, this game could charge at least double the current price and still be good value.

Recommended.

reviewText:
This is a pretty good space RPG. In addition to the main campaign quest, you pretty much go around the galaxy accepting different bounties so that you can upgrade your ship and complete the harder quests in the campaign. Almost all the bounties are combat-type bounties.

You can also acquire money through trade on the commodities market, but it can be very time-consuming. The key to commodities trading is finding out what outposts will pay the highest for various products. For instance, a scientific oytposts will pay higher for intellectual property and tech stuff, but a rogue or outlaw outposts will pay more for illicit drugs and whatnot. You can also gain trading info by reading news boards and speaking to bartenders. Traveling between space stations and various parts of the galaxy can be boring. It can take several minutes to travel between points on opposite sides of the galaxy.

The graphics are nice and the music is awesome, but it gets a little monotonous after awhile since it plays constantly on a loop throughout the entire game.

The combat is interesting. It is naval-style" combat
date: which means your primary guns fire from the side. This imposes a significant learning curve to combat since you have to fight sideways
recommended: which makes it harder to see incoming missiles. There are secondary weapons that you can switch to that don't require sideways combat
hoursPlayed: but then you have to constantly adjust your ship angle if you switch weapons a lot. It is challenging but rewarding when you finally get it all down.\n\nRebel Galaxy is a fun and nice alternative to most space sims that require a lot of management and alliance building over a long period of time. Rebel Galaxy commences with all that by giving you a campaign and a ship. The rest is up to you."

reviewText:
If this game felt any more like Firefly it would be Firefly!

The game is brightly colored, beautiful to look at, sounds great, and has an enjoyable soundtrack.  All of which come together to give you that feeling of a western in space.

You can make your way by trading, scavenging, performing missions, bounty hunting, and what we have all come here for really..... FIGHTING! All so you can afford that next ship upgrade.  But maybe you should save your credits for that bigger ship with the extra firepower and a slightly bigger cargo bay.

All in all this is a fun game that gave me nearly 40 hours of gameplay just on the story and some sidequests alone, and if I wanted to there are still more things I could buy and more ships I could upgrade to because the game doesn't finish when the storyline does.

reviewText:
I didn't know quite what to expect. But from the trailer it looked like it would be an absolute wild ride.

It is.

I don't know what pulled me in more: The incredible soundtrack, which while somewhat short, never ever got old and always pumped me up for taking on a whole enemy flotilla single-handedly while being completely out-classed and out-gunned. Or the visuals which are stunning from the very beginning.

This game has hit a perfect spot of being scifi and western: a playable Firefly. It keeps you enthralled even after you finish the story. The developers really hit spot on on the idea of purely enjoyable gameplay. It's not complex and convoluted. It's not necessarily simple either. you have to think about how you approach your enemy. What weapons are best, do you go with massive firepower or shield and hull strength? A middle ground? How can a small cruiser take on a dreadnought 5 times it's size without getting obliterated?

There are a couple pseudo-downsides, other than the (epic) short soundtrack,

The first somewhat downside to this game is that because it's their first one (as far as i can tell), they weren't able to make it bigger, or the story longer. There isn't much character development, however they put a LOT of thought into what was there, such as if you listen to the alien languages, you can actually pick up what words mean what in the translations. I'm a language nerd and that scored MAJOR points for me.

The other downside is that you have to get used to it not being a 'realistic' space game, since you are playing on a flat plane, you cannot do spins or attack from above or below as you would imagine being able to in theoretical 'real' space combat.
But the gameplay is so fun that, at least for myself, i completely discarded that particular misgiving and simply had fun with it.

This is quite honestly one of the best games i've played in YEARS, i can't recommend it more.

reviewText: After reading reviews about this game being successor to the freelancer classic, I bought the game. The first few hours of game was quite disappointing as the 2D flight mode and the lukeworm story can hardly convince me that this game is even comparable to freelancer. After 5 hours, however, the game became a little more interesting as weapons and ships are unlocked and some of the missions are quite interesting. I have to admit the graphics are good, not superb, but comparable to the freelance --- a shame on its own as the freelancer was a game almost two decades old. The combat system was not inspiring but acceptable and admittedly quite fun to play. Just as I thought the game is getting better, it quickly revealed to me that this is no more than a freelancer game in its core repacked with better graphics and a toned down 2D flight mode. The game soon degenerates into a struggling effort to complete repetitive missions to gain enough money to upgrade ships and components that are ridiculously expensive and are so for no other apparent reasons than to compel the player to complete those stupid missions. So far I think it is unrealistic to make enough money to buy any of those higher level weapons and ships with trade alone. The difficulty associated with some of these missions are also questionable as some missions would see you quickly swarmed by a horde of overpowered enemies ships while other missions give ridiculously high reward for the simpler tasks.\n\nIn conclusions, I believe this is a game suitable, in fact I would use the word ideal, for killing your excessive pastime at a moderate price. However, to comment that this game may even aspire to be of the equal to freelancer is a severe overstatement.

reviewText:
Shallow.

On the surface this game is fantastic. I want to love it. The soundtrack makes you feel like a space cowboy right at the main menu. The designs manage to sell you on this gritty space society without feeling messy or cluttered. The gameplay premiss seems like a fresh twist on a working concept... and here things fall apart.

It has an interesting idea of broadside combat in a freelancer type space sim, but it fails to achieve either. Whatever there is to master in this game is mastered in under an hour, and it basically comes down to have bigger guns and better shields". Any fancy manouvers will only give the enemy time to recharge their shields or let them turn their undamaged sides towards you. Just fly up and hammer them harder while your turrets autoshoot any fighters. After that you just repeat the same interactions over and over to earn cash towards upgrades that add +stat% . You can feel safe taking any mission that has a danger rating you've dealt with before
date: because they scale with you and nothing ever changes.\n\nEven more dissapointing is the fact that there is virtually no point or reason to fight or do missions as it's slow and tedious
recommended: forcing you to cover large distances of empty space. Just find the trade route that is currently most profitable per minute and fly it back and forth until it drains to make atleast 10x in an hour what you could have gotten from missions during the same time. This way you'll never make enemies either!\n\nAlso
hoursPlayed: dont buy anything but cargo or cargospace boosts. ♥♥♥♥ is super expensive and serves no point. You basically don't have to fight ever if your goal is to become the biggest bad ♥♥♥ in space. Some light shields and an engine will do fine! Any investments in your ship will just take money away from buying up expensive cargo. Then
voteText:
when you made all the money there is to make from trade runs where you interact with absolutely no one... buy the most expensive ♥♥♥♥ you can find. Voila! You are now the best at this game and nothing can hurt you!

The best part? Maybe you got a bit eager and there was more money to be made? Bigger ships to be found? Better guns? And now all you trading captial is gone? NO PROBLEM! Just sell all your ship parts AT COST and become a peacful trader again.

You could just do this at any point when you wanted to actually kill something. You never have to feel invested in anything! Choices have no consequence or impact. Life is great in space! Except for all that emptyness and boredom you will feel. They really captured that part...
"

reviewText:
First and foremost I'm not a paid reviewer/streamer/critic or any of that. I was blessed enough to receive a key for free eventhough I will buy multiple copies of this for my family/friends. Just being upfront about it but I played in the beta and pre-release so my review is coming from all my experience with the game. Now onto the review.

Ever since the rlease of Freelancer on PC way back in 2000, I have been aching for a new space sim experience. If your like me and also have that itch then look no further. This game has pirating/trading/looting/mining/space battles.... a whole slew of things you can do in the sandbox that they have created for you.

There are several systems or galaxies in which you traverse and have jump gates to connect them. Each system has its own factions with which to either befriend or destroy. You have a main story but also space stations with side missions along with the included Trading/Mining/Mercenary guilds which also provide missions. These three factions also provide unique ships, weapons, shields, and other things to outfit your ship. The combat is likened to naval style (think Assassins Creed Black Flag ship battles) and its set on a 2d plane.

The art style, ship design, space backdrops are all top notch. The audio is also one thing that is a step above. The soundtrack alone warrants a look at this game. It gives the feel of a space fairing outlaw lol. Think Firefly, Han Solo, Cowboy Bebop, Outlaw Star vibe. The sounds of the weapons firing gives a sense of real power and gurth behind each barrage launched from your broadside cannons. The best sound to me is when your FTL drive spools up and then hits warp.

This game has been on my radar for some time now as my top 5 most anticipated games of 2015. I knew that Travis and Erich who left Runic Games to establish Double Damage wouldn't let me down. If you have any interest, what are you waiting for help these two Devs out by purchasing this amazing experience! I know I will be purchasing copies for my friends and family and for only 20$ US you can't beat that deal. The price for value is one of the best of 2015 alone. Do your self a favor and play it.

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the Game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m1Sz7SlU428

One of the best space adventures I've played in 2015.... don't miss this gem of a game. Rebel Galaxy is a swashbuckling space adventure, with action-packed combat, exploration, discovery, trade, and “negotiation” with the outlandish denizens at the edge of the known universe.

As the commander of an immensely powerful star destroyer, you’ll battle pirates, explore anomalies, befriend aliens, scavenge battle wreckage, mine asteroids, and discover artifacts. Choose your path as a roguish do-gooder, crafty space-trader or power-hungry privateer – or maybe a little of each! Buy larger and more powerful craft with your hard-earned credits, and outfit them with a variety of wicked weapons and defenses. Set in a galaxy of fantastic sights, and secrets to be found, Rebel Galaxy is above all a space epic of adventure, exploration, and combat.

The edge of the universe is a pretty dangerous place, so watch your back. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:

reviewText: Such a fun game. Compared to other space titles around at the time, Elite, Star Citizen, Star Conflict, No Man's Sky, and a host of others surfacing and submerging, this game stands out first to me the fact that it's single player. Shock horror. If you can get over that, it's fantastic.\nI can't stress enough what a masterpiece the devs have done as far as software goes. Produced in a ridiculously short time, by the guys that brought us diablo, and then torchlight. Install's 2Gb, and run's so smooth even on a low end laptop. Has controller support, also (personally i love the controller controls on this title, well thought out, the commands are simple enough to just get stuck in). The controls overall aren't gratuitously complex. There aren't as many menus to cycle through as other games, and this doesn't feel like a bad thing, or that you're missing things. The combat is great fun. Winning or losing, it just FEELS good, with an awesome soundtrack to accompany it. Basically, in my view, while i enjoy say, elite, for a long term, sim"

reviewText:
Great game. Reminds me of the assassin creed black flag ship combat combined with freelancer. The story is pretty weak but the tall ship combat combined with lots of upgrades makes it a fun time. The soundtrack is an amazing firefly-esq western score.

A couple downsides:
-Nothing really to do after 20 hours (maybe 30 hours for achievement completionists)
-No real reason to explore (no secret gates that I could find like freelancer)
-Biggest issue: No crew interactions or upgradable crew. This would be a fantastic improvement.
-Some balancing issues (minor)

Overall, I recommend. Especially for $10-20.

reviewText:
Well, I bought this on a whim, but it turns out, money was never better spent.

All in all, I would defintely recommend it to anyone who's wanted to fly their own starship in a mostly lawless zone. If you've ever played Tachyon: The Fringe, you're going to love this game.

I know that quite a few might be turned away due to the thing's lack of vertical flight. Put simply, the lack of a vertical axis isn't a drawback - it's a feature. The kind of ships you'll be in charge of, you won't need a vertical axis.

I'll list out the good stuff and the bad. Hopefully that'll help.

The Good:-
1) Low-cost title that plays like a AAA game.
2) Fast-paced and simple to learn.
3) Quirky in many aspects.
4) Great soundtrack, with an obvious inspiration from Firefly.
5) Very nice ship design, and a used-up feel that's surprisingly cozy.

The Neutral:-
1) Star-systems aren't particularly unique, but the graphical detail and insanity offsets that to quite some extent.
2) Trading and Mining are viable alternatives to a kill-em-all blitz, but it can be boring or tedious after a point.
3) Fairly interesting characters, but their full potential was never realised.
4) Cash is something weird - either so much that you don't know what to do, or too little, resulting in you getting outgunned.
5) Mercenaries are a nice touch, but again - like the main characters - not realised to their full potential.

The Bad:-
1) Some missions can be hilariously broken, and tougher than they look, which can cause hair-pulling at times.
2) Rather short single-player campaign.
3) Can be slightly boring after a certain point, though not too bad.
4) No further development on this title, it would seem. Hopefully there'll be more on this after some time.

Definitely give it a try. You won't regret it!

Even with these complaints, ill give this game a 7/10. If they are fixed id say 8.5/10

reviewText: Rebel Galaxy is a very entertaining adventure space 'simulator'.  More adventure than Elite Dangerous and easier to jump into for a quick session.  Many aspects of the game are similar to Elite Dangerous, but in RG you only move in two demensions instead of all three.  But the 2 dimensions of movement is implemented in a way that doesn't leave me missing the 3rd dimension.  A bit more arcade than a space simulator, but you don't have to worry about dealing with the real-size of space and how long it takes to navigate it as you do in Elite D. (but that's one of the things I often enjoy about Elite!).\n\nWell worth the price and I can see myself getting many hours of enjoyment from this game!

reviewText:
Fantastic graphics, solid gameplay.

This mid/large tier cruiser game will keep you locked in and immersed for at least 30 hours of good fun, hunting down enemy fleets, trading for best profit, avoiding getting caught with illegal goods, fighting larger ships and finally getting that monster of a battleship you've been saving for. I myself played this game on a radeon 390 and was easily able to have smooth fps maxed out at 2560 x 1440p.

The game looks amazing; especially when cruising between stations and fighting. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking to have some fun in a space game for at while (i was getting pretty bored of Elite Dangerous at this point and wanted a bit of a change, this game provided it even though its in the same genre).

reviewText: This is the game I've been looking for since Freelancer. Combat takes place on capital ships, so don't expect to be pulling off sweet manuevres or Luke in the Death Star trench stuff. The whole premise of the game is that you're looking for pieces of a puzzle first introduced by your enigmatic aunt, along the way you undertake missions and ♥♥♥♥ off all the pirates in the sector to the point you can't dock anywhere any more. I came to this off the back of Elite Dangerous, and have been completely satisfied. High risk missions pay more money (hauling huge munitions cargos into the middle of a siege is immensly rewarding), and you have full freedom to do whatever you want and explore the galaxy. Combat is usually pretty fluid, though learning to balance your weapons and deflectors takes a little practice, and the broadside based combat may not be everyone's cup of tea.

reviewText:
Things I absolutely love about Rebel Galaxy:

1. Broadside Combat
2. 4x (light) Space Sim with tight controls on a controller
3. Excellent graphics, gameplay, and a decient story
4. Impressive amount of content for the asking price.

Things I absolutely despise about Rebel Galaxy:

1. Scaled Enemies

Really this is the only thing keeping me from recommending the game. It has so much going for it, but the deeper I got into the game, the more it gave me this overwelming hatered of grinding for gear and ships that perform the same since the enemies will automatically get harder.

I felt like I will never beat Rebel Galaxy and it would only allow me to finish it... at some point, and that makes Rebel Galaxy feel like a waste of time.

You don't even realize that this is a problem until it is too late and now you have to game the system" in order to play it the way it wants you to.

2. Saving at ports

This last point would not anger me so much if the game didn't have Scaled Enemies.

reviewText:
I give it a cautious thumbs up. If you enjoyed the naval combat in Assasin's Creed: Black Flag, get ready for that exact same experience except with better music and laser beams.

Pro's:
Excellent soundtrack and if you get tired of it, the game makes it really easy to swap in your own at start up.

Combat is simple, but can be challenging at times depending what sort of mess you fly into.

The ship design is interesting and the different weight classes make each class pilot differently enough to keep them distinct. That said, it'd be nice to have a few more ships to choose from or mod support so we can make our own.

Con's:
Eventually the whole game gets repetitive. The music repeats after a bit, the systems start to look the same with the only real difference being the color of the core and the enemies are more or less interchangeable as far as faction goes.

Characters are forgettable and the story won't suck you in, but for $20 bucks you knew there was going to be a trade off and the narrative is it.

If you can't wait to play Star Citizen and Elite:Dangerous seems to complicated and in depth or requires too much patience, than this might be your cup of tea. You could do worse for $20 dollars (20 tacos at taco bell?). If you catch it on sale for $10 or less, I'd say go for it without reservation, at full price you might want to ask yourself what else that $20 could buy you.

If the game ever gets mod support then buy it without hesitation and see what kind of hijinks you can get up to.

reviewText: What a BLAST!!! Want to know how Han Solo felt? give this game a whirl. Bang for the buck this is an awesome deal! t is part space sim, part arcade game. At first I was disappointed that there seems to be no vertical axis, only horizontal. That after a while seems to not matter so much. It seems to be pretty large and very beautiful. I havent even left the first galaxy yet...hopefully there will be expansions as things go along. In the mean time there is plenty to do...trade, smuggle get into MANY fights. Upgrade your ship, get a new one...visit strange new places and interact with alien races... Some will be disatisfied there is not the depth of a sim...it DOES lean towards the arcade side...still...that to me isn't a huge deal. There are plenty of in depthe starship simmulations. This has just enough of it and the fun or the arcadish feel. THEN there is the music! AWESOME! very blues rockish, gets you right in the mood to BE that Han Solo character or be your own Scruffy Nerfherder!\nThis was supposed to release on PS4 and I had been waiting, but no date...So I bought it...a couple of days later, what do you know...they released it  there as well. So I have 2 copies! Its good enough and really cheap enough for me to not mind so much.  I very much reccomend this game!

reviewText:
What a blast! Didn't know I was craving Rock'n Roll in space. Now I need more of that ludicrous alchemy: Dubstep Gothic, Minimal House Fantasy, NewRetroWave Sword and Planet...

Rebel Galaxy profits from some tightly focused game design that does exactly 2 or 3 things really well without resorting to needless filler. Consequently its approach is very much arcade, so don't expect a lot of simulation here.

The missing vertical axis works surprisingly well and I didn't feel restricted by it. Presumably many people will be put off, though.

+Flair: Like an issue of HeavyMetal magazine.
+Soundtrack: +150% cool. Also easily replaced with your personal flavour, if needed.
+Action: Fast and Fun.
-Exploration: Nice visuals but basically just background for some gunfights.
-Variation: After a certain point it's more of the same².

reviewText:
I really like the Idea of this game. Battleship combat in Space witha variety of weapons and enemys. Solving Missions as Mercenary for hire or Merchant or whatever.

The game IS fun, at least in the first 15 to 19 hours. Thus i still would recommed this game, even for it's full price.



However, after 19 hours the gameplay really runs thin on me and is still the same as it was at the beginning, just with a little bit different and statistically better weapons.
If there is more variety further in then that iks bad because after 19 hours the game should have put on it's best gameplay pants.

Overall it doesn't really do variation that well.

These are the reasons why i coulödn't keep going any more.

Equipment/Upgrades are more or less superlinear:

There is no sense in choosing a weaker weapon because you perhabs like the look or how it's mechanic works, if it's of a lower damage and a shorter range then what you actually can get you won't bother because of it's downsides.
This counts for every aspect of the upgrades, everything is rather a linear upgrade because the best things to get will be (numerical as well as trough testing them) only the best Broadsides, Turrets, Shields and so on.

On top of the the lack of variation also comes from the game having not enough actually usefull or rewarding... well rewards. drops of items or weapons. In my 19 hours with the game it dropped maybe 5 Items one of wich i then actually took on till i stopped playing because it was just the best. Or at least i think it were drops because the game sure as hell didn't really tell me.

All the thiongs that the enemys let fall is really boring loot that is also really cumbersome and stupid hard to collect. Because for some reason you can lock on to dropped cargo but if the Tractorbeam just doesn't want to collect the more viable ressource and instead insists on picking up the ♥♥♥♥ Nuts and Bolts then there is nothing you can really do about it aside from collectting the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing drive it elsewhere, throw it into space over there and then come back to repeat the same thing until... NO THANKS after a short while i just didn't bother with most of these drops.

Good equipment and weapons you only get in stations. That is not a bad thing per se but it hurts the gameplay fun. Why don't we have a slvage mechanism where we can salvage broken enemy ships?

Samey and thin Mission/Story:

The Story is okay. Nothing really to write home about. It gives you a direction to go for but much more then thin context for the mission it ain't. Not even the Main Ones. Every Mission is more or less the same. No matter what the description or story behind the Mission. You go somewhere, bla bla happens, enemys are there or turn up, you shot stuff, perhabs you have to deliver something and that was it. Go there, pewpew, done.

Well, there WAS one mission that was a escort mission. But that was an instant death of mission target thing. Not that i really could have done something against it. Wich incidentally feeds into the next problem.

The combatsystem is flat:

And i don't only say that because in stead of real space you actually just move on a single layer, an invisible surfeace" in space. That in itselfe i don't mind at all.

The promisse of the combat system is really interesting at first. You have braoadsides
recommended: and with growing ships you own more and more turrets on top of it. In the Pause menue you can then give the different turrets commands like
hoursPlayed: only attack fighters
voteText:
or that rocketturret is only suppossed to shoot at Capital ships. You can also take control over the different turrets youself but that doesn't really make much sense. With increasing Equipment you get the feeling your tactical possibilities grow. But they don't

Aside from limiting missille turrets for the bigger ships the best strategy is to give all turrets the commando only to attack what you actually lock in with the trageting system. THIS is thousand times more effective then let different turrets do different tasls.

You then skirt around the edges of the battlefield picking of the enemys piece by piece because it makes no sense to charge in and do risky stuff. That will just get you killed or addled with immense reparicosts. It doesn't bring you really much to use cover. You can hire ONE additional mercenary but those aren't much more then the turrets you already have. There is nor real strategy to the combat

And that is a problem because it is boring as hell. Okay that's a lie

reviewText:
TLDR:  If you have even a marginal interest in space themed combat/exploration, go buy this now.

This game has all the fun of exploring, mining, combat, story, with none of the fiddly bits you tend to get in space themed games.  There are a ton of really smart, quality of life, user friendly design choices made by the developer, and it makes playing the game just plain fun.

Once you get past the learning stage, which doesn't actually take long, and figure out how to fight and gear your ship, this game has a serious 'just one more mission' vibe.  You will lose hours to this that you thought were minutes.

This game has a real charm to it, highly recommended.  Well worth full price, and then some.  Get it now, you won't be sorry.

reviewText:
If you like the idea of EVE / Elite:Dangerous but tried playing both and thought... I can't be arsed. Then play this instead.

Basically it's like an Indie Freelancer, this would be the closest game you could compare it to. Yes it is not a 'space simulator' but what it does give you is turrets that you can just give targeting orders to... which i think is awesome and a suedo tactical battle if you use the scan function to effectively pause the game and think out a strategy. I have played this game for several hours and have many more hours of gameplay left. Mining is... well mining but it has been done quite well. Battles are fun but it is a bit of a 'I have bigger guns and better shields' fight more than anything. Trading actually works!

Basically if you enjoyed Freelancer buy this, if you are drawn to 'Elite' type games but ultimately you've tried things like X, Elite:D and EVE and just couldn't be bothered with the time investment and complication then buy this. If you like to wear a long brown jacket and insist that your girlfriend calls you Mal... buy this.

I personally would just plain recommend you buy this!

9/10 - Could be more variation with stations and objects. Music is great but repetitive. Wish I could have a fleet not just one ship.

reviewText:
This is a very well made game. An almost Freelancer style game with simple mechanics that make learning quick and fun. The missions you take can be legal or illegal - bounty hunter, merchant, smuggler, miner, thief, and so forth. Combat is satisfying and engaging, though a bit over the top at times and occasionally downright impossible until you have had further equipment upgrades. Once purchased though, the difficulty lowers.

The commodity system was great! This was one of the most satisfying games for being a merchant I've ever played. Watch for starvation and run them food from an agrarian planet. Take water from one system that is rich in it to a more barren system and earn 200% or more than what you bought it for. Took a little getting use to, and I still don't understand it all, but the overall mechanic is satisfying once you get an idea of it.

My only gripe is it needs more content. After the main story is over, you have the biggest Dreadnaugh, and you are fully upgraded, doing missions is a little pointless. The devs should open it up for modding. More ships, weapons, equipment, systems, etc., etc., and this game would be more than a hoot.

Definitely worth the $20. The game is great and a definite recommend, even if it's for a few story runs only.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy was initialy hard to play, the controls felt wierd and until I got my settings right the framerate wasn't great, but after fixing the settings and about two hours this became one of the best games I have ever played. Top five for sure. Basicly think of what it would be like if Empire at War's space battles weren't RTS, or if Battle Star Galactica Online wasn't for wallet warriors and wasn't unbalanced. The locked plane and broadside combat keeps the game simple and exciting and totally un-clunky, although sometimes the menus can be a bit difficult.

The ship designs are great too, especially the underated Sorcerer dreadnought (my personal favorite ship, by far) although sometimes the AI targeting gets confused due to the ship's geometry, which was fixed with the sorcerer for the main part but makes the McKinley my least favorite ship so far.

Aliens in this game also have good design by being Lovecraftian fish people or rad badger dudes and they all feel Star Wars inspired and combined with the hailing system also add a sort of Star Trek feel.

Overall, the game is initially daunting and difficult to get used to, but after you've given it a chance it is absolutely great.

reviewText:
Rebel Galaxy is a fun expansive space game that sacrifices complete freedom and dogfighting to bring something completely new to the table, which is fun and unique

Pros:
-Areas feel big and look wonderful
-Awesome music which adds a bit of a Mad Max feel (my opinion)
-Ship combat which reminds strongly combat in pirate games (hence swashbuckling adventure) which requires maneuvering to let shields recover or attack another angle of the enemy that's more vulnerable and using deflectors" to absorb damage in an emergency
-Fully voice acted with only a few quircky lines and many alien dialects
-huge variety of weapons and defence mechanisms to choose from which can change gameplay
date:
especially the "broadside" weapons
-Possibility to either be lawful or piraty which will make some outposts hate you and others accept you
-Trade or fight and/or join certain factions which have unique ships or items
-You can engage Warp at almost any point and do not have to travel to some gate unless you go to a different starsystem
-An interesting story around your Aunt and a certain object she uncovered...

Cons:
-You are limited to a 2D Plane

reviewText: What a BLAST!!! Want to know how Han Solo felt? give this game a whirl. Bang for the buck this is an awesome deal! t is part space sim, part arcade game. reviewText:
I am actually surprised that a low buget game like Rebel Galaxy can have so much content in one go. Trading, Pirating, Distress calls, Even random events that affect the local markets or station access. The world is yours to toy with but you still need to pay attention to what is going on. You dont want to slam straight into a space station where there is a invasion going down. (Unless you are planning on clearing it up of course)

The combat is different that in other space oriented games. As you are flying Capital grade ships you cant fly UP or DOWN. Sounds bad but hang on. Fact is you dont need to. With some work your ship becomes a flying fortress. With plasma !BROADSIDES! and enough turrets on it to wipe out a fleet.As for valuing defense and offence its your call. Personally i like being up close so i took some fast acting cannons for close quarters. More damage, less range. The game is FULL of tradeoffs when it comes to arnament. So you need to pick your method carefully.

Personally i HIGHLY recommend this game to any game progression enthusiasts with a limited budget. The game is cheap, VERY long if you want to play all the way, and there are enough tactics and explosions around for a great experience.

10 out of 10 in my book.

reviewText:
Fantastic graphics, solid gameplay.

This mid/large tier cruiser game will keep you locked in and immersed for at least 30 hours of good fun, hunting down enemy fleets, trading for best profit, avoiding getting caught with illegal goods, fighting larger ships and finally getting that monster of a battleship you've been saving for. I myself played this game on a radeon 390 and was easily able to have smooth fps maxed out at 2560 x 1440p.

The game looks amazing; especially when cruising between stations and fighting. I would recommend this game to anyone who is looking to have some fun in a space game for at while (i was getting pretty bored of Elite Dangerous at this point and wanted a bit of a change, this game provided it even though its in the same genre).

reviewText: This is the game I've been looking for since Freelancer. Combat takes place on capital ships, so don't expect to be pulling off sweet manuevres or Luke in the Death Star trench stuff. The whole premise of the game is that you're looking for pieces of a puzzle first introduced by your enigmatic aunt, along the way you undertake missions and ♥♥♥♥ off all the pirates in the sector to the point you can't dock anywhere any more. I came to this off the back of Elite Dangerous, and have been completely satisfied. High risk missions pay more money (hauling huge munitions cargos into the middle of a siege is immensly rewarding), and you have full freedom to do whatever you want and explore the galaxy. Combat is usually pretty fluid, though learning to balance your weapons and deflectors takes a little practice, and the broadside based combat may not be everyone's cup of tea.

reviewText: Now this game is solid FUN! Period! I'm an emotional gamer so for me what makes or breaks a game is the FEELING a game emotes. It does not have to be perfect next gen graphics, or super solid gameplay, or the most original story ever. If it feels right and gives enjoyement then it's a success for me. Now obviously all previously mentioned things add up to the overall feel of a game. However they are like spice and are not the sole source of the 'magic' of a game. The cornerstone needs to be set right with a game or the whole building will start sinking crooked. For me this elusive thing in games is the feeling they magically either have or don't have. Take this game for example. It does not have award winning graphics or plot or even character development. It does not have a particular interesting story and the game makes no pretentions of it either. This game is not trying to be serious about itself and that my friends is what made a movie called tremors such a great fun flick in it's time. Solid practical effects, avoiding tongue in cheek direction or story for that matter is what made that movie have a great FEEL to it. Same here. By looking on this game's merits on paper by all means this should be a flop, but it's completely and utterly the opposite! This is why people betting on money and calculating companies trying to bank a bazillion of whatever currency they can get a hold of, will never see the light of day how to make a good solid fun entertainment! All I can say is, try this game out if you are a person like me and care for the overall feeling of a gameplay experience. The only good thing this game has on paper is it's soundtrack :D Perfect campy fun in a great way!\n\nHowever no game is perfect and hardly is this title here. This game is EASY to get into, but after awhile it becomes a grindtastic repetitive romp with not so good AI. Beware of these things if you are easilly turned off. It did not turn me off so much because the overall easiness and feeling the game churns out kept me at it enjoying getting better ships and weaponry. I am a casual gamer and I appreciate when a game is this accessible. However of course it would be great if this game had more depth and polish into it as it progresses. The devs could maybe make DLC for this title? Anyway I'm certainly looking for a sequel that tackles more with this titles shortcomings. I loved freelancer and was immediately at home with this one. Besides freelancer was not so much more complex gameplaywise as this one is. Peoples fond memories tend to get golden in time. I liked this one, so maybe give it a cautious try if you liked freelancer..

reviewText:
This game is everything I had hoped Elite Dangerous would be. Structurally, both games are very similar: you hop round the galaxy trading, mining, exploring, bounty-hunting and doing various missions, all the while earning credits so you can upgrade your ship and equipment. The main difference being this game removes all the tedium that ED insists you go through repeatedly and infinitely. Elite's station docking was fun for an hour or two, but after the 1000th dock, you just wish they'd just remove it...Rebel Galaxy removes this and you just insta-dock! Elite's 5 minutes with absolutely NOTHING to do while you warp to another station was never fun, and RG condenses this to a 10-30 second jump where you actually have some dodging and janking to do. Design decisions like this might make RG a more casual game than ED, but for me it also makes it 1000% more playable.

This brings us to the combat. Purists will frown on Rebel Galaxy for it's 2-D implementation of space versus Elite's glorious 3D, but at the end of the day the combat is arcadey in both games, and RG's combat simply manages to be much more FUN. And certainly more epic. 30+ ship battles while you blast fighters with your short range turrets, broadside their capital ships and unleash homing missiles at everything else are far more epic than anyting Elite managed to throw my way.

So my final description is that Rebel Galaxy is Elite with all the tedium removed, an actual story added, way better missions, and with considerably more fun combat. Which is what I've wanted in a space game since I racked up hundreds of hours of the original Elite on my Spectrum sometime back in the 1980s.

TLDR: 8/10* this game is everything Elite Dangerous should have been

* I would give this game 9/10 but for one annoying feature....you cannot view the local station map while docked. This means that you cannot easily plan the best cargo to buy or the best missions to take because you cannot see the optimum routes around the sector without seeing that local map. It's a quality of life thing that proves more frustrating than it might sound. If they fix that, this is a solid 9/10.

reviewText:
If you're gonna get this game you should really know what you're getting in to. The combat could be fun for some, but to me it's dull, unintuitive and lacks depth of any kind. It's not about skill it's all about your gear.

The missions are uninspiring and feel like quests in MMOs, that would've been fine if not for the fact that this is a single player gane and I expect more from it.

The story wasn't too gripping at first but there might be some people who are really interested by it.

The travelling is boring and takes waaaaaaay too long.

The soundtrack is good though so I give it a plus there, the voice acting is also good and there seems to be put in a lot of effort there.

Do your research before buying the game, this is a very unique game... For good or bad (With my taste it's bad bu tI can see where others find the appeal).

All in all I'd say this is a very niche game, but if you're looking for a star citizen or elite dangerous type of game this is not it.

reviewText:
A game without any need for a player. You make no decisions- just follow a waypoint indicator to the next mission. You don't aim, your weapons autoaim and some of them autofire. There is no terrain, occassional asteroids dot the map but they don't effect combat much. Every set of enemies feels identical - there is no variety whatsoever. The game is played strictly on a 2d plane. The only tactic I ever had to use was kite enemies from long range if I was overwhelmed (which was very rare).  Weapon variety is low and upgrade progression is linear.

The music quickly becomes dull, mostly twangy country music. Not a lot of variety.

The graphics are nice and ships show damage decalls when hit. There is a big variety in ship size and appearance. It would be nice if a ship 10 times my own ship's size was intimidating at all I guess.

Perhaps most telling is the components present in the game. There's a lot of opportunity here, perhaps there could be a part that doubles your speed and halves your shields. Instead all of them give marginal benefits to your ship (like a 10% increase in turning speed). These components are all expensive, requiring more than a dozen missions of farming to get.

The entire game is a grind with no need for a player. Why couldn't you find something for me to do Rebel Galaxy?

reviewText:
First game in 11 years on Steam that I've requested a refund.

Contrary to what you may read from the starry-eyed youngsters spamming out blue thumbs, this is not a scion of Privateer.  This is a fourth generation knock-off of Privateer designed for the ADD crowd.  The combat is simplistic, mindless, and confusing.  The map scale is tiny.  The... well, if you loved Privateer, you know where I'm headed here.

On the bright side, the developers do understand something that most designers of modern free-form space combat/trading games often miss entirely:  Privateer was a huge success because of its atmosphere and you are there" feeling.  They nailed that part.  Too bad the rest of it sucks skunk sacs.

Rather than spend cash on this thing
date: just give it to Chris Roberts to work on his latest game.  You'll get a far better return on your investment"

reviewText: Naval style combat is good and fun, and it works... if you have a top down view. The control scheme and game mechanics for combat and controls are very cumbersome.

This game is not a first person simulator but forces your camera view to behave like one.    You can't exactly lock your camera to a top down view  and still hope to actually do any fighting at the same time since it is heavily dependant on your camera to be swerving around to the sides of the ship to enable attacking/aiming/shooting.

The 'rpg' adventure aspect is very shallow/empty.  It's just one big fetch/delivery/grind with no depth to the world.

reviewText:
The vast majority of reviews are quite decieving for this game, in that they paint a picture for this game that makes it seem like more than it really is.

The 2D naval combat and the camera that's way too close makes the game feel extremely small and claustrophobic and makes combat a nuisance at best, and on top of the terrible camera, the heavy amounts of aim assist make it very dull, tracking your shots hardly matters since your shots effectively home in on the target so long as you're in range and have charged your broadside shots and the turrets are literally an autolock and fire themselves when you're in broadside mode.

The controls and functionality are very off-putting as well, this game was very obviously made for consoles and wasn't properly ported to PC, there are no options in game, only a settings launcher that pops up before you enter the game so if you want to change anything at all you have to restart the game before you can. Keyboard and mouse controls feel pretty slip and slide too.

Finally there's all the comparisons to Freelancer I want to put to bed.
I played Freelancer for hours, probably hundreds of hours, I absolutely ADORED Freelancer, it was the ideal space sim for a plebian like me, nice and simple and really pretty while still feeling like it's in space.
This however is no Freelancer.
The combat is way too basic, the movement is way too restricted, the world is far too claustrophobic. Everythings packed and squeezed into this tiny 2D space where the concept of up and down are alien to the player character.

Sorry Freelancer fans, you're gonna have to keep going without.

Overall this game's pretty naff.

It should have been a Naval game.

reviewText:
So I've had this game for a couple of days and have a dozen hours on it or so and my overal impression is 'meh' with a side of 'boring'.

I found the start of the game very infuriating, the controls didn't work on a laptop (although they were fine when I reconfigured them). But combat is still a pain, many of the actions you can perform while flying demand the camera to be facing a certain direction and you can't steer you're ship while simultaneously aiming a broadside. But that's kind of OK, it just means that the game is aimed at beginers of this genre. It does do somethings well, like having shields and armour go down on different parts of the ship independently. Would be nice if they could also be upgraded independently.

Which brings me to my biggest gripe about the game. Upgrading your ship is dull. You have only a handful of options per part, which then go from Mk1 to Mk2 to Mk3, etc... Doesn't feel like an accomplishment to have my top speed under boost increase by 10%. Add to that that every battle feels the same (unless there are some unseen possible tactics I haven't come across) and the world is bland.

Basically, when ever I played this game only one thought crossed my mind Why am I not playing X3: Terran Conflict ?". It's not a perfect game by far

reviewText:
Mixed feelings about this one.

As a mouse-and-keyboard PC gamer, the consolification of the interface and ship combat feels awful. The zoom is weird, the interface manipulation is weird, all the usual problems you'd expect on the interface of a console port.

On the other hand, the game evokes strong memories of Freelancer and even Freespace (god those beam weapons are gorgeous). It remains to be seen if the latter can overpower the former for me, and it also remains to be seen whether the game's interface will ever be de-consolified for the proper PC interface. As it stands right now, I just can't overlook the way the game handles.

reviewText:
This game scratched an itch in me that I didn't really know was there until I played it. It isn't your traditional fare, and the game streamlines the experience of being a space captain. That said it plays like Firefly meets Pirates of the Caribbean. If you never have enjoyed playing games where you line up broadsides and enjoy the sweet victory as your enemy crumples under your withering fire...you might not like this game. If you do, and you like your universe dipped in hard whisky with plenty of grit on the side this game might be just your thing.

The Good:Ship combat is fast and furious, with most engagements and missions being over in a couple of minutes. Swarms of fighters, dancing beam weapons, and volleys of missiles light up the fights; all coming at you and maybe the poor sap you hired to protect you. Meanwhile you use a deflector (timed extra shield), main shields, and your armor to protect the innards of your ship while trying to line up a broadside as your turrets pick away at your opponent's shields. Because once someone is down to armor, it doesn't take that long before they are nothing be space dust.

Trading, while simple, is still deep enough to enjoy. There is also mining, bounty hunting, distress calls (and ambushes), dead drop missions, and more to enjoy. You can spend hours alone in the first system building up reputation and your ship before stepping out into the wider galaxy...and you just might.


The Bad:As much fun as the combat can be, it sometimes falls a little heavily on your gear as to whether you can engage in that fight or not. Thankfully the game does a good job of tracking the threat level as to your chances of pulling off the fight or whether you need to pass or run away. Which even with a medium frigate all in top gear for the first system I'm finding I'm doing more running then fighting...yet. Mission boards also give you a threat level when you take them so you know you aren't walking into a complete curb stomp, but you will feel the sting of defeat if you don't pay attention and especially if you aren't willing to run away until your ship and equipment is more up to the task.

The other issue some might take is that this is all on a 2-D plane. So you don't go up or down with your ship, however fighters and objectives such an mine-able asteroids can be go/be off this plane. Turrets can handle these threats, but only if they can fire in that arc. As I discovered in mining however, you might need more then one of the expensive mining lasers to reach an asteroid depending on the turret placement and ship. They have a decent reach and make excellent short range beam weapons, but mining can be a pain and for as much investment you have to put into your ship to set it up to do right that can lead to some frustration.


The Ugly:Unfortunately the game doesn't feel like it's fleshed out ship wise. There are 21 ships you can supposedly fly over the course of the game, and about half of those will be available to you from the start, a few more unlocked by leaving the first system, and a handful unlocked by faction reputation. It would have been nice to see some heavy armored and fast gunships, or some lighter armored glass cannons. There is a class of ship called 'strike craft' which seems to drop off by the end of the first system.

The fighting can also get a little formulaic over time. I find running while my turrets pick off the fighters before engaging the larger ships to be the best road to success. Trading also can be a pain until you stumble upon the transponder that allows you to see the commodities of stations across the map without having to first dock at them.

Verdict:If you enjoy broadsides and want a new type of scenario for your space faring adventures, this game might be just what you are looking for. If being a captain of a capital class ship isn't your cup of tea, then you still might want to pick it up on a sale. I recommend even at full price.

reviewText: Does not start on Mac OS Mavericks. Many people who do not want to upgrade to Mac OS ElCapitan for valid reasons have reported about this problem since early October 2015 and until now, 8 months later, this is not fixed. There are some hacks in some forums that helped some people but not all of them (including me). This is really bad service, as the problem seems to be quite simple to fix from the producers' side (make their launcher start in full screen without using the most fancy ElCapitan methods to do so). It is just about the launcher, not the game itself. This should be a simple task. However, without the launcher to set the game options, the game itself starts only in not-playable configuration. A catch-22 for the end user who has paid money for playing it. So, thumbs down from my side.

reviewText:
(Review based on preview copy provided by developers)

Rebel Galaxy is a Space Opera with some pretty legendary names behind its creation, and it definitely shows. There's no question that it's worth the asking price of $20 USD - though it does have its pros and cons worth considering if it's the perfect fit for you, as well as some gameplay aspects some people will enjoy more than others.

----

Important Notes:
- This game involves trading, mining, and most of all - combat.

- Combat is based on Naval combat, not standard 6-degree space combat, you will be using broadside cannons, ramming, and turrets for your capital ship on a horizontal plane (non capital ships use the full 6 degrees of freedom, but you don't get to fly those :P). This leads to interesting, yet still very satisfying, combat.

- You have access to a lot of control with your ship, a lot of choices, including what tools you employ and how your weapons behave in battle - and they definitely have an impact on how you play.

-You also have the ability to toy with alliances and factions, to change the system (improving/destroying your relations with different factions changes how you play the game)

- Combat, either through Bounties, Missions, or Random Encounters will be your fastest way to gather resources and progress - though Trading/Mining are definitely still somewhat viable options.

----

Pros:
- Good visuals, with satisfying explosions, weapon fire, etc. And visible damage on your ship.

- Amazing audio assets (and the ability to customize the audio if you want). Voice Acting is good"

reviewText: This is a game that starts out incredible and quickly becomes repetitive and boring. The more I played it the less I enjoyed it. I was immediately pulled in with a fantastic soundtrack and interesting gameplay. However I realized very rapidly that the bit I got at the start was basically all there was. There's retrieval, protection, and shipping and those are your main mission types. You can mine for some ore to trade and you can buy low and sell high based on random events in the system you're in. It very quickly feels hollow because who cares if planet z is having problems so they need more of y item that you can buy elsewhere. None of it matters at the end, the issues resolve regardless of what you do. The main quest seems interesting enough but the quests are the same blow up the bads retrieve mystic object" nonsense that the side quests are.\n\nOverall an interesting idea but not deep enough."

reviewText: I understood this game wouldn't have the real kind of depth I was looking for, but felt it would be good enough as a simple time killer.  I like the 2D plane naval style battles.  What I don't like is not owning multiple ships with different setups.  Mining is really more complicated than it should be for this type of game.  If my mining laser is on the bottom of the ship, good luck hitting an asteroid above your ship.  Scanning for asteroids gives no information of what you are mining for and as far as I can tell there is no item that does.  Certain weapons seemingly fire through your ship even though vision is blocked.  Really it's not a terrible game, but it's not a particularly good one.  Galaxy On Fire has more depth than this game.  The combat is good and interesting, the story is good and even the voice acting is good.  Graphics are fine.  Some small details were missed and the game was dumbed down more than it needed to be.  If you are looking for something really simple, then this game is for you.  It's on Galaxy On Fire's level.  If you are the type who likes the X Series or was into Eve Online and you were looking for something kind of in between in the single player realm, you will be slightly disappointed.

reviewText:
Although I can't recommend this game, I did not hate it. It was all right and the price is fair. The main problem in my opinion is that every combat situation is basically the same. While the combat is OK it gets old really soon.

The main story is hardly the centerpiece, as everything else in this game it's (just) OK. The last mission was quite dissapointing, as a matter of fact I didn't even realize I was in the last stand off against the main baddies until it was over.

Even though finished the main story I only visited 1/3 of all solar systems, partially bacause the story didn't take me there and parrtially because there was no reason to go there. In fact all systems are basically the same (the third I saw).

The second biggest problem after the staleness of combat is that the ship design isn't varried enough. There is little reason to buy the smaller faster ships. You basically buy the biggest mobile weapons platform" smack a bunch of guns on it

reviewText:
This is a wonderful open-world space game with a lot to offer, but my hours are low and I'm giving it a thumbs-down because I just can't get past the horrid UI.

The UI for this game is very obviously designed for consoles and not for PC, but even after plugging in a controller and trying it that way, I found myself getting frustrated.  Some things that I don't like, roughly in order of most irritating:
Waiting for information to cycle.  When looking at commodities, whether on the commodities screen or on the map, instead of having a scrollable list, pages/lines will cycle every 4 seconds or so.  This creates a) a lot of waiting and b) you can't stop the cycle when your item comes up and actually read it.
All scrolling lists and menus move one item at a time.  You can still select something with the mouse if it's on the screen, though, assuming you can see it or figure out what it is while it's grayed out.
No way to display the sector map while docked.
No way to create multiple waypoints, meaning you can't plan out routes that navigate around hostiles or asteroid belts.
No way to zoom your camera in/out, resulting in a lot of screen space always being occupied by your (albeit gorgeous) ship.
No speed indicator on the HUD, for you or your targets.

If the UI gets fixed, I'll likely dump countless hours into this game and come back and rewrite my review, but until then, I can only say that it feels like a really clunky console port.

reviewText:
4/10
Seriously, just get a Scarab, keep your turrets maxed out, and outmaneuver or out gun every ship in the game. It's just as combat effective as bigger ships, and much cheaper, since you don't pay a mint to replace 10 turrets whose coverage doesnt even let them fire.

Pro:
Shiny
Quite controllable with mouse and keyboard once you get used to it
Very Simple

Con:
..Excessively simple
No replayability due to every 'randomly generated' system being the same, with the same 7 factions, ships, stations
Short campaign with no feeling of resolution or urgency due to functioning as normal combat missions, only with voiceovers.
Vastly underdelivers due to excessive positive reviews here.

I'd say buy this game if you really want a playable space game, but frankly, you're going to get 6 hours in and say, Is this IT?!" like I did. Maybe less."

reviewText:
--Additional update---

I just finished the main storyline. What a fantastic game!!! It's been a long time since I have played a game that hits that special spot of enjoyment that makes me just want to keep playing. I love this game...



--UDATE--

Having finally made it to the second system, I can say that I am absolutely pleased with this game. The next sector has bigger and better ships, weapons, and modules to fit with. I also went into the third sector and saw that the ships get even larger, with even better gear. Unfortunately, I was totally unprepared for how much herder that new system was, so I had to go back.

Man! This game is awesome!

I haven't played it for a very long time, but what I have played, I certainly like.

The ships all feel different, the progression feels substantial, and getting new weapons and systems for each ship makes everything feel a lot more visceral.

One of my favourite things about the game is that you can fit up your ship with some new gear and truly feel a difference in power, making you feel like a real space bad@ss.

Certainly worth the asking price, in my books.

reviewText: Excellent potential, but the save system is hands down the worst implementation of saves i have experienced.  Without the ability to manually save the game, if you make a single mistake and getting into deep trouble and the system auto-saves you in that state, your game is ruined and you have to restart.  I played for nearly two hours and lost everything because a red marauder team caught me and I couldn't escape.  A no win scenario that effectively destroys your save game isn't a 'challenge', its a game killer.  I refuse to devote more time to a game that doesn't give you the ability to protect your progress with a manual save option.  Until then, this is a game wiating to frustrate you to the point you uninstall it.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game.  I really did.

Reading other reviews and watching videos reminded me of Escape Velocity: Nova, a great Ambrosia game from oh so long ago.  I thought that this game could capture the same magica that game possesed but with the updated flare of almost 20 years of gaming advances.

Unfortunatly, I was wrong.

Combat in Rebel Galaxy feels dry, leaving you endlessly flying in circles trying to keep fighters on screen.  Capital ship combat, while entertaining for the first 20 minutes, comes down to trying to land as many broadsides as possible which, once again, leads to flying in circles.

The 2-d movement that was great in a top down space trading game like Escape Velocity is restrictive and unnatural.  At no point could I suspend my disbelief and imagine that I was piloting a space ship.  Any sense of immersion is ruined by this element.

With all that said the game isn't bad looking and the price is pretty low.  That might be enough to make this game an enjoy able experience for some but it didn't make it worth it for me.

reviewText: The game balance is all kinds of drunk. The side missions, of which you'll do a whole load, have Risk estimates next to them. These estimates are entirely useless. You can get face melted in a Normal, and never even notice your shields getting touched in a Very High. The power boost between gear levels is also really large, more than 50% boost usually. This means you're going to get melted often when heading into a new area whilst you try to scrape together the money to make your ship competitive.\n\nThis power difference pretty much kills the immersion as well. Why are two systems, right next door to each other, at such differences in weapon tech? Why doesn't a single ship from the high area go to the low area and just take over? They'd be completely untouchable?

reviewText:
I was hoping for Mount and Blade meets Firefly. What I got was neither. This game has so much potential, but is hugley hurt by a number of things.
(If you're wondering why my play time is so low its because I plan to get a refund and because the glaring problems are obvious from the start.)

Firstly the thing I noticed first that bugged me was that, you ARE LOCKED TO A SINGLE PLANE OF MOVEMENT!(sounds small but it is SO annoying) Now if this were top down, this wouldnt be a problem, but the view is thrid person, making it painfully obvious how limited you are. What makes it worse is that other ships (including those you fight) can fly freely, making combat confusing and disorienting.

Second, the graphics, nice enough at first (tough not at all cutting edge) but the problem there isn't poorly done graphics, it's OVERDONE graphics, I am being entirley honest when I say that the lens flare/ lighting effects during (one dimensional)'flight' actually HURT to look at.

And finally, parts of it just feel....off. Little things, like a cramped UI in stations with loads of wasted space, or dialogues with characters (which are admittedley quite nicley done) feeling far too zoomed in and with no ability to use the keyboard for dialouge choices (up, down, enter or even 1,2 and 3).

It's a nice idea that wasn't done badly, but its just not quite 'right' to play. I cant honestley recommend it.

reviewText:
Game is fun, but limited. This game is Sid Meier's Pirates LITE. You have no major interaction with any factions, and can not partake in major game map changing ways. It's essentially the combat of Sid Meier's in Space, with nothing close to SMP's metagame. It's the very definition of shallow. Everything will one way or another end up with a blaster in your face. You want to trade or mine? Good luck. You'll be needing a good turret.

Ultimately I don't recommend this game despite the fact that I know a lot of people may enjoy it. I respect it's sea-naval intentions, but I just am TOO much of a fan of proper scifi stuff and not arcade based games to enjoy this.

My ideal Scifi games are along the lines of Nexus, and Homeworld. I find this to be very simplistic, to it's own detriment because it gets CLUSMY quickly with combat. It's not hard to stay oriented, but it is HARDER than it should be. Camera + controls (really, gamepad optimal, who are you kidding) + enemies + lack of distinct options controlling your own weapons makes this game a hassle.

Added on top of it, that it's a big ol'grind fest in a single player game, and you lose my interest quickly.

That said, there aren't a lot of good scifi options these days, so a lot of people will find the 20$ entry fee to be acceptable for the amount of entertainment within.
voteText: 12 of 31 people (39%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've logged 34 hours into the game as of writing this review.

The game has been nothing short of an exceptional experience. From the very moment you start the game, you get a good sense of what you're getting into. The music sets the tone to this sort of grungy, rockabilly space Western. It's full of character has a good sense of space". All this despite playing like a sort of "World of Warships meets Elite: Dangerous" hybrid between space exploration and naval combat. I highly recommend buying this game.


Pros:

Full controller support (including optional Playstation layout).
Tight Mouse&Keyboard controls.
Very pretty graphics and effects.
Visible modular ship damage.
Many graphics settings in the launcher.
Superb soundtrack.
Optional custom soundtrack to replace OR supplement the original soundtrack.
Fluid combat mechanics.
More lasers than I sometimes know what to do with.
Unique and lively NPC interactions.
Moderate learning curve.
VERY attentive and responsive developers constantly patching reported issues.

Cons:

Enemy dialogue is sometimes repetitive.
No vertical travel (2D movement only).
Objects (like Cargo) sometimes block docking or other actions.
Slaves (Cargo) have no clear way to be saved other than forfeiting to Militia (-4 rep penalty).
Single-player only (for now)."

reviewText:
Save your money..... worst of the space sim group.


PROS
Cool music and easy to navigate, ship upgrade path straight forward. Overall game had promise, until...

CONS
TERRIBLE combat broadside junk aiming mechanic, ruins the game play. It takes literally forever to hit anything with the lazy aiming system. Hold right mouse until you get a yellow path to aim, left to fire.  Misses everytime or does little damage. I really can't say enough bad things about how poorly thought out this part of the game is. Funny, that most of the game is about combat interactions and this part failed so badly. It's a shame because otherwise it seemed unique, but is unplayable due to this frustrating design idea. Sailing ships in space, no thanks!

Overall a waste of $20

The solid reviews must be rigged from devs. Too bad Steam doesn't give refunds on this trash indie stuff. Fix your broken core mechanic and allow weapons to hit something and maybe the game could work.

Starpoint Gemini 2 is 1000x times more playable.

reviewText: The game is pretty fun but lacks much content to be a $17.99 game. reviewText:
OS X review below:
--

Game is nice, especially soundtrack – sets the mood perfectly and is very pleasant to listen to.

There is however a major problem on OS X – XBox controller is not supported. Game controls and menus are clearly optimized for gamepads, but mouse look is laggy and has too much inertia. Lining up broadsided are a pain (inertia is OK with analog sticks, with mouse it is annoying as hell), turret control is just horrible (see above).

FOV could be wider (or adjustable) – your ship taking 1/4 of screen at all times is very annoying, especially on ultrawide screens. And it's not pretty on big screen, textures are console-quality and look muddy.

P.S. Regarding gameplay – warp! It is boooooring. You undock, you warp, you watch distance decreasing for 2 minutes. You fight, you win, you warp, you watch distance decreasing for 2 minutes. Rinse, repeat.

I won't recommend this game to Mac users – game is designed for gamepad, gamepad is not supported.

reviewText: Disappointing to say the least, basically its similar to Eve but without any p2p or pvp. Very vanilla economy. Super generic quests, you can literally have multiple instances of the same quest. You can go ratting. You can go mining. Would not recommend going trading. Single pane (no up/ down) essentially no 3d movement in a space game??? Why???  Pretty I'll give it that. Broadsides are nice but its gimmicky. Sound track is good but it is a short soundtrack. So after the first hour or less you will hear the same songs again and again and again. Pointless. Targeting sucks. to interact with anything you have to get pretty darn close which is just dumb. Travel between quests takes too long, you can upgrade your travel speed but it’s still pretty darn slow.  I want to like it but meh boring...

reviewText:
This game evolves from games like Star Flight, Star Fleet and Freelancer with the interface and game play being most like Freelancer(almost a re-write).  I liked Freelancer and must've played through 3 or 4 times.   The graphics and UI from this game most resemble Freelancer.

For me the whole broadside pirate style of battling is confusing enough that this game likely has not much time left on my hard drive.  No story line to speak of, no character developement, same 4 options to get a mission on each planet/station/location.  I can live with everything except the battle perspective issue, it would've been much better to have a ♥♥♥♥ pit view of battle like other flying games.  It would also be nice of while flying around you could choose between first and third person views.  Also annoying game play plot issues like can't pick up debris cargo withpout a tractor beam but you have to run earand missions to earn enough to get one, should be part of the base ship configuration, same with weapons, start with nothing being the target for every bandit who wants to shoot you down.

Had I played a demo of this game I would not have purchased.  I wish I had gotten the new Defender instead of this game.

reviewText:
Disliked that there is no manual or much of a tutorial in the game so good luck with all the controls.  I learned in the forums after a kind soul let me know that there are videos/links to videos in the game if you press esc/start button and look for them in the menus there.   Never would have thought that the equivalent of the manual? i guess would be in the menu.

Most of everyone else was busy saying the equivalent of 'man up', so not the greatest community if you are looking for any kind of help.

The game might be fun but you will have to put up with non-intuitive controls until the developers improve them or actually give more information to the players.  So at this point the game seems more to be in EA state rather than released state.  I say EA because games in those states are the ones that I expect with no manual/minimal explanation of controls when control scheme is not intuitive.

Also becareful since some of the reviews mention that it reminds them of other games space games like freelancer/(insert awesome space game) but they fail to mention that the game movement/combat is in 2D like Starpoint Gemini.

So TLDR; Gamble: might be good but be warned that controls aren't the best and community not the most helpful.  This game is more like an enhanced Starpoint Gemini.

Edit:
The review mentions community as since the 'tutorial' to basic keys is lacking then it means that the users have to rely on 'community'.

On the plus side though the developers seem to be good though so there is a future.

CONS:
- Controls not all intuitive
- Tutorial, according to other players you have to play > 15mins before you actually get to it.
- Aweful community (don't expect help from 90% of it and have a thick hide when asking).
- Universe is 2D like Starpoint Gemini (some people like this so if you are ok with it then you good).

PRO:
- Devs seem to nice and involved so a few weeks or months the game might become much better.
- Possible gem in the future, so maybe hold out until later.

reviewText:
This game tries hard to emulate Freelancer or Privateer, but sadly fails.

1. The look and feel

Looks ok, especially considering this is an indie title. Especially the spaceships have a cool touch to them.

2. Controls
Instead of freelancer or even EVE controls, they decided to do some strange console like UI navigation & flight controls on a 2D plane orientation (in space?!?). They felt clunky and unintuitive to me.

3. Combat and space gameplay

This is in my oppinion the biggest issue - the broadside combat might be a good idea in theory, but not how it is applied here - since the ships often behave more like fighter craft than behemoth ships shooting broadsides at each other, it is highly annoying to control. And most of it is strangely semi automated with snapping auto aims etc. - I get the feeling this was consoled" down.
Why not just do something classic like freespace or freelancer? Free movement and skill aiming in a full 3D environment
date:
not on a 2D plane with strange autoaim and clunky movement?

4. Strange camera behavior
Really annoying was the camera
recommended:
which would zoom in and zoom out during screen switchens (and interpreting this as a warp)

5. Story
I guess 15 years ago
hoursPlayed: it was quite ok to receive storyline quests from some shady guys in a spaceport bar.  Transfer it to today in a slighly better 3D look instead of pixel characters
voteText:
and it no longer is so cool. Especially since the writing does not hook you.

6. Who put the afterburner on "W" and not on "tab" - seriously :)

Facit

reviewText:
The game is pretty good for its price. Instead of repeting all that has been said. I will say that this game feels like FTL on steroids. Plentty of ships to customize, you have to grind to get credits and stuff to update your ship. You can hire mercenaries to improve your ship. And every now and then you will face a fleet that you have to run. All this with great graphics, sound and gameplay.

The only difference from FTL is that this game doesn´t flip a coin when you start the game giving you a maybe chance to finish it. Which in my opinion was the stuff that i found really frustrating of FTL.

But it has been replaced with endless grinding to upgrade you ship to keep advancing. You could choose not to upgrade and go test your ship, but eventually you will fail. So grinding is necessary and a lot. The other thing that i find pretty annoying is the travel distance between objectives. At first it is fun, because you actually need to avoid stuff, but after a while is annoying. And the distances can take some time to get too, this makes the grinding much more irritating.

But i still feel the game is worth every penny of you money, and as many have said the soundtrack is awesome.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Good fun at a great price!!!!!
I haven't read the current reviews so this might be repetitive but here goes... If you like games like privateer and X2 and Freelancer, then this one is one you will enjoy.  If you enjoy space games with sweeping stellar vistas then again you should find this one good.  I don't know about you but I *hate* difficulty settings, again this game doesn't have that; if you are getting your butt kicked, do some side missions and upgrade your gear and you're back in the action.  The soundtrack is amazingly good though on paper it would have seemed a mismatch.  Just goes to show, you sometimes just have to try a thing before you judge it -- same goes with this game.  Try it, you'll be pleasantly surprised.

****SPOILER ALERT****
When trading, be savvy, some systems have a particular defficit others an abundance.  For example, one system will have serious problems with pirates and will have a strong demand for munitions while a neighboring peaceful system will have a cheap abundance of munitions.  Look for patterns, fly through a jump gate and you will reap rewards.
Remember.  Be careful out there....and enjoy!
