reviewText: This game rocks even outside the soundtrack which is excellent and then you can add your own music to boot. The visuals are very nice, even on the lowest settings there is not much difference, worried about 2d gameplay in space? This game gives the feel of a 3d game in a very lively universe not dissappointing in the least. You have plenty of ships to choose from  and they all have many things to upgrade, so find a ship you like and run with it like the starting ship? keep it and just upgrade you'll do just fine.\nThe story i'm told can be done in 30-40 hrs. but despite what my hrs. on record might say (i play offline alot out of town) i have actually about 60 hrs. give or take on this game so far and am barely thru a quarter of the storyline i believe. There is so much to do between trading, fighting, mining, that i only occasionally touch on the story which you can play at your leisure. You can be a good guy, bad guy, good then bad,bad then good? Got multiple personalities this game is for you.. well worth the 20 bucks for this one any day of the week its just well done...add to cart and you will only be wondering and hoping for continued added content for more trouble to get into...enjoy\n

reviewText:
I believe I've put enough time into this game to warrant a fair review. On a personal note, this is the only game in my library where I've had to think really hard about giving it a thumbs up or down.

What is it: imagine a sid meiers pirates in space. Its open world, with emphasis on combat. You fly into two dimensional space combat and shoot your broadside cannons into your opponent. I'm not praising or condemning this mechanic, its just the way it is. You can trade, but in the most simple sense of the word, the game tells you which resources are too highly priced/ lowly priced in each station. If you cannot complete the next required story mission, the only thing you can do is to go grind for more credits to upgrade until you can.

Pros
- Simple

Cons
- Too simple

The lightspeed travelling is really annoying, I've spent probably more than half my ingame time travelling from A to B and you automatically drop out of warp" if you encounter something. So you have to sit there listening to a very limited soundtrack waiting an average of about a minute till you reach your destination
date: trying to avoid asteroid fields etc. Longest warp time has been around 2 minutes
recommended: you get where you need to go
hoursPlayed: blow someone up and spend 2 minutes warping back.\n\nI didnt make it past the second world by the time I decided to stop playing (so I can only give information relevant up to that point in the game). Your main source of damage against big ships are your broadsides and missiles

votesFunny: broadside

reviewText:
This game is simply amazing.

This game is the natural evolution of a 2d space scrolling shooter like Tyrian or Galactix.  It's a wonderful mix of those games, your standard space-trader game, based on Tradewars 2002, and Firefly all rolled up into one giant explosive ball of awesome.

Many spaceship games now-days require days or even months of tutorials and online reading just to fit your ships properly, position your ship, what you can take on and what you can't, etc.   Rebel Galaxy you can just jump into and be blowing stuff up in minutes.   While i love a good space sim, The attention to detail and realistic physics in those games makes the learning curve incredibly difficult. Keeping this game on a single flat plane, and then creating the game around that plane is a stroke of sheer genius. I've even put down playing Fallout 4 for this.

reviewText: This game is really fun.  I'm not sure it has a tremendous amount of replay value, but I really like it.  I've been looking for something similar to MechWarrior 2: Mercenaries for years and this is pretty close, just in space.  You are essentially a rogue captain on a journey to learn what happened to your sister.  This is the main story, but there are a lot of side quests and events to do.  Trade runs, save people, attack rival factions, quests, attack militia, contraband, etc..  I like being able to upgrade my ship, as well as, the armaments of this ship.\n\nAlso, hands down, this game has one of the best sound tracks ever.  Look it up on YouTube... a lot of really good songs.

reviewText:
I'd give this a 4 out of 5 stars. It's enjoyable and can scratch a blow ♥♥♥♥ up" itch pretty nicely. There's just enough strategy to battles to keep them interesting but not so much that it becomes a concentration drain. There's not a lot of depth to the game but I didn't expect much for the $20 price tag.

The reason for the missing star is that the UI and experience is a little rough around the edges and the controls can be very slightly awkward. The lack of HP indicators make checking shield/armor strength a little troublesome. There's also a bug preventing the sale of surplus ship components but I expect that be fixed up in short order.

All in all a good little game for $20. I've gotten my money out of it for sure.

reviewText: This game rocks! People say it's a grind. That may be so, but this game knows how to do grinding right - by making the gameplay a ton of fun. They basically took the most awesome part of Assassin's Creed IV (the broadside ship combat), made it a space game, and added a stylistic dash of Firefly. There's just enough of a story to make things interesting, to keep me wanting to play to find out what happens next. There's also just enough variety in gameplay to keep things from getting stale, and the numerous small upgrades to one's ship (and occassional big upgrade to buying a new ship altogether) makes me want to keep playing.... just a little longer (kind of like 'one more turn' a la Civilization, except this game is real time).\n\nGraphics are great, sound is great, and this game really captures the feel of epic capital ship battles. Really, it's a $30 or $40 game that sells for only $20. I give it 9/10!

This game is basically what it looks like: a space trucker sim with combat that is similar to the ship-to-ship combat in Assassins Creed: Black Flag, with the primary weapons being broadside cannons and turrets. If you've heard that this game starts out kinda crappy, you heard right. The starting ship (a Hammerhead called the Rasputin") is exactly what the intro cinematic says it is: a near-derelict ship with lousy hull & shielding

reviewText:
Great game!  Has the feel of Strike Command mixed with Privateer mixed with Freelancer.  This is _exactly_ what I've been looking for for years.  Open ended (do missions all day), yet directed (do the main quest line).  Graphics are top-notch, great performance (I'm using an older MSI laptop with an older GTX 680M), and excellent soundtrack.  Has a flippant tone, but serious when it needs to be.  Well done game.

The only beef I have is with the controls.  Mixing the warp (E) with tractor (also E) was frustrating until I finally remapped the keys.  Also, flipping to the scan mode seems redundant, and should be mixed with the 'pulse'.  But other than that, very easy to control and a pleasure to travel.

Highly recommended!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I really enjoyed this game. Mainly due to the atmosphre and THE SOUNDTRACK which blends really well into gameplay. You really feel like you're flying a hunk of junk in Firefly.

Stop reading to avoid minor spolers!

The game has a things you might not expect and might dissapoint. For example, you're on a 2D plane, not in 3D space, so it's a bit more like a boat sim than a space sim - add in the broadside comba and it's definitely a boat sim. Still, it works well and is fun to play, so I didn't mind.

Also, the story is good but kind of short, and once you're in sandbox mode, well there's not a whole lot to do except grind for more cash... I didn't need to upgrade to another ship to finish the game - upgrading your shields / hull and weapons is enough and it's easy to earn the cash for that quickly.

A few weird things too - like normal faction space stations in a system you're not supposed to be able to reach - how'd people get there?!?

Still, I really enjoyed it, mostly for the general atmosphere which is spot on. Good job, I had fun playing this - it could do with a sequel!

reviewText:
One of the best space sims i've played in a long time. But there are a few issues, but they are minor at best.

Issues:
1. No paint jobs for your ship. You can't change the color of the ships. Be nice, but not game breaking.
2.Money, there is none. The next ship above mine has a price tag of 15.5 MILLION credits. The best sales of mining goods: 15k. Jobs: 6500-25000. One neted me 131k, but my ship was in ruins after the job.
3. NO HIGHT ADJUSTMENT! If you are a mining sort, you'll be useing laser turrets. Problem is, most ships have turets on the underside as well as the upper decks. To bring all to bare, you need to either have a ship with all turrets clustered which sucks in combat most of the time, or park around 2km away so you don't swiss cheese your own ship. And just because youe are locked on a 2d movement, does NOT constrict the asteroids to stay on your level. So now they are out of your firing arks. It does simplify movement, but it would still be nice.

In review, just be ready to get your ♥♥♥ handed to you in a cute bow for a few hours then you have to go through a warp gate and repeat the whole cycle over again. This game will gring you down, and you will thank it and ask for round 2.

reviewText:
Hello Steamers
After giving the storyline a fast once through i decided to give my review of Rebel Galaxy.  First off great work to the creators of this little fantastic space game.  Finally these guys had the balls enough to put Rock Music in a Space Game and it really ramps up the excitement , I got all the dust cleaned out of my Bose speakers on this game and nothing but a big smile on my face when the explosions started from my missles  firing out the sides of my ship.
Sure there are some things that an older player might sqeem at as far as the cartoonie characters you meet but it's not a far trade off from Jaba.  The ships are superb in design and id have to say they look better than a few of the top rated space sim games on the market.  They give you plenty of mounting options for Lasers,Rockets,Missles,Mines and Mining Lasers that can be used for fighting aswell.

There is a Storyline to the game and it's good...... I'm glad there is a storyline here some of the bigger space sims decided to leave out storylines and there games feel like there is somthing always missing even in the missions they have.  Rebel Galaxy seems to understand this and always has some npc in the game coming on screen to talk to you about your next mission or a character trying to make a deal with you.  You are not alone in rebel space there is always someone around to greet you rather if it's good or bad.  This i'm sure is a trail space game by Double Damage to see how it does and all i can say is please give us more we like it.  Well i do any way, this is a great space game to play for a few months and you can't beat the price.  score 86/100

reviewText:
Its Firefly meets Cowboy Bebop meets Battlestar Galactica.

Rebel Galaxy is a good-looking and fun space action game with a kickass soundtrack. It plays more of an arcade game rather than a space sim so for those looking for the latter might want to look somewhere else. What this game has is a procedurally-generated, sandbox solar systems set on a 2D plane where the player can explore right from the start.

For starters, the player's ship can't roll, pitch, or yaw (sorry, no Crazy Ivan manuevers here) - only forward movement, and left/right turns. This is because the game’s combat is designed around the broadside naval engagements similar to Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag. Basically, you line up your ship (think of it as a space boat) against the enemy ship for a firing solution, and then unload your armaments to see some fireworks. It might sound easy but it has its share of tactical positioning and maneuvering - each side of your ship (front, rear, port, and starboard) has a hull and shield rating. After you eat through a ship’s shield face, you start hitting its hull to do some serious damage. You can spin that damaged side out of the line of fire to regenerate your shields and retaliate or simply retreat and fight another day.

The game has a decent selection of weaponry, ships, and ship upgrades. You can also choose to align with different factions but sadly, they have no personalities to speak of outside of the nicely animated talking avatars they have.

There is a main quest you can follow, or ignore it and set out in any direction you want and be a trader, a miner, a bounty hunter, or space pirate. You can get missions from space stations that can earn you currency to buy ships/weapons/ship upgrades, as well as alignment points to factions. The said missions can get pretty repetitive after a while, but the gloriously huge space battles keep me coming back for more.

Exploration in this game is fun and is rarely dull. It has the same relaxing feel as doing cross country delivery jobs in Euro Truck Simulator 2. There are asteroid fields, floating space junk from the ruins of some old battle (which may contain some sweet loot and military grade weaponry), nebulae of different swirling colors, planets, moons, and of course, stars. It will take a few minutes to fly from point A to point B, but there’s usually some unidentified signal, a distress call, or just a random fleet of space bandits to keep things interesting.

The game’s soundtrack is really good. It exudes the same vibe as Firefly with its guitar heavy tracks with twangs. The devs also included the most phenomenal custom music support I have ever seen in a game. There’s nothing like Want It All Back from Cowboy Bebop kicking in as I enter combat. I have Cage the Elephant, Clutch, Johnny Cash, Darren Korb (Bastion OST), Queens of the Stone Age, Yoko Kanno (Cowboy Bebop), Vitaminless (Cowboy Bebop), and Bear McCreary (Battlestar Galactica) on my custom playlist. You can sort and assign them as combat, idle, or title music. Your custom music can also be merged with the game soundtrack for more variety.

I definitely recommend this game.

reviewText:
I came to the realization that this game isn't worth sinking hours into, after killing 3 capital only to be presented with Nuts an Bolts and Green Whiskey.

I can't recommend Rebel Galaxy because it lacks mechanics.

Examples: Broadside combat is lame,  it's just static turrets on the side of your ship, Wooo....fun. Even though the combat looks great it's repetitive and ships don't have critical points. No point in becoming skilled pilot because what a player can do after 500 hours of playing this game, a beginner can do the same after the tutorial. The trading mechanic are half ♥♥♥♥♥. No economy, as the values seem to be randomly generated after some time. Since the people who made rebel galaxy also made TorchLight, I was hoping for interesting loot. But all we get is a linear upgrade system where the best weapons are plasma laser hands down and High Capacity Shields. I’m not even going to mention the story because I started skipping dialogue after meeting a gay Australian bartender.

reviewText:
i was about to buy something else until a friend of mine who i sent a message to mentioned this,

not too expensive and i have enjoyed it so far, great fun and a real time vampire i have enjoyed this a great deal so far, i hope they are planning a whole lot more to fix some things

I do worry that there is not much under the hood and there are things that are going to get tired very quickly

trading is broken, mining is broken, combat is fun and i really like some of the ideas, i think i am about to wear out my E key though

flaws in my eyes your small ship has the same shields as your destroyer?!? you dont get to pile more shields on your destroyer for more shields you may aswell stick to smaller ships and be just as hard and far more maneuverable this is totally weird to me i would have thought my destroyer could carry a load more of these shields etc

weapons are cool but it all seems a little staged, level 1 2 3 and some of the weapons are a complete waste of time but this is fine the game works and combat works.

lovely soundtrack, and going off storyline is recommended for a while

tldr: if space is your thing and you like X space games, and Firefly then you will be happy

reviewText: Think of a cross between the original Elite, or perhaps Frontier (if you're old enough to remember them) coupled with an amped-up version of the combat from Sword of the Stars 1 and you've pretty much got the barebones of Rebel Galaxy.  Throw in a distinctly wild-West, frontier ambience driven by the look of the ships (most definitely in the Solo-esque tradition of she may not look like much
date: but she's got it where it counts") and the pumping country-rock backing track and you're close to what Rebel Galaxy is all about.\n\nThe biggest single bone of contention people seem to have with this game is that it's a space sim that doesn't allow movement in any axis.  For me
recommended: this really isn't an issue.  The combat is deliberately designed with an emphasis on broadside-heavy battles.  This simply wouldn't work well across 3 axes.  As I mentioned at the top
hoursPlayed: combat in this is something akin to Sword of the Stars 1 on steroids - and for me it works beautifully.\n\nI would imagine that the greatest strength of this game could potentially be its greatest weakness: much like the original Elite
voteText: there isn't really a great deal of hand-holding; yes
helpfulPercent: there are storyline-driven missions to follow
votesHelpful: but equally you're free to indulge in any of the time-honoured space-game traditions of trading
votesTotal: bounty-hunting or piracy.  From what I can make out
votesFunny: most players (myself included) seem to eschew the story and focus on doing our own thing.\n\nIn terms of negatives; well
commentsCount: there is undeniably a 'grind' aspect as you're generally striving to get the next best ship or increase your reputation with somebody but as yet I haven't found this to be a problem - it's a mechanic that is always likely to be present in games of this ilk
column16: as Elite: Dangerous proves.\n\nAll in all

reviewText:
A good space-themed RPG with a linear storyline.

Cash is king.
1. Find the best way to earn cash. Trade commonities, take up missions, etc.
2. Use the money you earn to upgrade your capital ship.
3. Shoot the living craps out of the enemies and proceed to the next galaxy.

By this point of my gameplay which is around 29hrs of playtime, game is becoming like a grind.
What kept me going is mainly the prospect of getting a bigger and more badass capital ship.

Some things that come into mind.
- Game is developed by a 2-person team, and for this price, a big plus
- Great graphics, music, and voice acting.
- No way to build a fleet and do massive scale attacks (at least I haven't found any yet)

Overall this is still a plus. Maybe 7/10. Can last you 20-30hrs at least.
As for me, probably looking at the next game to play soon.

reviewText:
If you're like I was and are hesitant because of the whole 2D space thing, don't be.  I barely notice it.  It plays well in 2D (not to say 3D wouldn't be better).

Reminds me a lot of Privateer, but with more sandbox, less story.

Lots of fun to be had here.

The combat is surprisingly deeper than I expected.
